div.p: Cicero translated (Prisc. vi. 63), Quid tu? unde tandem appares, o Socrate? an id quidem non dubium est, quin ab Alcibiade?
fai/nei: make one's appearance (cf. 315 e) was used popularly in the sense of h(/kein, parei=nai. Cf. Xen. Mem. ii. 8. 1 po/qen, e)/fh, *eu)/qhre, fai/nei;
dh=la: sc. e)sti/, here used adj. (cf. 330 a); not the particle dhladh/.

kunhgesi/ou: all languages apply the terms of the chase to the pursuit of love. Cf. Soph. 222 d th=| tw=n e)rw/ntwn qh/ra| to\n nou=n ou)/pw prose/sxes, Xen. Mem. i. 2. 24 *)alkibia/dhs d' au)= dia\ me\n ka/llos u(po\ pollw=n kai\ semnw=n gunaikw=n qhrw/menos.—This subst. is without a preceding art., just as though the following attribute tou= . . . w(/ran were lacking. See H. 668 a.

kalo\s a)nh/r: pred., cf. 341 a. Others would read a(nh/r, as subj.; but this anticipates the following a)nh\r me/ntoi. The youth in Athens, on the completion of his eighteenth year, became legally a)nh/r (e)peidh\ ei)s a)/ndras dokimasqei=en Isocr. vii. 37) by registration in the roll of the citizens of his deme.
w(s . . . ei)rh=sqai: for the inf. abs. see G. 268; H. 956. Cf. 339 e.—The slight blemish should receive a bare allusion.

au)toi=s: in such connections is nearly equiv. to mo/nois. Cf. Parm. 137 a e)peidh\ kai\ au)toi/ e)smen, Xen. An. ii. 3. 7 au)toi=s toi=s a)ndra/si . . . h)\ kai\ toi=s a)/llois, Ar. Ach. 504 au)toi\ ga/r e)smen, we are by ourselves. Cf. 320 a d, 337 c.
ti/ tou=to: sc. e)sti/n, cf. 310 d. An elliptical formula of daily life, nearly equiv. to ti/ tou=to diafe/rei; 331 c.

ou) . . . me/ntoi: the more common declaration, su\ me/ntoi e)paine/ths ei)=, you surely agree with, is expressed interr. with ou). Cf. Theaet. 163 e mnh/mhn ou) le/geis me/ntoi ti; Phaedr. 229 b, ou)k e)nqe/nde me/ntoi poqe\n le/getai o( *bore/as th\n *)wrei/quian a(rpa/sai; Charm. 159 b ou) tw=n kalw=n me/ntoi h( swfrosu/nh e)sti/;

Cf. Hom. *w 347 of Hermes, bh= d' i)e/nai kou/rw| ai)sumnhth=ri (a princely
youth) e)oikw/s, | prw=ton u(phnh/th|, tou= per xariesta/th h(/bh. So k 279. These verses, from which the sculptors afterwards derived the type of the statues of Hermes, are here peculiarly apt, since Alcibiades himself had served as a model for such statues. Cf. Clem. Al. Protrept. § 53, p. 47 P. kai\ oi( liqoco/oi tou\s *(erma=s *)aqh/nhsi pro\s *)alkibia/dhn a)pei/kazon.—Since the words are quoted from Homer, the customary Attic art. (xariesta/thn th\n h(/bhn) is wanting.

u(phnh/tou: that this even without prw=ton indicates the first bloom of youth, is shown by Photius, Lex., u(phnh/th|: a)kmai/w|: a)/rti geneiw=nti, and Pollux ii. 10, u(phnh/ths, e)n h)=ri th=s w(/ras, e)n a)kmh=|, e)n a)/nqei.
ti/ . . . nu=n: reverting to the original question.
kai\ ou)=n kai\ a)/rti: Socrates answers the first question last, and in truth I have just, etc. See H. 1048, 2.
u(pe\r e)mou= ei)=pe: cf. 336 b; 348 b.
paro/ntos . . . qama/: this a)/topo/n ti serves to excite the wonder of the e(/tairos and whets the curiosity of the reader.
ou)/te, te: for the correlation, cf. 347 e, 361 e. See H. 1044 a.

e)n th=|de th=| po/lei: i.e. in Athens. h(/de h( po/lis (like e)nqa/de, th=|de) refers to the city in or near which is the speaker; e)n tau/th| th=| po/lei, relatively, to the city previously mentioned; cf. Gorg. 468 e.
polu/ ge: sc. kalli/oni e)ne/tuxon. ge/ is freq. used in answers, strengthening the thought of the question, and may often be rendered yes.

ti\s: sometimes, as here, adds indefiniteness to the meaning of
adjs. and advs., thus enlarging and strengthening them, as the Lat. quidam. Cf. Xen. Mem. i. 3. 12 w(s deinh/n tina le/geis du/namin tou= filh/matos ei)=nai, how dreadful indeed, etc., Thuc. i. 138. 3 (*qemistoklh=s) diafero/ntws ti . . . a)/cios qauma/sai, in a remarkable degree, etc.
pw=s ou) me/llei: why should not? This and ti/ ou) me/llei are common phrases with Plato.

to\ sofw/teron . . . fai/nesqai: the words have a proverbial sound (as i.e. Sappho said o( de\ ka)/gaqos au)/tika kai\ ka/los e)/ssetai Frag. 101 Bgk.), the personal application being made only in the following sofw=| and sofwta/tw| me\n ou)=n. The new ka/llos is in a different realm from that of Alcibiades, sofw/teron not necessarily implying that Alcibiades is in any true sense sofo/s.
me\n ou)=n: immo vero, nay rather.
*prwtago/ras: the delay in uttering the name intensifies its effect.

ti/ . . . ou) dihgh/sw: cf. 317 d; Symp. 173 b ti/ ou)=n, e)/fh, ou) dihgh/sw moi; Phaedo 86 d ei) ou)=n tis u(mw=n eu)porw/teros e)mou=, ti/ ou)k a)pekri/nato; The surprise that the action has not already taken place contains an urgent exhortation to its performance (GMT. 19, N. 6), but ei) mh/ se/ ti kwlu/ei here and i(/na e)pakou/swsin 317 d, show that the expression has become a mere formula of exhortation. So the pres. in 310 e ti/ ou) badi/zomen;

We may picture a scene like the one in Charm. 155 b. Socrates is invited by some friends (h(mi=n, a)kou/ete) who are sitting in a palaestra or a ‘lesche,’ to take a seat and discourse to them. An Athenian would hardly walk abroad without at least one slave, while the wealthy had many, and those who owned none frequently attempted to conceal their poverty by hiring attendants. The manners of these slaves are described in [Xen.] Rep. Ath. i. 10 tw=n dou/lwn . . . plei/sth e)sti\n *)aqh/nhsin a)kolasi/a, kai\ ou)/te pata/cai e)/cestin au)to/qi, ou)/te u(peksth/setai/ soi (give place to you) o( dou=los, Ar. Nub. 7 ou)de\ kola/s' e)/cesti/ moi tou\s oi)ke/tas. Socrates evidently must secure his own seat.

diplh= kte(.: proverbial, cf. Soph. Ph. 1370 xou(/tw diplh=n me\n e)c e)mou= kth/sei xa/rin (you will gain double thanks), | diplh=n de\ patro/s.
From this point to the end of the dialogue Socrates narrates the circumstances of his interview with Protagoras.
baqe/os o)/rqrou: cf. Crito, 43 a o)/rqros baqu/s.

de\ a)delfo/s: in such double specifications, the Greek regularly uses de/, without me/n in the former member. Cf. Xen. An. i. 7. 9 *darei/ou kai\ *parusa/tidos pai=s, e)mo\s de\ a)delfo/s, Aesch. Pers. 150 mh/thr basile/ws, basi/leia d' e)mh/, Hdt. vii. 10 patri\ tw=| sw=|, a)delfew=| de\ e)mw=|, *darei/w|, h)go/reuon, Isae. ix. 23 e)me\ ga\r ui(o\n o)/nta *qeofra/stou sautou= de\ a)delfidou=n a)posterei=s a(/ moi oi( no/moi e)/dosan.
ti\s: Socrates, of course, had no special qurwro/s. Cf. 314 c.
eu)qu\s kte(.: he bursts in, without asking whether Socrates is awake, or decorously waiting to be announced.

*(ippokra/ths ou(=tos: not an address, since this would not be suited to the situation; but Socrates, who only hears his approaching visitor, without seeing him, remarks That is Hippocrates. Similarly Hipposthenidas in Plutarch de genio Socr. c. 18 *xli/dwn, e)/fh, nh\ to\n *(hrakle/a: feu=, mh/ ti xalepw/teron sumbe/bhke; Alcibiades in Symp. 213 b touti\ ti/ h)=n; *swkra/ths ou(=tos; Shakspere Jul. Caes. i. 3 ‘Casca, by your voice.’

vew/teron: the comp. in the questions of the curious Athenians (ti/ new/teron;) is familiar. The conservative view, ‘The new is rarely good,’ often allowed new/teros and ne/os to stand as euphemistic expressions for kako/s. Compare the uses of newteri/zein. Cf. Eur. Med. 37 de/doika d' au)th\n mh/ ti bouleu/sh| ne/on, Soph. Ant. 242, Ph. 784. As mh/ disclosed this sense in Socrates's question, Hippocrates hastened to allay his apprehension.
eu)= a)\n le/gois: not positive, like Apol. 24 e eu)= le/geis, but like our “That were well.” Cf. Soph. O. C. 647 me/g' a)\n le/gois dw/rhma th=s cunousi/as.
thnika/de: cf. l. 1, above.
prw/|hn: here equiv. to tri/thn h(me/ran, cf. 309 d. So, too, in the formula xqe\s kai\ prw/|hn.—Socrates's quiet manner is contrasted with the excitement of Hippocrates.
nh\ tou\s qeou/s: as though he needed to apologize for not coming sooner.
e(spe/ras: but not e)xqe/s g' e(spe/ras, for the civil day with the Greeks was reckoned from sunset to sunset, cf. 313 b.
e)piyhlafh/sas: for it was dark. Cf. Phaedo 99 b yhlafw=ntes oi( polloi\ w(/sper e)n sko/tei, Ar. Pax 691 e)yhlafw=men e)n sko/tw| ta\ pra/gmata.—

ski/mpodos: the frame of the low bed upon which Socrates was still lying. Cf. Eust. on Hom. II 612 to\n par' *)attikoi=s ski/mpoda, eu)telh= kli/nhn kai\ xqamalh/n, pela/zousan th=| gh=, Ar. Nub. 709 e)k tou= ski/mpodos | da/knousi/ m' e)ce/rpontes oi( *kori/nqioi.
e(spe/ras dh=ta: yes, last evening. dh=ta is strengthened from dh/, Hippocrates resuming after a pause.

*oi)no/hs: one deme of this name lay N.W. from Athens upon Mt. Cithaeron near Eleutherae, another N.E. near Marathon. The former must here be meant, as by this route fugitive slaves sooner reached the limits of Attica.—The frequent wars greatly facilitated the escape of discontented slaves. —
o( *sa/turos: shows that Socrates knows the slave, as also me/llwn soi fra/zein reveals the intimacy existing between Socrates and Hippocrates.

u(po\ . . . e)pelaqo/mhn: the freq. Attic usage of a neut. verb. const., like a pass., with u(po/ and the gen. of the cause. Cf. Apol. 17 a e)gw\ au)to\s u(p' au)tw=n o)li/gou e)mautou= e)pelaqo/mhn, Xen. An. v. 5. 9 a)ciou=men u(f' u(mw=n a)gaqo\n me/n ti pa/sxein, kako\n de\ mhde/n, Lys. XII. 96, Thuc. iii. 96. 1 *(hsi/odos o( poihth\s le/getai u(po\ tw=n tau/th| a)poqanei=n. See H. 819 d.
h)=lqon: for e)panh=lqon. Plato and other Attic writers freq. prefer simple to compound verbs. Cf. 320 a gegone/nai for diagegone/nai, 321 c e)/rxetai for e)pe/rxetai. —

dedeipnhko/tes: among the Attic Greeks the three meals were termed a)kra/tisma breakfast, a)/riston lunch, dei=pnon dinner; in Homer, a)/riston, dei=pnon, do/rpon. The dei=pnon was perhaps unusually late on this occasion, because Hippocrates had been awaited; still, it was often taken after sunset, cf. Lys. I. 22 tou/tw| h(li/ou deduko/tos i)o/nti e)c a)grou= a)ph/nthsa . . . e)ke/leuon sundeipnei=n.

e)/ti me
 . . . e)/peita: cf. Xen. An. vi. 2. 15 *cenofw=n de\ e)/ti me
 e)pexei/rhsen . . . e)kpleu=sai, quome/nw| de\ au)tw=| . . . e)sh/mhnen o( qeo\s . . . sustrateu/esqai. Strictly, Xen. still wished to sail away, when, etc.; or, paratactically, Xen. still wished to sail away, but, etc.; i.e. at first Xen. wished to sail away, but then, etc. Hell. ii. 4. 11 oi( de\ a)po\ *fulh=s e)/ti me
 e)pexei/rhsan mh\ a)nie/nai au)tou/s, e)pei\ de\ me/gas o( ku/klos w)
 pollh=s fulakh=s e)do/kei dei=sqai kte(. Elsewhere also e)/peita, like me/ntoi, toi/nun, a)ta/r, and other adversative conjs., is correl. with me/n.
nuktw=n: the pl. is used in Attic with reference to the different parts of the night, horae nocturnae; so e)k nuktw=n, me/sai nu/ktes. For the gen. after advs. of place, see G. 168; H. 757.

Cf. Hom. B 71 e)me\ de\ gluku\s u(/pnos a)nh=ken, Moore ‘Ere slumber's chain has bound me.’ Weariness held Hippocrates as if in bonds (e)k). He means that he slept longer than he intended, or he would have come earlier.
ou(/tw: Plato, more freq. than other writers, uses ou(/tws (314 c), e)/peita (319 d), ei)=ta (341 e) after partics., in imitation of the conversational style.
a)ndrei/an: here nearly equiv. to proqumi/an. Cf. Polit. 262 a proqumo/tata kai\ a)ndreio/tata. Socrates notices the eagerness and excitement of Hippocrates, and pretends ignorance of the reason.

a)dikei=: a)dikei=n is often equiv. to h)dikhke/nai, a)/dikon ei)=nai. The wrong continues in its effects, and so still exists. Similarly, nika=n be victor, h(tta=sqai be vanquished, diw/kein be prosecutor, feu/gein be an exile, h(/kein have come, oi)/xesqai have gone. Cf. 324 c. See G. 200 N. 3; H. 827.
au)tw=|, e)kei=non: both refer to the same person (Protagoras). Cf. Phaedo 111 b ta\s de\ w(/ras au)toi=s kra=sin (temperature) e)/xein toiau/thn, w(/ste e)kei/nous a)no/sous ei)=nai.—

a)\n au)tw=|... lang=greek>sofo/n: an ironical assurance, as though the payment of money were the sole condition needful. The receiving of money by the sophists for their instruction seemed to the best minds to be mercenary, and unworthy of the free and cultured Athenian. Cf. 311
b d, 328 b, 349 a, Ar. Nub. 98 ou(=toi dida/skous' , a)rgu/rion h)/n tis didw=|.
e)n . . . ei)/h: would that it depended on that. Cf. 319 c, 354 e, 356 d, 357 a, 313 a with acc. and inf.
w(s: causal. Cf. 335 d. See GMT. 81, N. 2.

e)pili/poimi: suffer to be lacking, omit; commonly intrans. Cf. Phil. 52 d ti/ pot' a)/ra, w)= *sw/krates, e)rwta=|s boulo/menos; *mhde\n w)= *prw/tarxe e)pilei/pein e)le/gxwn h(donh=s te kai\ e)pisth/mhs, 26 b kai\ a)/lla dh\ muri/a e)pilei/pw le/gwn. For the thought, cf. 313 b.

tw=n fi/lwn: cf. 311 d kai\ ta\ tw=n fi/lwn prosanali/skontes, 313 b, Symp. 218 d kai\ ei)/ ti a)/llo h)\ th=s ou)si/as th=s e)mh=s de/oio h)\ tw=n fi/lwn tw=n e)mw=n. —To avoid tw=n tw=n fi/lwn (the gen. of ta\ tw=n fi/lwn) one art. is omitted.

au)ta\ tau=ta: for this very purpose. —Hippocrates never thinks of raising the preliminary question, whether it is best to place himself under the teaching of Protagoras, — little dreaming of the opinions of his friend Socrates.
a)kh/koa au)de/n: sc. au)tou=, cf. 313 b ou)/te diei/lecai ou)depw/pote. He has never heard Protagoras discourse.
h)=: cf. Porphyr. on Hom. E 533 tw=n de\ *)attikw=n oi( me\n a)rxai=oi monogra/mmaton au)to\ proefe/ronto, oi( de\ new/- teroi su\n tw=| n.—
to\ pro/teron: the time is uncertain; perhaps B.C. 445. See Introd. § 1.
sofw/taton le/gein: like deino/tatos le/gein.—
ti/ ou) badi/zomen: see on 310 a.

w)gaqe/: is followed in the Mss. by e)kei=se i)/wmen, but the Athenians used mh/pw ge in replies, regularly omitting the repetition of the verb. Cf. Soph. Phil. 1410 stei=xe prosku/sas xqo/na. | HER. mh/pw ge, pri
 a)
 tw=n h(mete/rwn | a)i/h|s mu/qwn, Ar. Nub. 195 a)ll' ei)/siq) . . . | mh/pw ge, mh/pw g' , a)ll) e)pimeina/ntwn, Plato Phaedr. 242 a ka)gw\ a)pe/rxomai. PHAEDR. mh/pw ge, w)= *sw/krates, pri
 a)
 to\ kau=ma pare/lqh|, Aesch. Prom. 630 a)/koue dh/. CHO. mh/pw ge.

e)canastw=men ei)s th\n au)lh/n: cf. l. 12, Phaedo 116 a e)kei=nos me\n a)ni/stato ei)s oi)/khma/ ti w(s louso/menos, Xen. Symp. 9. 1 *)auto/lukos de\ e)cani/stato ei)s peri/paton. The prep. and connection imply the motion, ‘the going.’

qa/rrei, katalhyo/meqa: cf. Menex. fin. qa/rrei, ou) katerw=, Xen. Cyr. vii. 3. 13 a)lla\ qa/rrei, e)/fh, w)= *ku=re, ou) mh/ se kru/yw.—Protagoras's constant life within doors contrasts strongly with the habits of Socrates.
III.

2 ff. By way of preparing his young friend for the interview, Socrates wishes to awaken in his mind a question as to the real value of the costly instruction of Protagoras; a question which the vehement Hippocrates was in no mood to entertain. First, therefore, Socrates will elicit from him the vagueness of his quest; then, humbled by this discovery, Hippocrates is ready for the consideration of the main question.
r(w/mhs: relates generally to physical strength, but here to strength of will, fixedness of purpose. Cf. Polit. 259 c pro\s th\n th=s yuxh=s su/nesin kai\ r(w/mhn.
diesko/poun kai\ h)rw/twn: combining both in one act. Cf. Apol. 21 c diaskopw=n ou)=n tou/ton kai\ dialego/menos au)tw=|, 18 b u(mw=n tou\s pollou\s e)/peiqo/n te kai\ kathgo/roun e)mou=.
telw=n: fut., cf. telou=ntes 311 e.—
para\ ti/na kte(.: for a similar questioning, cf. Gorg. 447 c f.

Illustrations of a general question or of an abstract principle by particular examples, introduced by w(/sper a)/n, belong in such a marked way to the peculiarities of the style of the Platonic Socrates, that one may reasonably see in them a practice of the actual Socrates. In these passages it is no rare thing to find several members with ei), inserted one into another, and ‘anacolutha,’ in which the w(/sper is forgotten. We have here a prot., ei) . . . e)kei/nw|, then the apod. consisting of ei) . . . h)/reto, . . . a)pekri/nw. —The Athenians generally classed together physicians, sculptors, painters, flute-players, and sophists, as men whose professions were mercenary and to be adopted only through necessity. — Cf. 312 b, Gorg. 512 d, Luc. Somn. 9 ei) de\ kai\ *feidi/as h)\ *polu/kleitos ge/noio, th
 me
 te/xnhn a(/pantes e)paine/sontai, ou)k e)/sti de\ o(/stis tw=n i)do/ntwn, ei) nou=n e)/xoi, eu)/cait' a)/n soi o(/moios gene/sqai: oi(=os ga a)
 h)=|s, ba/nausos kai\ xeirw=nac kai\ a)poxeirobi/wtos nomisqh/sh| (you will be considered a mechanic and an artisan, living by manual toil). Cf. Plutarch Pericles 2 for nearly identical language: h( d' au)tourgi/a tw=n tapeinw=n th=s ei)s ta\ kala\ r(a|qumi/as ma/rtura to
 e)n toi=s a)xrh/stois po/non pare/xetai kaq) au(th=s: kai\ ou)dei\s eu)fuh\s ne/os h)\ to
 e)n *pi/sh| qeasa/menos *di/a gene/sqai *feidi/as e)pequ/mhsen h)\ th
 *(/hran th
 e)n *)/argei *polu/kleitos, ou)d) *)anakre/wn h)\ *filh/mwn h)\ *)arxi/loxos h(sqei\s au)tw=n toi=s poih/masin.

Hippocrates of Cos, the founder of the science of medicine, belonged to the family of the Asclepiadae, in which family the priesthood of Asclepius and the practice of medicine were hereditary. See also Phaedr. 270 c ei) me\n *(ippokra/tei ge tw=| tw=n *)asklhpiadw=n dei= ti piqe/sqai.
a)pekri/nw: see on 313 a.
o(/ti: sc. me/llw telei=n *(ippokra/tei misqo/n.

Phidias, son of Charmides, the Athenian, whose creative art produced ideals of the gods, and Polycletus (cf. 328 c) of Argos, unequalled in the expression of human beauty, represent together the culmination of Greek plastic art. They were older contemporaries of Socrates.
to\n *)aqhnai=on: is added in contrast with *)argei=on.
ei)=en: a particle related to ei)=a, not to the opt. ei)/h or ei)=en. It marks a conclusion and transition, and is much used by Plato.

a)
 me/n: after ei) me/n or e)a/n the principal sent. is freq. omitted when an antithesis with ei) de/ follows. eu)= e)/xei, it is well, can generally be supplied, as Hom. A 135 f. a)ll' ei) me
 dw/sousi ge/ras mega/qumoi *)axaioi/ | . . . | ei) de/ ke mh\ dw/wsin, e)gw\ de/ ken au)to\s e(/lwmai. Cf. 325 d below. The connection sometimes calls for a more definite expression, as here, i.e. tau=ta a)nali/skontes. See on 328 b; cf. Xen. Mem. iii. 9. 11 kai\ (e)pedei/knuen) tou\s a)/llous pa/ntas a)
 me
 au)toi\ h(gw=ntai e)pi/stasqai e)pimelei=sqai (sc. au)tou\s e)pimeloume/nous): ei) de\ mh/, toi=s e)pistame/nois peiqome/nous, and he showed that all the rest, if they thought themselves capable of attending to a matter (attended to it themselves); otherwise, they trusted those who were capable. Xen. An. vii. 7. 15 ei) me
 su/ ti e)/xeis pro\s h(ma=s le/gein (sc. le/ge): ei) de\ mh/, h(mei=s pro\s se\ e)/xomen. Even e)a
 me/n may be followed by ei) de/. See GMT. 53, N. 1; 52, 1, N. 2; H. 904 a; 906 a.
ei)pe/ moi: the imv. sing. is used before several vocs. when one person is prominently addressed. Cf. Euthyd. 283 b ei)pe/ moi, e)/fh, w)= *sw/krate/s te kai\ u(mei=s oi( a)/lloi.
a)/llo: “as Phidias is termed sculptor, Homer poet, what other name do we hear similarly given to Protagoras?”

a)galmatopoio/n: sc. o)/noma. With verbs of naming, the name itself is generally in appos. with o)/noma, e)pwnumi/a, or some similar word; the latter subst. may, however, be omitted. Cf. 315 e, Rep. ii. 369 c tau/th| th=| cunoiki/a| e)qe/meqa po/lin o)/noma, Hdt. vi. 63 *dhma/rhton au)tw=| ou)/noma e)/qeto.

o)noma/zousi . . . ei)=nai: cf. 325 a, Lach. 192 a o(\ e)n pa=sin o)noma/zeis taxuth=ta ei)=nai, Phil. 13 b ti/ e)no\n pa/sas h(dona\s a)gaqo\n ei)=nai prosagoreu/eis; a freq. const. with verbs of naming or calling.

e)rxo/meqa: more vivid than me/llomen, emphasizes the partic. Cf. 313 a, Theaet. 198 e, Hdt. i. 5 e)gw\ de\ peri\ me\n tou/twn ou)k e)/rxomai e)re/wn. The Eng. has the same idiom, ‘we are going to pay,’ i.e. ‘we purpose to pay.’
31 ff.

ei) prose/roito: sc. ti/ a)\n a)pokri/naio; or ti/ a)\n fai/hs; cf. Crat. 392 c ei)/ tis e)/roito/ se, po/teron oi)/ei o)rqo/teron kalei=n ta\ o<*>no/mata tou\s fronimwte/rous h)\ tou\s a)froneste/rous; HERM. dh=lon dh\ o(/ti tou\s fronimwte/rous fai/hn a)/n suppose one should ask whether you think the wise or the unwise likely to give names the more correctly (what would you reply?), etc.

e)ruqria/sas: syn chronous with ei)=pen. See G. 204, N. 2; H. 856 b. On the passage, cf. Demetrius peri\ e(rmhnei/as 218 in Spengel Rhet. Gr. iii. 309 o(/per dh\ o( *pla/twn fhsi
 e)pi\ tou= *(ippokra/tous, e)ruqria/sas . . . gene/sqai, o(/ti me
 e)narge/stato/n e)sti, panti\ dh=lon: h( d) e)na/rgeia ge/gonen e)k th=s fronti/dos th=s peri\ to
 lo/gon kai\ tou= a)pomnhmoneu=sai, o(/ti nu/k|twr pro\s au)to
 ei)sh=lqen o( *(ippokra/ths.—
u(pe/faine/ ti h(me/ras: there was a glimmer of daylight.
ei) . . . ti e)/oike: with indef. subj.; a freq. turn with Plato in such reasonings; cf. 330 b.
me/n: admitting with a blush the conclusion forced by the argument, he intends making some qualification with a de/, but is forestalled by Socrates. See on c, l. 8, below.
ei)s . . . pare/xwn: before the Greeks. Cf. 349 a, Thuc. vi. 31. 4 cune/bh e)s tou\s a)/llous *(/ellhnas e)pi/deicin ei)kasqh=nai it came about that it looked like a display before the other Greeks.
sauto/n: cf. 348 e.

“But then, since you do not wish to become a sophist.” Cf. Euthyd. 290 e a)ll' a)/ra, w)= pro\s *dio/s, mh\ o( *kth/sippos h)=n o( tau=t) ei)pw/n; Apol. 25 a a)ll) a)/ra, w)= *me/lhte, mh\ oi( e)n th=| e)kklhsi/a| diafqei/rousi tou\s newte/rous;—

mh\ ou)... lang=greek>u(polamba/neis: mh\ indicates properly a depend. question after an implied verb of fear or caution; ou) is const. with toiau/thn. (I question) whether you do not mean that . . . will be not of this sort, but, etc.; i.e. doubtless you mean that, etc. See H. 867; GMT. 46, N. 4 and N. 5 a. Cf. Meno 89 c i)/sws nh\ *di/a: a)lla\ mh\ tou=to ou) kalw=s w(mologh/samen;
grammatistou= kte(.: cf. 325 d ff.
e)pi\ te/xnh|: cf. 315 a; to practise it as an art, to make it a profession.
e)pi\ paidei/a|: for the sake of general culture. Cf. Gorg. 485 a filosofi/as me\n o(/son paidei/as xa/rin kalo\n mete/xein.
to/n, to/n: generic arts. See H. 659.
i)diw/thn: here contrasted with dhmiourgo/s (one who pursues the art, cf. 327 c), elsewhere with poihth/s, i)atro/s etc. Cf. 322 c, 327 c, 344 c, 345 a; i)diwteu/ein 327 a.
e)leu/qeron: liberalis, superior in dignity to the moneygetting class. See on 311 b.
pa/nu me\n ou)=n: emphatic form of assent.

It seems, then, that Hippocrates does not know what he wishes to obtain from Protagoras. The question naturally follows, what a sophist is, essentially; whether he has anything of value to impart, and whether it is a safe experiment to throw oneself precipitately (cf. 313 b) under his instruction, without previously ascertaining its precise nature.
tou= [ti/nos] pe/ri: sc. lanqa/nei me.—
o(/ti me/lleis kte(.: o(/ti depends upon lanqa/nei, but with qauma/zoim' a)/n the discourse abandons the depend. const.
qerapeu=sai: the care of the soul by sophist and philosopher is often compared to the physician's treatment of the body, cf. 357 e *prwtago/ras o(/de fhsi\n i)atro\s ei)=nai (sc. th=s a)maqi/as).

pra/gmati: the calling of the sofisth/s a thing has somewhat of mocking humor. Cf. Ar. Eccl. 441 gunai=ka d' ei)=nai pra=gm) e)/fh noubustiko\n kai\ xrhmatopoio/n (clever and money-making), Plato Gorg. 520 b me/mfesqai tou/tw| tw=| pra/gmati (i.e. the people) o(\ au)toi\ paideu/ousin. Still stronger are the expressions me/ga pra=gma, me/ga xrh=ma. Cf. Hdt. iii. 132 h)=n de\ me/giston prh=gma *dhmokh/dhs para\ basile/i, Dem. XXXV. 15 *la/kritos, me/ga pra=gma, *)isokra/tous maqhth/s.
me/n: confirmative, in truth. Freq. used alone in questions and replies. Hippocrates seems to speak with more confidence here than in a above.
In sofisth/s Hippocrates thinks he recognizes the stem ist-, o(\s ta\ sofa\ e)p-i/st-atai, as Crat. 406 b *)/artemis is explained as a)reth=s i(/stwr, and 407 c *(/hfaistos as o( fa/eos i(/stwr.

ti/: depends upon tw=n sofw=n. ta\ ti/ sofa/; i.e. the knowledge relating to what? in the next line the thought is completed, ta\ pro^s th\n a)pergasi/an th\n tw=n ei)ko/nwn that which relates to the portrayal of forms.

kai\ ta)=lla ou(/tws: sc. ei)/poimen a)/n. So freq. with kai\ ta)=lla a verb is to be supplied from the context, i.e. 319b kai\ ta)=lla pa/nta ou(/tws sc. poiou=ntas, Symp. 176a kai\ ta)=lla ta\ nomizo/mena sc. poih/santas, Gorg. 509 c deute/ran de\ th\n tou= deute/rou kakou= (sc. boh/qeian) kai\ tri/thn th\n tou= tri/tou, kai\ ta)=lla ou(/tws (sc. e)/xein).
e)sti/: sc. e)pisth/mwn from the previous context.
e)pista/ths: here equiv. to e)pisth/mwn, as comes out clearly in Crito 47 b tw=| e)pista/th| kai\ e)pai+/onti.—
ti/... lang=greek>h)/: equiv. to ti/ a)/llo . . . h)/.

At first Hippocrates replied confidently (e)gw\ me\n kte(.), now, with less assurance, he yet gives a somewhat fitting answer (h)\ . . . le/gein); finally, however, he has no longer any reply to urge. For ou)ke/ti, cf. 321 d, Phaedo 100 d ou) ga\r e)/ti tou=to diisxuri/zomai.
peri\ o(/tou kte(.: for a similar examination, cf. Gorg. 450 e ff.
peri\ ou(=per: follows also e)pi/statai, which here is equiv. to e)pisth/mwn e)sti/n.
V.
e)/rxei: cf. 311 e.

h)\ ei) me
 kte(.: the sent. ei) me
 . . ., polla\ a)
 perieske/yw is in its thought subord., as a concessive (while), to the following sent. o(\ de\ kte(., as is often the case in sents. with me/n. In such cases the former member properly does not belong to the main argument, but is introduced to emphasize the latter by contrast. Cf. Dem. de Cor. 160 ai)sxro/n e)stin ei) e)gw\ me
 ta\ e)/rga tw=n u(pe u(mw=n po/nwn u(pe/meina, u(mei=s de\ mhde\ tou\s lo/gous au)tw=n a)ne/cesqe it is shameful if (while) I bore the burden of the toils in your behalf, but you will not tolerate even the recital; where only the latter fact is shameful. Rarely the clause with me/n is the main, and that with de/ the subord. clause, cf. Xen. Mem. i. 2. 9. Similar in Latin are paratactic interr. clauses, as Cic. Tusc. 5. 90 an Scythes Anacharsis potuit pro nihilo pecuniam ducere, nostrates philosophi facere non poterunt. This whole period, with its repetitions, its pleasing, free, conversational style, doubtless vividly recalled the manner of Socrates.

diakinduneu/onta: const. here with acc. and inf.; in Thuc. vii. I, with the simple inf. ei)/te diakinduneu/swsin e)spleu=sai, as freq. kinduneu/ein.—There
were no qualifications legally prescribed for physicians, and the patient in ancient times ‘ran a considerable risk.’ Cf. Gorg. 514d; Pliny N. H. xxix. 1 discunt (medici) periculis nostris, et experimenta per mortes agunt.
perieske/yw, pareka/leis: the ideas of saying, answering, considering, in such hypothetical sents., Plato very often puts into the aor. (cf. 311

b c), prob. to indicate the momentary occurrence or beginning of the action. Cf. Theaet. 144e ei) nw=|n e)xo/ntoin e(kate/rou lu/ran e)/fh au)ta\s h(rmo/sqai o(moi/ws (if each of us held a lyre, and he said they were tuned alike), po/teron eu)qu\s a)\n e)pisteu/omen h)\ e)peskeya/meq' a)/n, ei) mousiko\s w)\n le/goi; See GMT. 49, 2, N. 5.

th\n yuxh/n: explanatory of o(\ kte(. Cf. 339 a, 351 a, 354 c, Rep. ix. 583 e o(\ metacu\ a)/ra nu=n dh\ a)mfote/rwn e)/famen ei)=nai, th\n h(suxi/an, tou=to/ pote a)mfo/tera e)/stai, lu/ph te kai\ h(donh/ so then that which we termed the intermediate state, namely, rest, will be both pain and pleasure.
e)n w(=|: see on 310 d.

peri\ de\ tou/tou: cf. 325 b f. e)f' w(=n de\ . . . tau=ta d) a)/ra. So when two periods consisting of prot. and apod. are united in a larger period by me\n . . . de/, the me/n and de/ of the protases are freq. repeated in the apodoses. Cf. Apol. 28
d e.

ei)/te kai\ ou): in the second mem ber of a depend. alternative question (whether . . . or not) ou) and mh/ are used indifferently; cf. l. 15 below; but in depend. nominal questions, distinguishing between what is and what is not, mh/ is used when the verb is not repeated, otherwise either ou) or mh/. For examples of nominal questions, cf. 314 a (l. 47), Xen. Mem. iii. 6. 10. See G. 283, 1, N.; H. 1022a.

tw=| . . . ce/nw|: when a subst. with the art. takes an attrib. modifier, a dem., esp. ou(=tos, may be inserted after the modifier and before the noun. Cf. 338 a to\ a)kribe\s tou=to ei)=dos, Dem. VI. 21 ai( pro\s tou\s tura/nnous au(=tai li/an o(mili/ai, Plato Phil. 50 b e)n th=| tou= bi/ou cumpa/sh| tragw|di/a|. From the point of view of the Athenians, ce/nw| places in a clearer light the inconsiderateness of Hippocrates, and here by its position it intensifies the reproach of Socrates.

o)/rqrios: temporal adj. for adv. Cf. Thuc. ii. 49. 4 diefqei/ronto oi( plei=stoi e)natai=oi kai\ e(bdomai=oi u(po\ tou= e)nto\s kau/matos (on the ninth and the
seventh day), Hom. A 424, 472, 497, a 443, and very freq. See Seymour Hom. Lang. and Verse § 38; G. 138, N. 7; H. 619.
w(s h)/dh diegnwkw/s: as though you had already fully decided.
suneste/on: su/neimi is used, like suggi/gnomai, with the meaning am (or become) one's pupil.
o(\n kte(.: cf. 310 e.
diei/lecai: sc. au)tw=|. Instead of the rel. repeated in a different case, a personal or dem. pron. is commonly used; or, as here, the pron. <*> be omitted altogether. See G. 156; H. 1005.

sofisth/n: a case of ‘prolepsis’ or anticipation; in which, to give it greater emphasis, a subst. is transferred from a depend. to the principal clause, usually with change of case. Cf. 341 d oi)=mai *pro/dikon sou= dokei=n a)popeira=sqai, ei) oi(=o/s t' e)/sei kte(., Xen. Mem. i. 4. 13 ti/nos ga\r a)/llou zw/|ou yuxh\ prw=ta me\n qew=n h)/|sqhtai o(/ti ei)si/. See H. 878.

e)/oiken: sc. e)me\ a)gnoei=n. Cf. Rep. i. 346 c h(/ntina a)/ra w)fe/leian koinh=| w)felou=ntai pa/ntes oi( dhmiourgoi/, dh=lon o(/ti koinh=| tini\ tw=| au)tw=| prosxrw/menoi (auailing themselves of some self-same thing) a)p' e)kei/nou w)felou=ntai. *)/eoiken, e)/fh (sc. au)tou\s w)felei=sqai kte(.). So in many places, where e)/oiken forms the answer.

e)/mporos h)\ ka/phlos: wholesale or retail dealer. This comparison often appears in Plato (cf. Soph. 223 d, 224 d, 231 d) and in later writers. On the terms, see Rep. ii. 371 d h)\ ou) kaph/lous kalou=men tou\s pro\s w)nh/n te kai\ pra=sin diakonou=ntas i(drume/nous e)n a)gora=| (those engaged in buying and selling, sitting in the market-place), tou\s de\ planh/tas e)pi\ ta\s po/leis e)mpo/rous; Soph. 223 d, Polit. 289 e. Becker Charicles (Göll) ii. 183 ff. —
ti\s: a sort of. See on 334 c.

yuxh/: the art. (not merely generic) may be omitted with yuxh/, sw=ma, and their parts. Before ga/r in answers, yes or no may easily be supplied; we might render certainly. Cf. Soph. Phil. 755 deino/n ge tou)pi/sagma tou= nosh/matos (the burden of the disease) PHIL. deino\n ga\r ou)de\ r(hto/n, Plato Rep. vi. 502 c cumbai/nei ga/r, e)/fh. Hippocrates was ready to purchase, at any price, what Protagoras brought. The comparison was therefore at once obvious to him; still, as he had before shown that he had no clear conception of what he could
learn from Protagoras, he now makes the further confession of his ignorance concerning the nature of this substance by which the soul is nourished. Socrates responds to his question with the intelligible but indefinite maqh/masi, in order at once to add the warning against seeking the instruction of the sophists before he has ascertained precisely what maqh/mata are to be derived from them. The words o(/pws ge mh\ kte(. cannot be separated from those which precede them, and must therefore be the utterance of Socrates, as must also maqh/masi dh/pou, h)=n d' e)gw/.
e)capath/sei: the Mss. read e)capath/sh|, but such exhortations and warnings with o(/pws and o(/pws mh/ take only the fut. See H. 886; Kr. Spr. 54, 8, 7. But see for oppos. view Kühn. 552, N. 6.

kai\ ga ou(=toi kte(.: the ignorance of the trader is more fully set forth in Gorg. 517 d ff. tou/twn ga (sc. siti/wn, potw=n, i(mati/wn kte(.) poristiko
 ei)=nai h)\ ka/phlon o)/nta h)\ e)/mporon . . ., ou)de
 qaumasto/n e)stin o)/nta toiou=ton do/cai kai\ au(tw=| kai\ toi=s a)/llois qerapeuth
 ei)=nai sw/matos, panti\ tw=| mh\ ei)do/ti, o(/ti e)/sti tis para\ tau/tas te/xnh gumnastikh/ te kai\ i)atrikh/, h(\ dh\ tw=| o)/nti e)sti\ sw/matos qerapei/a.—
w(=n... lang=greek>a)gwgi/mwn: depend. on o(/ ti following.

peri\ to\ sw=ma: with reference to the body. In such expressions the prep. with the acc. brings out the quality of the adj. more distinctly and independently than would a simple gen., and is preferred by Plato, with whom however it becomes almost a mannerism. Cf. pro\s th
 yuxh/n below, Gorg. 517 e ei)de/nai o(/ ti to\ xrhsto
 kai\ ponhro
 tw=n siti/wn h)\ potw=n e)sti
 ei)s a)reth
 sw/matos.
a)ei/: often means in each case, every time.
e)painou=si: as Protagoras afterwards does, cf. 318
w(s d' au(/tws: after Homer less freq. than w(sau/tws de/. Even when de/ intervenes, the w(s is not accented, although it stands for ou(/tws.—
oi( w)nou/menoi: sc. a)gnooi=en a)/n.

tugxa/neis e)pisth/mwn: Plato rarely uses tugxa/nein without a partic. Cf. Phaedr. 230 a ei)/te ti qhri/on tugxa/nw *tufw=nos poluplokw/teron (more complex), Rep. ii. 369 b e)peidh\ tugxa/nei h(mw=n e(/kastos ou)k au)ta/rkhs, a)lla\ pollw=n e)ndeh/s since no one of us is self-sufficing, but each has many wants, Tim. 61 c tugxa/nei de\ ou)/te tau=ta ou)/t' e)kei=na dunata\ i(kanw=s lexqh=nai.

toi=s filta/tois: these are, in Legg. i. 650 a, wife, sons, and daughters (e)pitre/ponta au(tou= qugate/ras te kai\ ui(ei=s kai\ gunai=kas, ou(/tws e)n toi=s filta/tois kinduneu/santa imperilling one's dearest interests), here h( yuxh/, its wellbeing, i.e. virtue, wisdom; similarly Gorg. 513 a o(/pws mh\ su\n toi=s filta/tois (at the loss of what is dearest) h( ai(/resis h(mi=n e)/stai tau/ths th=s duna/mews th=s e)n th=| po/lei.—

kubeu/h|s: the Greeks sometimes compared life to a game of chance; cf. Rep. x. 604 c; Terent. Ad. iv. 7. 21 ita vitast hominum, quasi quom ludas tesseris; and used kubeu/ein tini/, peri/ tini of a frivolous and fool-hardy risk, like our ‘stake upon the die.’ Cf. the tragic verse in Polyb. ii. 63 dei= th\n taxi/sthn e)kkubeu/ein toi=s o(/lois, Polybius in Suidas, s.v. ku/bos, oi( me\n a)logisti/an kai\ mani/an e)/fasan ei)=nai to\ paraba/llesqai kai\ kubeu/ein tw=| bi/w|. —

kai\ kinduneu/h|s: literal and figurative expressions are sometimes combined, the literal expression following and explaining the former. Cf. 334 d su/ntemne/ moi ta\s a)pokri/seis kai\ braxute/ras poi/ei, Acta Apost. xiv. 17 e)mpiplw=n trofh=s kai\ eu)frosu/nhs ta\s kardi/as u(mw=n.
a)/llois: i.e. other than the body.
a)pofe/rein: sc. to\n pria/menon, the purchaser, from the preceding circumst. partic.
kataqe/nta: cf. 328 c.

to\ ma/qhma . . . labo/nta: corresponds to de/casqai ei)s to\ sw=ma above,
and kai\ maqo/nta to pio/nta h)\ fago/nta, hence, on learning and so receiving into the soul.

ne/oi w(/ste kte(.: too young to determine. Yet not the degree of the quality but the quality itself is declared to be unsuited to the end, which is put in the inf., or inf. with w(/ste. Cf. Menex. 239 b o( xro/nos braxu\s dihgh/sasqai, Eur. Andr. 80 ge/rwn e)kei=nos w(/ste s' w)felei=n parw/n. See G. 261, 1; H 642. —Contrast the less modest expression of Protagoras 317 c.
a)nakoinwsw/meqa: cf. 317 d.

oi)=mai de\ . . . *kei=on: sc. au)to/qi ei)=nai. Cf. 316 d h)/|sqhmai, sc. prokalu/ptesqai, Symp. 176 a xalepw=s e)/xw u(po\ tou= xqe\s po/tou, oi)=mai de\ kai\ u(mw=n tou\s pollou/s, Apol. 25 e tau=ta e)gw/ soi ou) pei/qomai, oi)=mai de\ ou)de\ a)/llon a)nqrw/pwn ou)de/na. The words are parenthetical.

do/can tau=ta: after the analogy of dokei= tau=ta. Cf. Xen. An. iv. I. 13 do/can de\ tau=ta e)kh/rucan ou(/tw poiei=n. Plural in Andoc. I. 81 do/canta de\ u(mi=n tau=ta ei(/lesqe a)/ndras ei)/kosi, Xen. Hell. iii. 2. 19 do/canta de\ tau=ta kai\ peranqe/nta ta\ strateu/mata a)ph=lqe. See G. 278, 2; H. 974 a.

e)peidh\ de\ kte(.: in order to represent the porter as behaving in a manner so characteristic, Plato makes the conversation come to an end before the house; as Socrates when alone, in Symp. 175 a concludes his meditations e)n toi=s proqu/rois. Doubtless this was a familiar habit of Socrates.
proqu/rw|: for this porch, see Becker Char. ii. 132; Hermann Griech. Privatalt. § 19.

dokei= moi: so oi)=mai, oi)=da is sometimes inserted parenthetically without w(s, o(/ti. Cf. Menex. 236 b o(/te moi dokei= suneti/qei to\n e)pita/fion lo/gon when, as I believe, she composed the funeral oration, Thuc. i. 3. 1 dokei= de/ moi, ou)de\ tou)/noma tou=to cu/mpasa/ pw ei)=xen, Soph. O. C. 1615 sklhra\n me/n, oi)=da, also 309 b, 323 d, 327 b.

o( qurwro/s: in the house of the wealthy there was
always at that time a porter, whose duty it was in his qurwrei=on to watch all that passed in and out, to open the door which was usually closed, and to announce visitors (ei)sagge/llein or prosagge/llein). Not infrequently these porters were surly (cf. Philodem. peri\ kakiw=n § 9, prosagge/llein ou) qe/lontes h)\ skoraki/zontes h)/ ti toiou=ton e)pile/gontes), but here the reluctance of the faithful old eunuch points to the senseless doings in the house of his young master. Socrates, to be sure, he might have known; but this is another touch of Plato's, to show that Socrates was a beginner as yet.

ou) sxolh\ au)tw=|: a customary announcement to unwelcome visitors. In Cic. de Senec. 10, Cato remarks nemo adhuc convenire me voluit, cui fuerim occupatus. Symp. 212d, when a company of revellers knocks at the door late at night, Agatho bids his servants, e)a\n me/n tis tw=n e)pithdei/wn h)=|, kalei=te: ei) de\ mh/, le/gete, o(/ti ou) pi/nomen, a)lla\ a)napauo/meqa (have gone to bed) h)/dh.—

au)tw=|: himself; so slaves called their masters, pupils their teachers, parasites their patrons. Cf. Poll. iii. 74 *)aristofa/nhs me/ntoi kata\ th
 tw=n pollw=n sunh/qeian to
 despo/thn au)to
 ke/klhken, also the au)to\s e)/fh, ipse dixit of the pupils of Protagoras.

mo/gis kte(.: with difficulty the man was finally persuaded. Cf. Theaet. 160 e tou=to mo/lis pote\ e)gennh/samen Thuc. vii. 40 mo/lis pote\ a)ntanh/gonto, also mo/gis pws 328 d, Apol. 21 b mo/gis pa/nu e)pi\ zh/thsin au)tou= e)trapo/mhn after a long struggle I gave myself to an investigation, etc.

prostw/|w|: a narrow passage (qurwrei=on, qurw/n, pulw/n) led from the house-door to the porticos (to\ peri/stulon), which surrounded the court on all four sides, and which, as they lay before the different rooms, were termed prostw=|a. As nothing is said
here of the right or left, Protagoras is to be imagined as in the front and Hippias in the rear portico. Socrates and Hippocrates tarry a few moments in the passage, where, themselves unnoticed, they can survey the interior, including an adjacent room in which Prodicus is lying, cf. 315 d.

e)k tou= e)pi\ qa/tera: on one side, cf. Thuc. vii. 37, h( gumnhtei/a e)k tou= e)pi\ qa/tera prosh/|ei tw=| tei/xei (advanced to the wall from the opposite side), Xen. An. v. 4. 10. This use of the art. in such expressions is freq. with the Attic writers; cf. Euthyd. 297 c, e)k tou= e)p' a)ristera/ Phaedo 112b, ei)s to\ e)p' e)kei=na Thuc. viii. 104, e)n tw=| e)pe/keina, id. i. 32; iv. 72 e)n tw=| pro\ tou=.

*pa/ralos: h)=n me
 ga au)tw=| (Pericles) gunh\ prosh/kousa me
 kata\ ge/nos, sunw|khkui=a d' *(ipponi/kw| pro/teron, e)c ou(= *kalli/an e)/teke to
 plou/sion: e)/teke de\ kai\ para\ tw=| *periklei= *ca/nqippon kai\ *pa/ralon. Plutarch Pericles 24.
*xarmi/dhs: brother of Plato's mother; see the dialogue which bears his name.
The family of Philippides and Philomelus of Lower Paeania can be traced through many generations. See Boeckh Seewesen Urkunden, pp. 24 and 252 f.

Antimoerus owes his immortality to this single passage.—Even though the passage marks no clear distinction between maqhtai/ and e)ph/kooi, evidently those who walk nearest Protagoras are his more intimate pupils.
e)pi\ te/xnh|: see on 312b.
Const. oi(\ de\ o)/pisqen tou/twn h)kolou/qoun.

Cf. 316 c; and regarding Gorgias, Prodicus, and Hippias, Apol. 19 e tou/twn ga\r e(/kastos i)w\n ei)s e(ka/sthn tw=n po/lewn tou\s ne/ous, oi(=s e)/cesti tw=n e(autw=n politw=n proi=ka cunei=nai w(=| a)\n bou/lwntai (the young men, who may associate freely with whomsoever of their own citizens they desire), tou/tous pei/qousi ta\s e)kei/nwn cunousi/as a)polipo/ntas sfi/si cunei=nai xrh/mata dido/ntas kai\ xa/rin proseide/nai (paying them money and giving them thanks besides).
khlw=n th=| fwnh=|: Protagoras charms through the form, not the content, of his teaching.
oi( de\ e(/pontai: while they follow, a free extension of the rel. clause ou(\s a)/gei. The correl. of me/n l. 28 is de/ l. 31.

xorw=|: the tragic chorus, as it entered the theatre, was generally arranged in three rows (stoi=xoi, cf. sti/xoi), each consisting of five choreutae, the middle choreut in the row nearest to the spectators being the Coryphaeus. Similarly, here Protagoras is in the middle of a row of seven, the others walking behind these.
Socrates ironically admires the skill shown in keeping out of Protagoras's way.
tw=|: const. with pro/sqen *prwtago/rou after e)n. See G. 141, N. 3. f.; H. 666.
e)ph/kooi: mere silent listeners.
ei)s . . . ka/llista: took their positions in the rear in the most graceful manner.

to
 de\ met' ei)seno/hsa: these familiar words, and also kai\ *ta/ntalon ei)sei=don, would instantly, in the minds of Plato's contemporaries, shift the scene to Hades; for in the Homeric *ne/kuia Odysseus recounts, with these words, that he saw in Hades, among other shades, those also of Hercules and Tantalus. Cf. Hom. l 601 to
 de\ met' ei)seno/hsa bi/hn *(hraklhei/hn, ib. 582 kai\ mh
 *ta/ntalon ei)sei=don xale/p' a)/lge) e)/xonta. So then we are in the realm of shades; Protagoras, Hippias, Prodicus are famous names,—rather an outward form than a reality. The comparison to Tantalus is applied to Prodicus because of his sickly condition, in which he appeared xale/p' a)/lge) e)/xwn. To find, however, an allusion to Prodicus's greed or love of luxury, to see in Hippias a Hercules by reason of his combativeness, or to seek to find in the wise Protagoras a Sisyphus, would be frivolous, and would impair the humor of the comparison. Timon of Phlius had also parodied the *ne/kuia, as have Schiller, and Goethe in the Xenia (332-414).
qro/nw,

ba/qrwn: both words are suggestive of a boys' school. qro/nos, the high armchair, was, at least in later times, the accustomed seat of the rhetorician or sophist. Cf. Plut. peri\ tou= a)kou/ein, c. 12 a)nasta/ntes ga\r a)po\ tou= qro/nou kai\ a)poqe/menoi ta\ bibli/a . . . mikroi\ fai/nontai (sc. oi( sofistai/). ba/qra are the school benches, cf. 325 e.—Eryximachus, an intelligent physician of reputation, appears also in Phaedr. 268 a and Symp. 176 b ff.; with regard to Phaedrus, see the dialogue which bears his name; these two are everywhere represented as inti
mate friends. Andron is mentioned also in Gorg. 487 c as eagerly occupied with philosophy; he was afterwards perhaps one of the Four Hundred; probably the orator Androtion, against whom Demosthenes spoke, was his son.

Cf. 318 e; Hipp. Ma. 285 b a(\ su\ (Hippias) ka/llista e)pi/stasai, ta\ peri\ ta\ a)/stra te kai\ ta\ ou)ra/nia pa/qh. Astronomy was devoted to the investigation of the motions, nature, and origin of the heavenly bodies, and the general constitution of the universe,—h( fu/sis.
die/krine: Hippias pronounced his verdicts, like the judge or the schoolmaster, from his high seat. Cf. Rep. i. 348 b kai\ h)/dh dikastw=n tinw=n tw=n diakrinou/ntwn dehso/meqa.
a)/ra: refers to 314 b. So also e)pedh/mei, although at the time when Socrates is relating his story, Prodicus is still there. They found Socrates's conjecture respecting him (ibid.) correct.

oi)kh/mati: any room or chamber. Cf. Poll. ix. 45 oi)/khma para\ toi=s *)attikoi=s a(plw=s to\ oi)kh/simon: o(/ te ga\r *pla/twn e)n tw=| *prwtago/ra| e)/fh ‘h)=san d) . . . e)xrh=to,’ Symp. 217 d ou)dei\s e)n tw=| oi)kh/mati a)/llos kaqhu=den h)\ h(mei=s.

w(s tamiei/w|: cf. Thuc. vii. 24 w(/sper ga\r tamiei/w| xrwme/nwn tw=n *)aqhnai/wn toi=s tei/xesi. The changed contents of the store-room, and the e)kkenw/sas, taken with the vexation of the eunuch, complete the picture of the state of things in Callias's house.

kw|di/ois: cf. Poll. v. 16 de/rma tou= proba/tou kw/|dion. Cold weather, sickness, and effeminacy, caused people to wrap themselves in all sorts of skins and coverings. Cf. the description of the hopeful son, Ar. Nub. 10 e)n pe/nte sisu/rais e)gkekordulhme/nos wrapped up in five skins. Prodicus is represented as sickly, cf. 317 e, Plut. ei) presbut. politeute/on p. 791 e *pro/dikon to
 sofisth
 h)\ *filhta=n to
 poihth
 . . . ne/ous me/n, i)sxnou\s de\ kai\ nosw/deis kai\ ta\ polla\ klinopetei=s di) a)rrwsti/an o)/ntas (thin and sickly, and for the most part confined to the bed by their ailments).

tisi\ . . . kai\ ma/la polloi=s: tine\s polloi/ and similar combinations are not uncommon. Cf. Ar.
Av. 1014 keki/nhntai/ tines plhgai\ suxnai/ very frequent blows are set agoing, Plato Legg. iii. 678 d pampo/llais tisi/n (sc. geneai=s), 682 b e)n polloi=s tisi xro/nois.

Pausanias appears also in Symp. 176 a ff. as one of the more noteworthy persons in the cultivated Athenian society of that day; both in the Symp. l.c., 177 e, 193 b, and in Xen. Symp. c. 8, is his love for Agathon mentioned. Agathon, son of Tisamenus, was rich and handsome, and gained favor for his tragedies by a Gorgian splendor of language; he went later to the court of Archelaus in Macedonia, where he died about 401 B.C. We are to think of him here as about sixteen years old.

d' ou)=n: contrasts with a previous statement of conceded uncertainty, one as to which there is no doubt; but at any rate, sed certe. Cf. Xen. An. i. 2. 12 and 22, 3. 5; Plato Apol. 17 a, 34 e ei)/ me\n qarrale/ws e)gw\ e)/xw pro\s qa/naton h)\ mh/, a)/llos lo/gos, pro\s d' ou)=n do/can kte(., whether I can face death bravely or not is another matter, but certainly in view of our reputation I do not think it best, etc.
kalo/s: with meira/kion, paidika/, etc., the natural gender prevails. Cf. Lach. 180 e ta\ ga\r meira/kia ta/de pro\s a)llh/lous oi)/koi dialego/menoi qama\ e)pime/mnhntai *swkra/tous.—

e)/doca: “if I rightly remember.” Cf. Theaet. 142 c dokei= ga/r moi o)li/gon pro\ tou= qana/- tou e)ntuxei=n au)tw=| meiraki/w| o)/nti for, I believe, a little while before his own death, he met him, while still a youth.

ei) . . . tugxa/nei w)/n: if it should be found that he is, etc.; an elliptical prot., representing the object of wonder not as a matter of fact, but as more or less uncertain. Cf. 336 c; Thuc. i. 121. 5 deino
 a)
 ei)/h, ei) oi( me
 e)kei/nwn su/mmaxoi ou)k a)perou=sin, h(mei=s de\ ou)k a)/ra dapanh/somen if it should prove that their allies will not weary of paying, while we will not spend our money. See GMT. 56; H. 926.

h)=n kte(: there was this youth. Cf. Phaedo 59 b ou(=to/s te dh\ o( *)apollo/dwros tw=n e)pixwri/wn parh=n kai\ o( *krito/boulos kai\ o( path\r au)tou= *kri/twn, kai\ e)/ti *(ermoge/nhs kai\ *)antisqe/nhs. h)=n de\ kai\ *kth/sippos o( *paianieu\s kai\ *mene/cenos kai\ a)/lloi tine\s tw=n e)pixwri/wn, where, because parh=n precedes, h)=n signifies Ctesippus also was (sc. present) Rep. x. 615 d e)kei=no/n te katei/domen kai\ a)/llous sxedo/n ti au)tw=n tou\s plei/stous tura/nnous: h)=san de\ kai\ i)diw=tai/ tines tw=n mega/la h(marthko/twn, we saw him and others of whom the most were tyrants; and there were also (to be seen) some private persons who had committed great crimes, Symp. 173 b *)aristo/dhmos h)=n tis (in reply to ti/s soi dihgei=to;), 180 c ei)=nai. Adimantus was not an unusual name in Athens. Of those here mentioned
the son of Cepis is unknown; but the son of Leucolophides appears also in Ar. Ran. 1513; he is the general who was charged with treachery in the affair of Aegos Potami. Cf. Xen. Hell. ii. I. 32; Lys. XIV. 38. His property was confiscated; C. I. Att. I. 274, 275, 276.
e)/xwn: e)/xein with an adv. of condition is equiv. to ei)=nai with an adj.

pa/ssofos: an epithet frequently applied ironically by Plato to the sophists. Cf. Euthyd. 271 c pa/nsofoi a)texnw=s (Euthydemus and Dionysodorus). Used of the Eleatic and Heraclitic philosophers; cf. Theaet. 181 b, Rep. i. 331 e sofo\s ga\r kai\ qei=os a)nh/r (sc. Simonides).
w(s fh\|s su\ kte(.: cf. Symp. 186 e w(/s fasin oi(/de oi( poihtai\ kai\ e)gw\ pei/qomai, 212 b tau=ta dh\ e)/fh me\n *dioti/ma, pe/peismai d' e)gw/.

*kriti/as: well known as the leader of the Thirty Tyrants. His father and Plato's maternal grandfather were brothers. He gave himself diligently to the study of philosophy, and appears in several of Plato's dialogues.

toi/: indicates with emphasis the person addressed; most freq. with prons. Cf. Ar. Av. 406 i)w\ e)/poy (hoopoe), se/ toi kalw=, Plut. 1100 se/ toi le/gw, w)= *kari/wn, a)na/meinon. Here, in the presence of Callias and others, this directness is necessary.

e)na/millos ei)=nai: cope with, am a match for one. Cf. Rep. iv. 433 d e)na/millon a)/ra pro\s a)reth\n po/lews th=| te sofi/a| au)th=s kai\ th=| swfrosu/nh| kai\ th=| a)ndrei/a| h( tou= e(/kaston e)n au)th=| ta\ au(tou= pra/ttein du/namis then that each individual in the state should do his own work contributes as much toward the excellence of a city as its wisdom, temperance, and courage.

a)/n: always stands with the aor. inf. after verbs signifying to hope, expect, promise, suppose, and the like, when the governing verb does not make the reference to the fut. unmistakable. Cf. 318 a, 348 d, 353 b. See GMT. 22, 2, N. 3; 41, 3.

16 mo/nos: is const. with oi)/ei, being attracted into agreement with the subj. of the latter, while, according to the sense, we should expect mo/non agreeing with the subj. acc. of diale/gesqai. So regularly in oi)/omai dei=n, xrh=nai and similar expressions, the const. is unaffected by the impers. inf. Cf. Isocr. IX. 30 ou)x h(gh/sato dei=n xwri/on o)xuro
 katalabw
 periidei=n, Dem. XXI. 17 au)to\s dida/skein w)/|eto dei=n to
 xoro/n. See G. 138, N. 8; H. 944; 940.

Protagoras always displays his art in long and ornate discourses, aiming at thoughts which are striking rather than true. He does this here, in what he boastfully says of the antiquity of the sophistical art. The support for his statement he finds in the fact that all whom he quotes were eminent in the wisdom of practical life, which he maintains to be the essence of his own art. Socrates afterwards shows (cf. 342a ff.) that this method of grouping may be made very convenient. The supposed promh/qeia of Socrates serves perfectly the end of enabling Protagoras to declare his own fearlessness and to eulogize his profession. In fact, however, when he had offered to Socrates the decision as to the presence of others at the colloquy, Socrates had disclaimed any preference.
See on 315 a.
oi)kei/wn . . . newte/rwn: note the o(moiote/leuta.
to\n tau=ta pra/ttonta: emphati cally sums up the preceding accs., as does freq. ou(=tos alone. The clause is equiv. to xrh\ eu)labei=sqai tou=ton, but has more rhetorical dignity.

a)/llai dusme/neiai: moreover enmities. So freq. a new class is introduced by a)/llos. Cf. Apol. 36 b strathgiw=n kai\ dhmhgoriw=n kai\ tw=n a)/llwn a)rxw=n, where see Stallbaum, Gorg. 519 c tou/s te misqou\s a)posterou=ntes kai\ a)/llhn xa/rin ou)k a)podido/ntes (and returning no thanks either), Phaedr. 232 b. See G. 142, 2, N. 3; H. 705.
poiei=sqai . . . prokalu/ptesqai: in a clause with o(/ti the impf. would have been used. The pres. inf. and partic. belong also to the impf. See GMT. 15, 3; 16, 2; H. 853 a; 856 a.
oi(=on: attracted to the case of the antec.; see G. 153, N. 5; H. 1002.
*simwni/dhn: Protagoras's preference for Simonides appears thus early. Cf. 339 a ff.

The names of Orpheus and Musaeus were connected with various solemn rites and prophetic sayings; after the collection and arrangement of their poems by Onomacritus, the poets were often mentioned together.

*)/ikkos: cf. Paus. vi. 10. 2 *)/ikkos de\ o( *nikolai+/da *taranti=nos to/n te *)olumpiako\n ste/fanon e)/sxen e)pi\ penta/qlw| kai\ u(/steron gumnasth\s a)/ristos le/- getai tw=n e)f' e(autou= gene/sqai. According to Steph. Byz., s. v. *ta/ras, he was victorious, Ol. 77, 472 B.C. So Legg. viii. 840 a he is extolled w(s dia\ filoniki/an kai\ te/xnhn kai\ to\ meta\ tou= swfronei=n a)ndrei=on e)n th=| yuxh=| kekthme/nos because of his zeal for the games and skill in them, and of possessing in his soul courage combined with temperance.
ou)deno\s h(/ttwn: see on 324 d.

Herodicus was a teacher of gymnastics and medicine. His own debility led him to devise a strict regimen, which prolonged his life to old age, although he was always sickly. Cf. Rep. iii. 406 a, Aristot. Rhet. i. 5. 10, Plut. de sera ix. He was prob. born in Megara, and afterwards became a citizen of Selymbria on the Propontis. *shlumbrianoi/ is the form found in the Attic inscriptions of the fifth century, but *sa_lu^bri^/an in an Attic epitaph from the beginning of the fourth century B.C. (Kumanudes e)pigrafai\ e)pitu/mbioi No. 15.).

Agathocles is mentioned also in Lach. 180 d, and Pythoclides had instructed Pericles in music (acc. to
Aristotle in Plutarch Pericles 4). Of the musician Damon, also Pericles's friend, Plutarch says similarly ibid. a)/kros w)\n sofisth\s ou)k e)/laqe th=| lu/ra| parakalu/mmati xrw/menos it was no secret that he was a consummate sophist, and used the lyre as a pretext.

kata\ tou=to ei)=nai: in this matter at least; cf. e(kw\n ei)=nai, to\ e)pi\ sfa=s ei)=nai, to\ nu=n ei)=nai,—also without the art., Polit. 300 c ta\ para\ tw=n ei)do/twn ei)s du/namin ei)=nai (so far as possible) gegramme/na, Isae. II. 32 w)mo/samen eu)= poiei=n a)llh/lous kata\ du/namin ei)=nai. The inf., as an acc. of specification; indicates the sphere within which the declaration finds its place. See G. 268; H. 956 a.
ou)/ ti: very freq. in Plato (and in Homer) as a strengthened ou), by no means.

ou) ga\r laqei=n , kte(.: laqei=n, even after ga/r, depends upon h(gou=mai. For (I think) they do not escape the detection of those in authority. Cf. 351 a, Crat. 417 c tau/th| moi dokei= e)pifhmi/sai to\ a)gaqo\n lusitelou=n: to\ ga\r th=s fora=s lu/on to\ te/los lusitelou=n kale/sai herein, it seems to me, one happily terms the good lusitelou=n,—for that which sets free the end of motion one calls lusitelou=n, Rep. v. 479 b toi=s e)n tai=s e(stia/sesin e)pamfoteri/zousin e)/oike: kai\ ga\r tau=ta e)pamfoteri/zein they are like the riddles at feasts; for these also have a double sense, Lys. XXIX. 5 h(gou=mai de\ *filokra/- tei du/o ei)=nai a)pologi/as: prosh/kein ga\r kte(. This is regarded as assimilation in GMT. 92, 2, N. 3; H. 947.

tou\s duname/nous pra/ttein: those who can act, and not merely consider and discuss; i.e. “those in authority.” Cf. Thuc. viii. 72 pentakisxi/lioi/ te o(/ti ei)=en kai\ ou) tetrako/sioi mo/non oi( pra/ssontes that those administering the government were, etc., Isocr. IV. 188 tou\s me
 pra/ttein duname/nous peira=sqai (xrh\) dialla/ttein (ta\s po/leis), V. 13 dei= poih/sasqai/ tina prosta/thn tw=n kai\ le/gein kai\ pra/ttein duname/nwn kai\ do/can mega/lhn e)xo/ntwn, Dem. de Cor. 45 ai( de\ po/leis e)no/soun tw=n me
 e)n tw=| politeu/esqai kai\ pra/ttein dwrodokou=ntwn, tw=n d' i)diwtw=n kai\ pollw=n ta\ me
 ou) proorwme/nwn kte(. but the cities were diseased, since, on the one hand, those engaged in public life and service were venal; while, on the other hand, those in private life and the masses, failed to foresee, etc.
w(/n per: i.e. tw=n duname/nwn pra/ttein.

w(s e)/pos ei)pei=n: is used when the speaker, in order to express something very concisely, makes use of a term which taken strictly is too strong, as here ou)de\n ai)sqa/nontai, hence equiv. to nearly, almost. Very freq. in Plato. See G. 268; H. 956.

ou)de\n ai)sqa/nontai: for the thought, cf. Crito 48 c tw=n r(a|di/ws a)poktinnu/ntwn kai\ a)nabiwskome/nwn g' a)/n, ei) oi(=oi/ t) h)=san, ou)deni\ cu\n nw=|, tou/twn tw=n pollw=n these selfish considerations are characteristic of those who recklessly kill and would bring to life again if they could, these unreasoning common people.
ou(=toi: i.e. oi( pra/ttein duna/menoi.—
diagge/llwsi: proclaim, issue as an order.
u(mnou=sin: have in one's mouth, take up in chorus, cf. 343 b.
to/: const. with both du/nasqai and ei)=nai.—We expect shows great folly, etc.
katafanh= ei)=nai: getting caught.
kai\ (even)

tou= e)pixeirh/matos: emphatically repeats with anacoluthon the thought already contained in a)podidra/skonta,—as this denotes (since the failure is declared at the outset), only the attempt to escape. Cf. Menex. 244 e e)k tau/ths th=s po/lews, h(\n proqu/mws a)pw/llu which he eagerly sought to ruin.
pare/xesqai: sc. to\ e)pixei/rhma.

a(/pasan: strengthens e)nanti/an, i.e. directly the opposite way. Cf. Thuc. vi. 21 e)s a)llotri/an pa=san a)parth/santes removing to a land completely foreign, vi. 37. 3 e)n pa/sh| polemi/a| (entirely hostile) *sikeli/a|.—The gen. tou/twn does not stand for th=s tou/twn, but depends upon e)gw\ e)lh/luqa th\n e)nanti/an o(do/n, in the sense of “in contrast with them,” i.e. “I, in contrast with these, have taken directly the opposite course.” With pa=s, a(/pas thus used, the art. is lacking.
a)/llas: sc. eu)labei/as other precautions. Protagoras reflects with satisfaction that in other respects also his methods are of such a sort that he has no occasion for apprehension.

su
 qew=| ei)pei=n: deprecates any ill consequences of a boastful expression, to say it with the favor of the gods; like our ‘thank God’ with reference to the past, cf. Theaet. 151 b kai\, cu
 qew=| ei)pei=n, pa/nu i(kanw=s topa/zw (I can judge pretty accurately); and ‘by God's help,’ with reference to the future, cf. Eur. Med. 625 i)/sws ga, cu
 qew=| d' ei)rh/setai, | gamei=s toiou=ton w(/ste s' a)rnei=sqai ga/mon for perhaps—with leave of heaven be it said—you will contract such a marriage as you will be fain to disown.

w(/ste . . . pa/sxein: “there is nothing to be feared from the multitude because ou)de\n ai)sqanontai, but as oi( duna/menoi pra/ttein cannot be eluded, it is safer not to attempt this, therefore I avoid the danger.” Contrast
the attitude of Socrates, Crito 48 a ou)k a)/ra pa/nu h(mi=n ou(/tw frontiste/on, ti/ e)rou=sin oi( polloi\ h(ma=s, a)ll' o(/ ti o( e)pai+/wn peri\ tw=n dikai/wn kai\ a)di/kwn, o( ei(=s, kai\ au)th\ h( a)lh/qeia. ou) to\ zh=n peri\ plei/stou poihte/on, a)lla\ to\ eu)= zh=n.

e)n th=| te/xnh: e)/n tini ei)=nai, be engaged in anything. Cf. Meno 91 e oi)=mai ga\r au)to\n (Protagoras) a)poqanei=n e)ggu\s kai\ e(bdomh/konta e)/th gegono/ta, tessara/konta de\ e)n th=| te/xnh| o)/nta, Rep. vii. 531 b tau)to\n ga\r poiou=si toi=s e)n th=| a)stronomi/a|, Soph. O. T. 562 to/t' ou)=n o( ma/ntis ou(=tos h)=n e)n th=| te/xnh|;—

ta\ cu/mpanta: the years of his entire life, contrasted with those spent in studies. Cf. Hdt. v. 120 peso/ntwn de\ tw=n pa/ntwn pollw=n ma/lista *milh/sioi e)plh/ghsan, but while many fell from all the forces engaged, the Milesians suffered most severely. See Introd. p. 2.

ou)deno\s kte(.: in a confirmation of what has preceded, the asyndeton is common. See G. 153, N. 4; H. 1003 a for inverted assimilation. Similar pleonasm in Dem. XX. 3 ou) ga\r e)/stin e)f' o(/tou tou=to ou) pepo/nqate tw=n pa/ntwn.

w(/ste: i.e. “the former great sophists failed in attempting to cover this their real employment; I choose the safer course of avowing it as my own, and therefore strongly prefer to answer your question, not in private, but in the presence of the other sophists and their friends.” The elaborate prelude is followed by a short strain; and Socrates failed to catch the sequence (u(pw/pteusa ga\r kte(.).
a(pa/ntwn: const. with tw=n e)/ndon o)/ntwn.
kai\ e)gw\ kte(.: cf. 335 a, Euthyd. 302 a ka)gw\—h)/|dh ga\r o(/ti kte(.
e)ndei/casqai kai\ kallwpi/sasqai: i.e. e)ndeica/menon kallwpi/sasqai, see on 333 d.
ou) . . . e)kale/samen: see on 310 a.
bou/lesqe . . . kataskeua/swmen: for the ‘deliberative’ subjv. see G. 256; H. 866, 3.
sune/drion: a word of much dignity.
kaqizo/menoi diale/ghsqe: i.e. kaqi/zhsqe kai\ diale/ghsqe. Cf. Phaedr. 228 e a)lla\ pou= dh\ bou/lei kaqizo/menoi a)nagnw=men;

kai\ au)toi/: the plan so pleased all, that they did not, as Callias would naturally have preferred, wait for the servants to arrange matters, but proceeded to do this themselves. When Callias sees that this is in progress, he goes, as becomes the host, into the adjacent room, to assist Prodicus to come and join the party.

h(ke/thn . . . a)nasth/santes: cf. Euthyd. 273 a ei)selqo/ntes de\ periepatei/thn, d e)gelasa/thn ou)=n a)/mfw, ble/yantes ei)s a)llh/lous. So often in Plato. Also Ar. Plut. 429 ou) ga\r deino/tata dedra/katon zhtou=ntes kte(.

a)
 le/gois: for the potential opt. used in a mild command, see G. 226, 2, N. 1; H. 872 d. Here there is a polite invitation. Cf. Soph. Phil. 674 xwroi=s a)
 ei)/sw, El. 637 klu/ois a)
 h)/dh, *foi=be prostath/rie.
4 f. Socrates does not mention again the family of Hippocrates, and the specific expectation of the latter in resorting to Protagoras (e)llo/gimos gene/sqai e)n th=| po/lei).
w)= neani/ske: the formal address prepares the mind for an important statement.

e)/stai: an apod. having for its prots. e)a
 . . . sunh=|s, h(=| a)
 . . . sugge/nh|, (e)a
 th=| u(sterai/a| sugge/nh|,) (e)a
 e(ka/sths h(me/ras sugge/nh|). The subjs. of e)/stai are a)pie/nai, the same verb implied in tau)ta\ tau=ta, and e)pidido/nai.
gegono/ti: contains the leading idea.
me/n: we expect de/ with a request for a specific reply; but the form changes 1. 22 ff.

ka)
 su/ . . . a)
 ge/noio: kai/ and w(/sper before ei) freq. draw to themselves the a)/n of the apod., which is usually repeated after the verb or some other important word of the apod. The first a)/n shows the conditional character of the coming sentence; the last, esp. when several words have intervened, is felt to be needful as a resumption as well as to give emphasis. Cf. Menex. 236 d w(/ste ka)
 o)li/gou, ei)/ me keleu/ois o)rxh/sasqai, xarisai/mhn a)/n so that, if you should bid me dance, I would almost gratify you, Gorg. 447 d, Apol. 31 a. See G. 212, 3; H. 864.

mh\ ou(/tws: do not answer so! Cf. 331 c mh/ moi, h)=n d' e)gw/, Meno 74 d a)lla\ mh/ moi ou(/tws, Ar. Vesp. 1179 mh\ moi/ ge mu/qous, Dem. IV. 19 mh/ moi muri/ous mhde\ dismuri/ous ce/nous. Supply poi/ei, le/ge.
au)ti/ka: to begin with, for example. Cf. 359 e, Rep. i. 340 d e)pei\ au)ti/ka i)atro\n kalei=s su\ to\n e)camarta/nonta (mak- ing mistakes) peri\ tou\s ka/mnontas; Lach. 195 b.

Nothing is known of a painter Zeuxippus. Yet our passage shows that he had attracted attention. But since Zeuxis also was from Heraclea (probably the one in lower Italy) and Plato mentions him, Gorg. 453 c (cf. Xen. Mem i. 4. 3; Oec. 10. 1; Symp. 4. 63), there is much to favor the conjecture that he is here meant. *zeu=cis was originally only a pet form for *zeu/cippos, as Herodianus (Etym. M. 85, 50) cites *)/amfis for *)amfia/raos from Aeschylus, and *)=ifis for *)ifige/neia (Lycophr. 329). See Fick d. Griech. Personennamen, pp. xxviii. and 32.
ei)/poi a)/n: an apod. following the three prots. ei) e)piqumh/seie, (ei)) a)kou/seien, ei) e)pane/roito.
Orthagoras was, according to Aristoxenus, Epaminondas's teacher upon the flute. Thebes was famous for its flute-players.

ei)s ti/, kai\ peri\ tou=: with peculiar, almost comical emphasis, the proper subject of the question is placed at its close. The opening words, repeated with humorous earnestness from Protagoras himself, appear thus, in spite of their fair sound, really empty of meaning.
xai/rw a)pokrino/menos: I enjoy answering. For the pred. partic. see GMT. 112, 1; H. 983.
ta\s te/xnas kte(.: the branches pursued in the boys' schools, grammatikh/, logistikh/, kiqaristikh/,—thus about the same thought as e)k didaska/lwn a)pallage/ntas (cf. 326 c).
a)/kontas, a)/gontes: note the paronomasia.

logismou\s kte(.: here Protagoras refers unfavorably to those who teach these specialties as not being sophists in the best sense (lwbw=ntai tou\s ne/ous above); while, according to 316 d, such specialists have ever been true sophists; but the different purpose of the two arguments is obvious. The circle of the studies belonging to a complete education was enlarged just at this time; to grammatikh/ were added arithmetic, geometry, astronomy, and music; but as Callicles in Gorg. 485 a advises the pursuit of philosophy only o(/son paidei/as xa/rin, so the sophists warned against all that diverted from practical life, all mere theory. So Isocr. XV. 268 diatri=yai me
 ou)=n peri\ ta\s paidei/as tau/tas xro/non tina\ sumbouleu/saim' a)
 toi=s newte/rois, mh\ me/ntoi periidei=n th
 fu/sin th
 e(autw=n kataskeleteuqei=san (not however to suffer their constitution to be impaired) e)pi\ tou/tois. dei=n de\ (h(gou=mai) tou\s prou)/rgou ti poiei=n boulome/nous (those wishing to make some real progress) kai\ tw=n lo/gwn tou\s matai/ous kai\ tw=n pra/cewn ta\s mhde
 pro\s to
 bi/on ferou/sas a)nairei=n e)c a(pasw=n tw=n diatribw=n (to put away from their whole life vain words, and deeds which bring no profit).
*(ippi/an: cf. 315 c.

The sophists professed to teach a)reth/ (cf. para\ tou/tous tou\s u(pisxnoume/nous a)reth=s didaska/lous ei)=nai Meno 91 b), but this virtue was only an external prudence in private and public affairs, cf. tau/ths th=s a)reth=s, h(=| oi( a)/nqrwpoi ta/s te oi)ki/as kai\ ta\s po/leis kalw=s dioikou=si kai\ tou\s gone/as tou\s au(tw=n qerapeu/ousi, kai\ poli/tas kai\ ce/nous u(pode/casqai/ te kai\ a)pope/myai e)pi/stantai Meno 91 a.

a)gaqou\s poli/tas: not to be taken as pred. of a)/ndras, but the three words together form the pred. of an obj. to be supplied (au)tou/s, “those who come to you”). Expansions with a)nh/r seldom have an adj. added. Cf. Thuc. i. 74 a)/ndra strathgo\n cunetw/taton (most sagacious), Ar. Eq. 1304 a)/ndra moxqhro\n (worthless) poli/thn, Aeschin. III. 197 a)ndri\ sunhgo/rw| dikai/w| kai\ sw/froni.
ga/r, ga/r: the former introduces the reason for the expression of the doubt ei)/ per ke/kthsai, the latter for the existence of the doubt.

o(/pws a)pistw=: it is quite in Socrates's style for him to say that he does not know what he ought to believe. He had thought that virtue could not be imparted by instruction, but now he does not venture to doubt the authority of Protagoras, who holds that it can; cf. 320 b. a)/n, which the Mss. have after o(/pws, cannot stand with the subjv. of deliberation, cf. Phaedo 107 a ou)d' au)to\s e)/xw e)/ti o(/ph| a)pistw=.

ou), mhde/: usually h(gou=mai (cf. 328 e), le/gw and similar verbs take with the inf. the objective neg. ou), more rarely mh/, which places the negation in the thought of the subject. Both are used together also, Soph. Phil. 1058 e)gw/ q' , o(\s oi)=mai sou= ka/kion ou)de
 a)
 | tou/twn kratu/nein, mhd' e)piqu/nein xeri/ and I (am present), who think that I could be as good a master of this bow, and guide it as well as you.
Cf. Rep. iii. 407 c ou)kou=n fw=men kai\ *)asklhpio
 ou)k e)pixeirei=n, a)lla\ mh\ oi)/esqai dei=n, Phaedo 101 b, Isocr. XV. 60.

di/kaios: includes both the right and the duty; cf. 351 e.—We have here the pers. const., where the less freq. impers. const. might have been used, di/kaio/n e)sti with the acc. and inf.; the latter corresponds to the Eng. idiom. See H. 944 a.

e)gw\ . . . ei)=nai: shows why the Athenians can be cited in proof; the clause giving the reason with ga/r comes first, as often in Greek. See on 347 a, and compare a freq. use of a)lla\ ga/r. See H. 1050, 4.—Hippias 337 d calls Athens th=s *(ella/dos au)to\ to\ prutanei=on th=s sofi/as. And in fact it was only the recognition of her real superiority, with which recognition Socrates, ironically enough, expresses his agreement, if the Greeks yielded to Athens the pre-eminence in all culture, art, and science. Cf. Hdt. i. 60. e)n *)aqhnai/oisi toi=si prw/toisi legome/noisi ei)=nai *(ellh/nwn sofi/hn, Thuc. ii. 41 le/gw (says Pericles) th\n pa=san po/lin th=s *(ella/dos pai/deusin ei)=nai.
pra=cai peri/: take action with re- gard to is used thus by Xen., cf. Hell. vi. 3. 3 e)/pratte peri\ ei)rh/nhs, vi. 4. 25, vii. 4. 2, An. vii. 2. 12.
metapempome/nous: mid., sc. as subj. tou\s *)aqhnai/ous, as shown by h(gou=ntai and au)toi=s following.
tw=n oi)kodomhma/twn: we should have expected oi)kodomh/sews, cf. Gorg. 455 b.
kai\ ta)=lla pa/nta ou(/tws: sc. poiou=ntas. See on 312 d.

At that time the Prytanes had the conduct of the general assemblies, exercising their function through the e)pista/ths of the day. It was his duty, in case any speaker behaved unbecomingly, to have the police if necessary remove him (e(/lkein) from the bema, and put him out of the assembly, (ai)/rein, e)cai/rein), cf. Poll. viii. 131. These policemen, slaves of the state, were called from their weapons toco/tai, and from the nationality of the most of them *sku/qai. Boeckh, Staatsh. i. 291 f. Cf. Ar. Eq. 665 ka)=|q' ei(=lkon au)to\n oi( pruta/neis xoi( toco/tai the Prytanes and the police began to drag him out, Eccl. 258 e)kei=no mo/non a)/ske-
pton, h)/n s' oi( toco/tai e(/lkwsin, o(/ti dra/seis. h(mei=s de/ g), h)\n ai)/rws), e)a=n keleu/somen that alone is unconsidered, if the police try to drag you away, what you will do. But we, if they take you up, will bid them let you alone. Ach. 54 such a scene is described. The mid. (e)cai/rwntai) occurs only here.

Const. tau=ta, peri\ w(=n oi)/ontai e)n te/xnh| ei)=nai, ou(/tw diapra/ttontai. Things before termed o(/sa maqhta\ kai\ didakta/ are now designated as those peri\ w(=n e)n te/xnh| e)sti/n, see on 310 d.—Socrates reasons thus: “when the Athenians believe a matter to turn upon professional knowledge, they allow only professional men to speak upon it; but on matters connected with the civil administration they listen to all without distinction; this a)reth/ therefore, which relates to civil administration, in the view of Athenians is not a matter of art, and so cannot be learned.” Cf. 322
d e.

Socrates says, with reference to 318 e, dioi/khsis tw=n th=s po/lews. This form is entirely correct, since dioi/khsis th=s po/lews and such general expressions, like dioi/khsis, freq. stand without the art. Cf. Polit. 296 e to\n o(/ron o)rqh=s po/lews dioikh/sews the principle of the correct management of the state, Rep. X. 606 e pro\s dioi/khsin tw=n a)nqrwpi/nwn pragma/twn.
o(moi/ws, o(moi/ws: note the energy of the anaphora with me/n, de/.—
xalkeu/s, skutoto/mos: cf. 324 c.
tou/tois, maqw/n, e)pixeirei=: such transitions to the sing. are not infreq. with Plato. Cf. 324 a, 334 c. Here the reversion is natural
tou=to: i.e. o(/ti e)pixeirei=.

e)/peita: after a partic., marks the contrast between it and the following pred. Cf. 358 b, Apol. 20 c ou) ga\r dh/pou sou= ge ou)de\n tw=n a)/llwn peritto/teron pragmat euome/nou e)/peita tosau/th fh/mh te kai\ lo/gos ge/gonen for it cannot be that while you (as you say) have not been exceeding the limits observed by other men, in spite of this, so great talk and commotion has arisen about you, Soph. Ant. 496 misw= xw(/tan e)n kakoi=si/ tis | a(lou/s, e)/peita tou=to kallu/nein qe/lh| I hate it, when one, taken in evil deeds, then desires to gloss these over.

mh\ o(/ti, a)lla/: advances to a stronger statement; “not to speak of the city, even, etc.” Cf. Apol. 40 d oi)=mai a)
 mh\ o(/ti i)diw/thn tina/, a)lla\ to
 me/gan basile/a a)
 eu(rei=n kte(. I think that,
not to say a private individual, even the great king would find, etc. The expression is elliptical, see H. 1035.

In many places Socrates in Plato laments that the great men of Athens have not trained their sons to wisdom and virtue; in Meno 93 d ff. besides Pericles, he adduces Themistocles, Aristides, and Thucydides the son of Melesias. Both sons of Pericles died young of the plague; that Xanthippus was a worthless fellow is said by Plutarch, Pericles 36. Cf. 328 c.
ei)/xeto: with gen., be in close connection with, pertain to a thing. didaska/lwn cf. 324 d, Meno 94 b o(/sa te/xnhs e)/xetai, Theaet. 145 a kai\ o(/sa paidei/as e)/xetai.

ne/montai: many temples had herds of cattle belonging to them, which roamed at will over the sacred fields. Cf. Plutarch Lucull. c. 24 bo/es i(erai\ ne/montai *persi/as *)arte/midos: xrw=ntai de\ tai=s bousi\ pro\s qusi/an mo/non, a)/llws de\ pla/zontai kata\ th
 xw/ran a)/fetoi, Arrian An. vii. 20. 4 ne/mesqai/ te th
 nh=son ai)ci/ te a)gri/ais kai\ e)la/fois kai\ tau/tas a)nei=sqai (let range) a)fe/tous th=| *)arte/midi, Periplus Ponti Eux. 22 kai\ tw=n i(erei/wn ta\ me
 kataqu/ein, ta\ de\ a)fie/nai tw=| *)axillei=. Hence a)/feton ne/mesqai means range at will without oversight. Cf. Plato Rep. vi. 498 c to/te h)/dh a)fe/tous ne/mesqai kai\ mhde
 a)/llo pra/ttein.

Clinias, the father of Alcibiades and Clinias, fell at Coronea 447 B.C. The guardianship of these sons was assumed by Ariphron and Pericles, whose mother Agariste was first cousin to Megacles, the father of Clinias's widow, Dinomache (cf. Plut. Alc. 1). The sons probably lived, however, with their mother Dinomache in their father's house. Pericles directed the separation on Alcibiades's coming of age, in 433 B.C.
dh/: indicates (with a goodnatured thrust at Alcibiades who was present) that the apprehension of Pericles was quite natural and reasonable.
kataqe/menos: deposit, place in one's keeping. Cf. 314 a, Legg. xi. 913 c a(\ mh\ kate/qou, mh\ a)ne/lh|, Thuc. i. 115. 3 *)aqhnai=oi o(mh/rous e)/labon kai\ kate/qento e)s *ah=mnon.—
e)n *)ari/fronos: for the ellipsis, see on 326 c.

kai/: paratactic. “Although Pericles had separated Clinias from Alcibiades, yet he soon gave him back to him.” kai/ is often thus used. Cf. Soph. O. T. 413 su\ kai\ de/dorkas, kou) ble/peis i(/n' ei)= kakou= (i.e. although you have sight, you see not in what evil you are involved).
gegone/nai: of time, elapse. Cf. Rep. X. 616 b e)peidh\ de\ toi=s e)n tw=| leimw=ni (meadow) e(ka/stois e(pta\ h(me/rai ge/nointo, Phaedo 108 c e(/ws a)\n dh/ tines xro/noi ge/nwntai.—
a)pe/dwke tou/tw|: sc. Pericles to Alcibiades. For the prominent thought is the failure (a)pospa/sas a)po\ tou/tou) of Pericles to carry out the education of Clinias.
xrh/saito: opt. of indir. disc. derived from the deliberative subjv. Cf. 321 c. See G. 244; H. 932, 2.

ka/mptomai: am led to waver. Cf. Lach. 192 e ei)/ tis i)atro\s w)\n mh\ ka/mptoito a)lla\ karteroi=, Rep. vi. 494 e e)a\n d' ou)=n ei(=s ai)sqa/nhtai/ te/ ph| kai\ ka/mpthtai kai\ e(/lkhtai pro\s filosofi/an but suppose, further, one has some perception of the truth, and is led to waver and is drawn towards philosophy.
Socrates distinguishes between three sources of knowledge: “Protagoras has had much experience, has learned much from others, and has thought out much for himself.”
didakto\n . . . a)reth/: this is the proposition to be proved, and we naturally expect at the outset a definition of a)reth/.—
mh\ fqonh/sh|s: politely urges the request. Cf. Gorg. 489 a mh\ fqo/nei moi a)pokri/nasqai tou=to.

mu=qon h)\lo/gw|: Protagoras gives both story and argument. He first, after the manner of the sophists, tells a story, drawn in part from the popular myths concerning Prometheus and aboriginal man, and embellished by his free invention; a method, as he is aware, much more acceptable to the people than dry disquisition; and from this myth he draws various conciusions. Then, after 324 d (ou)ke/ti mu=qon, a)lla\ lo/gon), he develops an argument which he contrasts as real (lo/gos) with the fictitious (mu=qos). With similar contrast, Socrates says in Phaedo 61 b e)nnoh/sas o(/ti to
 poihth
 de/oi poiei=n mu/qous a)ll' ou) lo/gous (fictions, not
realities), Gorg. 523 a a)/koue dh\ ma/la kalou= lo/gou, o(
 su\ me
 h(gh/sei mu=qon, e)gw\ de\ lo/gon.
diecelqw/n: we should expect diecerxo/menos, but cf. Theaet. 167 d a)mfisbh/tei, lo/gw| a)ntidiecelqw/n dispute it, traversing it in an argument.

xarie/steron: an element of value, provided the argument be not impaired.
In the first part of the discourse, the myth, Plato represents Protagoras as imitating the tone of old legends, as indeed he may very likely have done in similar narratives. This appears in the whole tone of the recital, the simple construction, the selection of words and phrases peculiar to poetry (gh=s e)/ndon, a)/oplon fu/sin, smikro/thti h)/mpisxe, pthno\n fugh/n, a)istwqei/h, a)llhlofqoriw=n, sxo/menos, po/lewn ko/smoi te kai\ desmoi/, fili/as sunagwgoi/, no/son po/lews kte(.), and the freq. omission of the art. (esp. with a)/nqrwpos). The very beginning was common in legends. Cf. Stasinus Cypr. Frag. 1 h)=n o(/te muri/a fu=la, Critias in Sext. Empir. ix. 54 h)=n xro/nos, o(/te h)=n, Theocr. vii. 1 h)=s xro/nos, a(ni/k' e)gw/n.

e)/ndon: with the gen. survives in prose only in the old-fashioned Antiphon v. 45 e)/ndon w)\n au(tou= kai\ mh\ pefobhme/nos.—Parmenides held that fire and earth were the original elements of the sensible world; Empedocles first inserted between these as elements, air and water, which combine with fire and earth. That men originally sprang from the earth was the ancient belief of many peoples, and upon this belief rest the Greek autochthonic myths (Preller's Gr. Mythol. i.^{3} 63). To this Plato attaches also the myth in Polit. 272
a e.

tw=n: the art. before rel. clauses is freq. in Plato. Cf. Rep. vi. 510 a ta\ e)n toi=s u(/dasi fanta/smata kai\ e)n toi=s o(/sa pukna/ te kai\ lei=a kai\ fana\ cune/sthke the reflections in water, and in whatever bodies are solid, smooth, and polished, Phaedo 75 b o)re/getai tou= o(\ e)/stin i)/son aspires to that which is equal (i.e. abstract equality).

paraitei=tai: beg as a favor, cf. Apol. 27 a o(/per kat' a)rxa\s u(ma=s parh|thsa/mhn, Critias 106 c tau)to\n kai\ nu=n e)gw\ tou=to paraitou=mai. Instead of the acc. of the thing, here the inf. nei=mai is used. Otherwise below, 358 a.

tw=|de: for tou/tw| is another touch of poetic and archaic expression, in addition to those mentioned above (see on 1. 1). Still others are the dat. qrici/ with a)mfiennu/s, instead of the acc. (cf. Symp. 219 b), au)toi=s e)mhxana=to after toi=s d), and au)ta\ e)/sw|ze after a(\ de/. See G. 164; H. 724.
19 f. The purpose of clothing the animals with tri/xes and sterea\ de/rmata is given in changing construction, first i(kanoi=s and dunatoi=s, then kai\ o(/pws u(pa/rxoi.
e)/sti d' oi(=s: cf. 346 e e)/stin ou(/s. In the nom., however, according to prevalent Attic use, 342 e ei)si\n oi(/. See G. 152, N. 2; H. 998.
swthri/an: safety, continuance.
ou) pa/nu ti: ‘litotes,’ not very wise, i.e. very unwise. So often ou) pa/nu ti, ou) ma/la, ou) sfo/dra, like ou)x h(/kista etc.

e)/rxetai: freq. with the dat. of interest, in the poets; cf. Aesch. Prom. 358 a)ll' h)=lqen au)tw=| *zhno\s a)/grupnon be/los (sleepless bolt), also in Plato Rep. x. 596 e kalw=s kai\ ei)s de/on e)/rxei tw=| lo/gw|, Xen. Symp. 2. 1 e)/rxetai au)toi=s e)pi\ kw=mon (revel) *surako/sio/s tis a)/nqrwpos.

e)mmelw=s e)/xonta: with the gen., like the common w(s, pw=s, kalw=s e)/xein. Somewhat different is Gorg. 501 c a)ske/ptws e)/xwn (equiv. to a)melw=n) tou= a)mei/nonos without consideration of the better, Phaedo 108 a e)piqumhtikw=s (desirous) tou= sw/matos e)/xousa. On e)mmelw=s cf. 339 c. For the intrans. use of e)/xein and some other verbs, see G. 195, N. 2; H. 810.

Cf. Lucretius v. 223: tum porro puer nudus humi jacet, infans, indigus omni vitali auxilio, Aristotle peri\ zw/|wn mori/wn iv. 10, p. 687 a 23 a)ll' oi( le/gontes w(s sune/sthken ou) kalw=s (is not well put together) o( a)/nqrwpos a)lla\ xei/rista tw=n zw/|wn (a)nupo/dhto/n te ga au)to
 ei)=nai/ fasi kai\ gumno
 kai\ ou)k e)/xonta o(/plon pro\s th
 a)lkh/n) ou)k o)rqw=s le/gousin,— words which show that Protagoras uttered here a thought often expressed, and also that Aristotle was acquainted with Plato's Protagoras. See on 352 c.

sxo/menos: this aor. is often used in an intrans. or passive sense, involved in, possessed by. Cf.
