Hom. l 279 w(=| a)/xei+ sxome/nh involved in her woes, Plato Soph. 250 d pa/sh| sunesxo/meqa a)pori/a|, Phaedr. 244 e tw=| o)rqw=s mane/nti te (to the one truly mad), kai\ katasxome/nw| (th=| mani/a|), Isocr. XIX. 11 fqo/h| sxo/menon.

Somewhat differently Polit. 274 c o(/qen dh\ ta\ pa/lai lexqe/nta para\ qew=n dw=ra (gifts from the gods) h(mi=n dedw/rhtai pu=r me\n para\ *promhqe/ws, te/xnai de\ par' *(hfai/stou kai\ th=s sunte/xnou.

According also to the sacred legend of the Greeks, fire was the source and teacher of every art. Cf. Aesch. Prom. 109 ff. narqhkoplh/rwton de\ qhrw=mai puro\s | phgh\n klopai/an (and I discover the secret source of fire filling the hollow of the reed), h(\ dida/skalos te/xnhs | pa/shs brotoi=s pe/fhne kai\ me/gas po/ros. Protagoras places the e)/ntexnos sofi/a, which provides for the necessities of the physical life, in contrast with the politikh/, which is the ground of the social life and of all culture.
e)/sxe, ei)=xen: obtained, had; for the inceptive use of the aor., see G. 200, N. 5 b; H. 841.
Protagoras represents Olympus as resembling a city of the Greek heroic age; the ruler occupies the citadel, the people the lower city.
ou)ke/ti: he could no longer go forward, and enter the citadel itself.
fulakai/: prob. *bi/a and *kra/tos are meant, whom Hesiod Theog. 385 ff. calls the inseparable attendants of Zeus, and whom Aeschylus (Prometheus ad init.) introduces as his evercompliant beadles.

Hephaestus and Athena were closely associated in the Attic belief; see the legend of Erichthonius, the feasts *xalkei=a and *)apatou/ria, and the *)aqhnai/a *(hfaisti/a recently established by inscriptions. Preller's Gr. Mythol. i. 146 f.
kloph=s di/kh: technical term from the Attic criminal process; a prosecution for theft pursued Prometheus.
qei/as . . . moi/ras: received a share in divinity.
prw=ton, e)/peita: indicate, not temporal sequence, but the different points of view, from which the imparting of that which belonged to the gods worked advantageously to men.
mo/non: neut. adj., identifies o( a)/nqrwpos as one of ta\ zw=|a.—
e)no/mise: inceptive aor., took up the belief in the gods.
e)/peita: correlative with me/n.—

dihrqrw/sato: the technical term for articulation; articulated speech and thus formed words. Language therefore, acc. to Protagoras, did not arise at the beginning with man, but he immediately fashioned it, from the sounds derived from nature, through the skill bestowed upon him by Prometheus (cf. Symp. 191 a ta\ sth/qh dih/rqrou sc. o( *)apo/llwn).
pantaxh=|: in every respect.
a)sqene/steroi: pred. nom. See G. 136, N. 3; H. 958, 940.

qhri/wn: subjective gen. Cf. Xen. An. ii. 5. 7 to
 ga qew=n po/lemon ou)k oi)=da a)po\ poi/ou a)
 ta/xous feu/gwn tis a)pofu/goi, Thuc. i. 24. 4 oi( *)epida/mnioi pe/mpousin deo/menoi to
 tw=n barba/rwn po/lemon katalu=sai (to put an end to the war waged by the barbarians).

ai)dw=, di/khn: often represented as the protecting spirits and the underlying conditions of all social and civilized life, “reverence for divine and human law.” Cf. Tyrt. xii. 39 f. (= Theogn. 937 f.) ghra/skwn a)stoi=si metapre/pei (growing old, he is distinguished among the citizens), ou)de/ tis au)to\n | bla/ptein (deprive him of) ou)/t' ai)dou=s ou)/te di/khs e)qe/lei, Theogn. 291 f. ai)dw\s me\n ga\r o)/lwlen, a)naidei/h de\ kai\ u(/bris (shamelessness and insolence) | nikh/sasa di/khn gh=n kata\ pa=san e)/xei, Hes. *)/erga 192 di/kh d' e)n xersi\ kai\ ai)dw\s ou)k e)/stai, and similarly ib. 200 ai)dw\s kai\ ne/mesis.

desmoi/: cf. Tim. 31 c desmo\n ga\r e)n me/sw| dei= tina a)mfoi=n cunagwgo\n gi/gnesqai for there must be some bond between them uniting them both. The words are perhaps borrowed from some poet. The paronomasia ko/smoi, desmoi/ is noticeable.

ou)=n: in a dependent question, cf. Symp. 219 d w(/ste ou)/q' o(/pws ou)=n o)rgizoi/mhn ei)/xon so neither therefore could I be angry with him. So a)/ra Phaedr. 228 d dei/cas ge prw=ton ti/ a)/ra e)n th=| a)ristera=| e)/xeis.—For a similar sudden transition to dir. disc., cf. 320 d, 325 d, 338 b.
kai\ oi( a)/lloi dhmiourgoi/: is loosely appended; sc. polloi=s i(kanoi\ i)diw/tais. We should have expected kai\ ei(=s e(/kastos tw=n a)/llwn dhmiourgw=n w(sau/tws. Cf. 328 c.

This is the culmination of the myth, which was to show that virtue can be taught (see on 320 c); while it really only asserts that all men possess virtue, and this with an important saving qualification (line 26). If virtue is purely a gift, and is so vitally important, there is no reason why Zeus should not have bestowed it upon all, instead of leaving exceptions who were to be destroyed as pests. If virtue is not a gift, the myth proves (asserts) nothing whatever. The importance to Protagoras, however, of the exception, is that it leaves room for the argument upon responsibility and punishment (323 c f.).

no/son: used only poetically of persons. Cf. Aesch. Prom. 1068 f. tou\s prodo/tas ga\r misei=n e)/maqon, | kou)k e)/sti no/sos, | th=sd' h(/ntin) a)pe/ptusa (de- test) ma=llon. More frequent thus is pestis.
*)aqhnai=oi: pl. proper names of peoples generally take the art., but may omit it. This omission here is easier because of the oi(/ te a)/lloi, cf. 324 c.
a)reth=s tektonikh=s: “a matter involving the builder's art”; cf. 319 b.
metei=nai sumboulh=s: have a right to give counsel.
politikt=s a)reth=s: objective gen. after sumboulh/n, “a matter involving political science.”
h(/n: sc. a)reth/n, subj. of i)e/nai.

i)e/nai dia/: take one's way through a thing, “follow the path of,” “act in the sphere of”; used by Plato in many connections. Others use similarly xwrei=n, poreu/esqai, e)/rxesqai dia/. Cf. Xen. An. iii. 2. 8 ei) me\n ou)=n bouleuo/meqa pa/lin au)toi=s dia\ fili/as i)e/nai, . . . kai\ to\ loipo\n dia\ panto\s pole/mou au)toi=s i)e/nai.—

swfrosu/nhs: must here
have the sense of ai)dw/s.—

ei)ko/tws... lang=greek>a)ne/xontai: the emphasis is on both the adv. and the verb (cf. 322 e). “In view of the facts contained in the myth (ou(/tw dh/, kai\ dia\ tau=ta), the Athenians, and with good reason, listen to every man,”—i.e. they believe every man to possess virtue; a conclusion which Protagoras goes on to confirm.

h)/: sc. a)nagkai=on o)/n from prosh=kon, cf. Phaedr. 245 d tou=to de\ (i.e. the self-moving) ou)/t' a)po/llusqai ou)/te gi/gnesqai dunato/n, h)\ pa/nta te ou)rano
 pa=sa/n te ge/nesin sumpesou=san sth=nai (else the whole heaven and all created things must collapse and come to a standstill) where a)nagkai=on is supplied from dunato/n. Conversely, Rep. vi. 490 a h(
 (sc. a)lh/qeian) diw/kein au)to
 pa/ntws kai\ pa/nth| e)/dei, h)\ a)lazo/ni (an impostor) o)/nti mhdamh=| metei=nai filosofi/as a)lhqinh=s (sc. dunato
 h)=n). For h)/, otherwise, or else (alioquin), see 323 b bis, 325 a etc.
ei)=nai: exist. Cf. 327 a.

w(s: apparently might depend upon a)pata=sqai, equiv. to met' a)pa/ths pei/qesqai, cf. Crat. 413 d i)/sws ga\r a)/n se kai\ ta\ e)pi/loipa e)capath/saimi, w(s ou)k a)khkow\s le/gw, and so often. But here tw=| o)/nti shows that w(s depends rather upon the following to/de . . . tekmh/rion. Cf. 324 c.
w(/sper su\ le/geis: cf. 319 c.
e)kei=: i.e. e)n tai=s a)/llais a)retai=s.

h(gou=nto: a general truth, but impf. as referred to a previous illustration or observation. Cf. Crito 47 d diafqerou=men e)kei/no kai\ lwbhso/meqa, o(\ tw=| me\n dikai/w| be/ltion e)gi/gneto, tw=| de\ a)di/kw| a)pw/lluto.
e)ntau=qa mani/an: sc. h(gou=ntai. Thus the universality of virtue is proved by the fact that men will not tolerate the truthful confession of its lack.

dikaiosu/nhn: cf. Thuc. i. 137. 4 h(
 yeudw=s prosepoih/sato, Aeschin. II. 166 th
 fh/mhn h(
 prosepoih/sw. Everywhere else Plato uses the inf. after prospoiei=sqai.—w(s: sometimes followed by the simple adj. absolutely, while usually o)/n is added; cf. Rep. v. 449 c w(s a)/ra panti\ dh=lon, Gorg. 495 c w(s e(/teron th
 a)ndrei/an th=s e)pisth/mhs (on the ground that courage differs from knowledge) du/o tau=ta e)/leges;
ou)de/na o(/ntina: see on 317 c.

XIII. According to rhetorical principles, the part which has been proved is brought to a separate close, here and 324 c, and what remains to be proved is stated; finally 328 c the whole is brought to a regular conclusion. Protagoras was himself a teacher of rhetoric.
ou) fu/sei kte(.: but cf. e)pi\ pa/ntas nei/mw 322 c. It is now necessary to show that virtue is not an original possession of all.
a)po\ tou= au)toma/tou: equiv. to tu/xh| below.

meta\ tou=to: freq. in Plato; in the next place, when one point is finished and another is to be taken up. Cf. 355 a to\ meta\ tou=to as subst., the next point. Now follows the second division of the speech of Protagoras.
ai)sxrou\s h)\ smikrou/s: the Greeks regarded beauty and stature as qualities which were never separated.—For the acc. of the person after poiei=n ti, see G. 165; H. 725, a.
ta\ . . . tou/tois: follows tau=ta epexegetically.
a)se/beia: cf. 322 a. Since men worshipped the gods before receiving a)reth\ politikh/, Protagoras begins here to enlarge his definition of virtue, cf. 325 a, 329 c, 330 a.
dh=lon o(/ti: this expression, as well as oi)=d' o(/ti, is often added to a clause or inserted in it with the force of an adv., evidently, certainly. See H. 1049, 1 a.
du/natai: signifies; cf. Crat. 429 d a)=ra o(/ti yeudh= le/gein to\ para/pan ou)k e)/stin, a)=ra tou=to/ soi du/natai o( lo/gos; Euthyd. 286 c tou=to ga\r du/natai o( lo/gos.—

au)to/ se dida/cei: the matter itself will teach you. au)to/ is not to be referred to kola/zein. Cf. the standing formulae au)to\ dei/cei (Hipp. Ma. 288 b ei) d' e)pixeirh/sas e)/stai katage/lastos, au)to\ dei/cei), au)to\ dhlw/sei (329 b, Critias 108 c tou=to me\n ou)=n oi(=o/n e)stin, au)to/ soi ta/xa dhlw/sei), and passages like Soph. Frag. 352 taxu\ d) au)to\ dei/cei tou)=rgon, w(s e)gw/, safw=s.—
oi(/ ge a)/nqrwpoi: not necessarily all men, but all excepting the class referred to below, o(/stis mh\ w(/sper qhri/on kte(.
tou\s a)dikou=ntas, o(/ti h)di/khsen: for the change to the sing., see on 319 d.
pro\s tou/tw| e)/xwn: equiv. to tou/tw| prose/xwn.
o(/stis . . . qhri/on: antithetical with oi(/ ge a)/nqrwpoi above.

meta\ lo/gou: with reason (opposed to a)logi/stws), so that he gives to himself, and can give to others, account of what he does. Cf. Tim. 28 a to\ me\n dh\ noh/sei meta\ lo/gou perilhpto/n (to be received by the intelligence with reason), a)ei\ kata\ tau)ta\ o)/n (being always the same), to\ d' au)= do/ch| met) ai)sqh/sews a)lo/gou docasto/n (but the other, conceived by the opinion, with the help of irrational sense), gigno/menon kai\ a)pollu/menon, Phaedr. 256 a o( de\ pro\s tau=ta met' ai)dou=s kai\ lo/gou a)ntitei/nei. See on 351 e.

ou) ga\r kte(.: a thought widely current among the Greeks, from which Theognis has derived the ethical con
tent of his words 583 f. a)lla\ ta\ me\n probe/bhken (that which is past) a)mh/xano/n e)sti gene/sqai | a)rga/: ta\ d' e)copi/sw, tw=n fulakh\ mele/tw. Cf. Simon. Frag. 69 to\ ga\r gegenhme/non ou)ke/t' a)/rekton (unaccomplished) e)/sta:, Dem. III. 6 ta\ me\n dh\ to/te praxqe/nta ou)k a)/n a)/llws e)/xoi, Hor. Car. iii. 29. 45 ff.
tou= me/llontos: subst., cf. Parm. 137 a tre/monti to\ me/llon.

i(/na . . . kolasqe/nta: the theory of prevention, which meets us also in Gorg. 525 b and elsewhere in Plato, prevailed more and more in the time of the sophists as the ideas of the state and of law lost power and sacredness. In former times the ideas of retribution and of the expiation of the violation of right and law, had been the foundation of criminal law; cf. Aesch. Cho. 313 dra/santi paqei=n, | trige/rwn mu=qos ta/de fwnei= the doer must suffer, thus says a most ancient adage.

timwrou=ntai kte(.: cf. Arist. Rhet. i. 10. 17 diafe/rei de\ timwri/a kai\ ko/lasis: h( me
 ga ko/lasis tou= pa/sxontos e(/neka/ e)stin, h( de\ timwri/a tou= poiou=ntos, i(/na a)poplhrwqh=| (be satisfied). The rare pres. mid. of kola/zw occurs also Ar. Vesp. 405 nu=n e)kei=no tou)cu/qumon, w(=| kolazo/mesqa, ke/ntron e)nte/tat' o)cu/ now that choleric sting, with which we punish, is sharp and ready for action; the aor., Menex. 240 d deca/menoi kai\ kolasa/menoi th
 u(perhfani/an, Xen. An. ii. 5. 13 a)
 kola/saisqe, and the fut. is freq.

a)pode/deiktai kte(.: replying to Socrates's objection 319 b f., Protagoras argues, “All men blame and punish, not for natural defects, but for avoidable faults. But punishment can have reference (Protagoras asserts) only to prevention, i.e. to the teaching of virtue; hence the Athenians and others (show that they) think virtue can be taught.” This is in the place of showing w(s didakto/n e)stin h( a)reth/ 320 c.

a)pori/a: the art. is some times omitted when a rel. follows the
noun, since the needed definiteness is given by the rel. clause. Cf. Charm. 169 a a)=r' e)n tou/tois e)sti
 e)pisth/mh, h(
 dh\ h(mei=s swfrosu/nhn fame
 ei)=nai, Rep. iii. 413 e fu/lac au(tou= w)
 a)gaqo\s kai\ mousikh=s h(=s e)ma/nqanen, Symp. 197 e w)|dh=s mete/xonta, h(
 a)/dei qe/lgwn joining in the song which he sings, charming, etc.— Here begins the third division of the speech.
e)/xetai: see on 319 e.
a)gaqoi/: sc. ei)si/.

ou)deno\s belti/ous: lit. more excellent than no one, to excel no one. Cf. 335 a, Aesch. Prom. 1016 au)qadi/a ga\r ou)deno\s mei=zon sqe/nei for self-will is utterly powerless, Dem. II. 17 ou)de/nwn ei)si\ belti/ous, XIX. 208 e)mou= ou)deno\s mei=zon fqeggome/nou h(ttw=ntai when I speak more weakly than any other, they are discomfited. More freq. are the cases in which the comparative word has a neg. force, as in the use of e)la/sswn, h(/sswn, e)ndee/steros, with a preceding ou)deno/s. Cf. 316 e ou)deno\s h(/ttwn, he is inferior to no one, Eur. Bacch. 777 *dio/nusos h(/sswn ou)deno\s qew=n e)/fu.

ou)ke/ti mu=qon: the second part of the discourse had already been for the most part disconnected from the myth; but Protagoras now calls attention to this, in order to strengthen the impression that he is giving a fundamental demonstration from the nature of the subject itself.
e)n tou/tw|: “in the answer to this question.”
The following period is a typical example of imitation of oral disc., which, in its efforts at clearness, allows itself all manner of repetitions, recapitulations, and little anacolutha.
kai\ sullh/bdhn kte(.: inserted with anacoluthon; see on 323 e.
ei)=nai: see on 311 e.
kai\ meta\ tou/tou: a dem. or pers. pron. is common in such cases, after a copulative or disjunctive conj., instead of a repeated rel.
ou(/tw: resumes meta\ tou/tou above.
to\n mh\ mete/xonta: cf. 323 a, l. 40.
dida/skein kte(.: depends on dei= above.
ou(/tw pefuko/tos: resumes the foregoing prot. in order to add another, containing a contradiction, and then the more emphatically to draw the conclusion ske/yai kte(.

qaumasi/ws gi/gnontai: we should have expected qauma/sioi/ ei)sin or qauma/sia pra/ttousin, still the reading can be sustained by expressions like that of Timothens in Plut. Mor. 127 a w(s oi( para\ *pla/twni deipnh/santes kai\ ei)sau/rion h(de/ws gi/gnontai, 686 b (Ath. X. 419 d) tou\s para\ *pla/twni deipnh/santas kai\ th=| u(sterai/a| kalw=s gi/gnesqai, Aristophon in Ath. xiii. 559 d kako\s kakw=s ge/noiq' o( gh/mas deu/teros. It is prob. the language of common life. The meaning is then, how strangely it fares with the good, what a strange course they take. More freq. pefuke/nai is thus construed with an adv.; e.g. Phaedo 60 b (to\ h(du\) w(s qaumasi/ws pe/fuke pro\s to\ luphro/n.
didaktou= . . . o)/ntos: this is continued from didakto/n of the previous line, “if it can be taught, as I have shown that people believe.”
ta\ me\n a)/lla kte(.: argument a minore ad majus.
zhmi/a: in this use commonly has the art., “the legally appointed penalty.”

te/: would be in its place, were the passage i.e. e)f' w(=n h(/ te zhmi/a e)sti\ qa/natos kai\ tw=n oi)/kwn a)natropai\ gi/gnontai. The sent., however, proceeds as though it began e)f' w(=n de\ h( zhmi/a qa/nato/s te. Such transpositions of te/ within the connected group of words are not infreq.; cf. 336 c lo/gon te dou=nai kai\ de/casqai, 338 b, l. 2, Rep. i. 348 b a(/ma au)toi/ te dikastai\ kai\ r(h/tores e)so/meqa, Lach. 195 c to\ u(gieino\n ei)pei=n oi(=o/n te kai\ nosw=des, Crito 43 b e)n tosau/th| te a)grupni/a| kai\ lu/ph| ei)=nai.
mhde\ . . . a)reth/n: added epexegetically, with anacoluthon after e)f' w(=n.

cullh/bdhn: is unexpected after w(s e)/pos ei)pei=n, but cf. Apol. 22 b w(s e)/pos ga\r ei)pei=n o)li/gou au)tw=n a(/pantes oi( paro/ntes a)\n be/ltion e)/legon.—The destruction of one's house, the extinction of one's family, stood for the greatest possible disaster.

d' a)/ra: see on 313 a, 1. 2. Cf. Crito 46 d h)\ pri
 me
 e)me\ dei=n a)poqnh/|skein kalw=s e)le/geto, nu=n de\ kata/dhlos a)/ra e)ge/neto kte(.; 50 e h)\ pro\s me
 a)/ra soi to
 pate/ra ou)k e)c i)/sou h)=n to\ di/kaion (while towards your father it was certainly not right for you), pro\s de\ th
 patri/da a)/ra kai\ tou\s no/mous e)ce/stai soi kte(.

oi)/esqai/ ge xrh/: an expression freq. in Plato in reply to a question raised by the speaker himself or a bystander. What follows is added ‘asyndetically,’ because it confirms oi)/- esqai xrh/ by a surprising fact.
On the following classical passage upon the training of the youth, see Becker Char. ii. 19 ff., Hermann Griech. Alt. iii. § 33 ff., Guhl and Koner, Life of the Greeks and Romans, §§ 50, 51.
e)peida\n qa=tton kte(.: during the first years, nurse and mother; later, pedagogue and father.
qa=tton: is rare after e)pei/ and similar particles; more freq. is ta/xista. In Plato, besides this place, qa=tton is found thus only in Alc. I. 105 a e)a\n qa=tton.
ff. So Demea admonishes his son, Terent. Ad. iii. 3. 63: Hoc facito. —Hoc fugito.—Hoc laudi est. —Hoc vitio datur.
pei/qhtai kte(.: see on 311 d, 1. 20.
kai\ plhgai=s: cf. Menand. Sent. 422 o( mh\ darei\s a)/nqrwpos ou) paideu/etai.
ei)s didaska/lwn: see on 326 c, 1. 37.
With the grammatisth/s the boys learned ta\ gra/mmata, i.e. to read and write, then with the kiqaristh/s they learned to sing, and generally to play the lyre.

tou/twn: i.e. eu)kosmi/as. So freq. the neut. pl. of dem. prons. is used for the sing., as ta/de, tau=ta, qa/tera, as is also freq. the case with pred. adjs. Cf. 327 b, 353 a dia\ tau=ta, Crito 52 a e)fie/ntwn (permit) h(mw=n duoi=n qa/tera, h)\ pei/qein h(ma=s h)\ poiei=n, tou/twn ou)de/tera poiei=, Thuc. iv. 1 a)du/nata h)=n e)n tw=| paro/nti tou\s *aokrou\s a)mu/nesqai. See H. 635.
to/te: previously; cf. c above, Gorg. 488 c oi(=o/n moi dokei=s kai\ to/te e)ndei/knusqai, w(s kte(. So often.
ba/qrwn: see on 315 c.

poihtw=n: Homer before all others. In Xen. Symp. 3. 5 Niceratus says o( path\r e)pimelou/menos o(/pws a)nh\r a)gaqo\s genoi/mhn, h)na/gkase/ me pa/nta ta\ *(omh/rou e)/ph maqei=n. Prominently after Homer come Hesiod, Theognis, Phocylides; kai\ ga\r tou/tous fasi\ me\n a)ri/stous gegenh=sqai sumbou/lous tw=| bi/w| tw=| tw=n a)nqrw/pwn Isocr. II. 43. In part the teachers dictated passages merely, which were to be committed to memory; cf. Euthyd. 276 c o(po/te a)postomati/zoi (dictated) u(mi=n o( grammatisth/s, po/teroi e)ma/nqanon tw=n pai/dwn ta\ a)postomatizo/mena;
a)nagka/zousin: cf. Arist. Pol. viii. 4 ou) ga\r pai/zousi manqa/nontes (oi( ne/oi) : meta\ lu/phs ga\r h( ma/qhsis.
die/codoi: attractive tales, descriptions In 361 d, detailed exposition, course of argument.
e)/painoi: more general than e)gkw/mia.

e(/tera toiau=ta: sc. poiou=sin, see on 312 d. For the thought, see Ar. Nub. 964 ei)=ta badi/zein (sc. e)/dei) e)n tai=sin o(doi=s eu)ta/ktws ei)s kiqaristou= | tou\s kwmh/tas gumnou\s a)qro/ous then those of the same district had to go in good order through the streets, in a body and wearing only the chiton, to the school of the harp-player.
a)/n: gives a shade of contingency in final clauses. Cf. Gorg. 481 a mhxanhte/on o(/pws a)\n diafu/gh| kai\ mh\ dw=| di/khn o( e)xqro/s.
a)/llwn: see on 316 d, 1. 24.
melopoiw=n: viz. the Aeolic and Doric lyric poets, the dithyrambic poets Cecidas, Lamprocles, Lasos, Cydias and others, besides the choral songs of the tragedians.

e)ntei/nontes: used of putting prose into metrical form, or adapting verses to musical rhythm and melody. Cf. Phaedo 60 d e)ntei/nas tou\s tou= *ai)sw/pou lo/gous kai\ to\ ei)s to\n *)apo/llw prooi/mion.

i(/na kte(.: the Greeks ascribed to music the highest influence in moral culture. Cf. Rep. iii. 401 d kuriwta/th e)n mousikh=| trofh/ (musical training is most controlling) o(/ti ma/lista katadu/etai ei)s to\ e)nto\s th=s yuxh=s o(/ te r(uqmo\s kai\ a(rmoni/a kai\ e)rrwmene/stata (most mightily) a(/ptetai au)th=s.
paidotri/bou: the teacher of gymnastics, who trained the youth in a palai/stra fitted up by himself or allowed him by the state.
ponhri/an: depravity, wretched condition.

e)k didaska/lwn: the subst. depending on e)k is omitted; cf. e)n *)ari/fronos (320 a), the freq. ei)s didaska/lwn (325 d), ei)s paidotri/bou (326 b), and e)n kiqaristou= memaqhke/nai (Theaet. 206 a), Ar. Plut. 84 e)k *patrokle/ous e)/rxomai, Lysistr. 701 th\n e(tai/ran e)ka/les' e)k tw=n geito/nwn.
e)f' au(tw=n ei)kh=|: cf. 320 a, 323 c.

u(pogra/yantes gramma/s: cf. Seneca Epistol. 94 § 51 digiti puerorum tenentur et aliena manu per literarum simulacra ducuntur, and Quintil. i. 1. 27 cum vero jam ductus sequi coeperit (sc. puer) non inutile erit literas tabellae quam optime insculpi ut per illos velut sulcos ducatur stilus (cf. v. 14. 31). The passages just quoted have led to the impression that Plato also refers to letters to be traced over by the boy. But grammh/ does not mean letter, and we must therefore understand the lines within which the boys must keep their letters. The comparison is thus the more forcible. In Theaet. 172 e, Plato calls the a)ntwmosi/a a u(pografh/, h(=s e)kto\s ou) r(hte/on.

w(/s: rare in prose, cf. 338 a w(\s ou)=n poih/sete, Rep. vii. 530 d kinduneu/ei, w(s pro\s a)stronomi/an o)/mmata pe/phgen, w(\s pro\s e)narmo/nion fora\n w)=ta pagh=nai, it is probable that as the eyes are appointed for astronomy, so the ears for harmonious motions.—The slight mingling of syntactic and paratactic connection, seen in w(\s de/ after w(/sper, is very common in Plato, i.e. 328 a, cf. also o(/mws de/ after ei) 353 d.

eu)qu=nai: to these every official in Athens was subjected on the expiration of his term of office (Hermann Staatsalt. § 154. Schömann gr. Alterth. i. 432^{3}); although they apply only to a)/rxein, Protagoras mentions them on account of the analogy between them and the punishments of children, cf. 325 d. Compare his doctrine of punishment, 324 a f.

e)sti/n: but it does not follow from Protagoras's long argument that virtue is a thing which can be taught, but simply that it is so regarded. See on 324 c, 325 b. Moreover, the virtue taught in the Athenian schools was not at all that which was taught by Protagoras, so that the value of the former training would not prove the value of his.

polu\ ma=llon: i.e. xrh=n qauma/zein, ei) mh\ didakto\n h)=n.
Cf. Hom. b 276 f. pau=roi ga/r toi pai=des o(moi=oi patri\ pe/lontai, | oi( ple/ones kaki/ous, pau=roi de/ te patru\s a)rei/ous.
e)n toi=s e)/mprosqen: cf. 324 e.
i)diwteu/ein: equiv. to mhde\n e)pai+/ein (327 c), mh\ mete/xein (325a), the opposite of dhmiourgo\n ei)=nai/ tinos. Cf. 312 b.
ei) mh\ kte(.: cf. 323 a.

o(poi=o/s tis e)du/nato: sc. ei)=nai, impf. by assimilation; cf. Gorg. 506 b h(de/ws a)\n *kalliklei= tou/tw| e)/ti dielego/mhn, e(/ws au)tw=| th\n tou= *)amfi/onos a)pe/dwka r(h=sin. See GMT. 66, 3; G. 239, 2; H. 919 b.

kai\ e)pe/plhtte: does not influence the construction, on account of the predominance of the idea of dida/skein, hence we read not tw=| au)lou=nti, but the acc. depending on e)di/daske. Cf. Phaedo 94 d ta\ me\n a)peilou=sa ta\ de\ nouqetou=sa tai=s e)piqumi/ais, Gorg. 460 d mh\ tw=| dida/canti e)gkalei=n mhde\ e)celau/nein e)k th=s po/lews a)lla\ tw=| a)dikou=nti we should not lay it to the charge of the instructor, nor banish him, but rather the wrong-doer. So ou)d' a)pokru/ptetai below is outweighed by fqonei=. Cf. 335 e, 1. 53.
e)fqo/nei tou/tou: cf. Menex. 238 a tou/tou de\ tou= karpou= ou)k e)fqo/nhsen (sc. gh=).
e)/fh: serves to remind the reader that Socrates is rehearsing the argument of another; cf. 310 a. Moreover the ‘hyperbaton’ gives emphasis to the words ti ma=llon. See H. 1062.
o(/tou e)/tuxen: see on o(poi=o/s tis e)du/nato above.

e)llo/gimos: ‘proleptic’; cf. Rep. iv. 425 a e)nno/mous te kai\ spoudai/ous e)c au)tw=n a)/ndras au)ca/nesqai, viii. 565 c e(/na tina\ a)ei\ dh=mos ei)/wqe tre/fein te kai\ au)/cein me/gan, Meno 93 d to\n ui(o\n i(ppe/a e)dida/cato a)gaqo/n. So freq.
a)kleh/s: sc. e)ge/neto from hu)ch/qh.

a)ll' ou)=n: but however that might be; stronger than d' ou)=n, and often followed by ge/. This is used when previous statements are for the moment left in abeyance, while that which follows is unquestionably certain. Cf. Apol. 34 e a)ll' ou)=n dedogme/non ge/ e)sti to\ *swkra/th diafe/rein tini\ tw=n pollw=n a)nqrw/pwn, Gorg. 496 d a)ll' ou)=n to/ ge peinh=n au)to\ a)niaro/n (painful).

tou/s: is not repeated, since i)diw/tas and mhde
 e)pai+/ontas relate to the same individuals. Cf. Dem. XIX. 87 (dei=) to
 ai)/tion kai\ paraskeua/santa th
 e)cousi/an tau/thn e)kei/nw| misei=n kai\ timwrei=sqai you ought to hate and to punish the one who is responsible, and who secured this power to that one.

“As, in the supposed case, there would be good and bad flute players, and yet all would be flute players, so now all are upright and virtuous; but because some are more so, those who have less virtue seem to have none. Still, that these last are also really virtuous, would be clear, if they were compared with absolute savages.” So Protagoras wishes to prove his view respecting those who are regarded as unjust and vicious, through what would be indisputably true in the supposed case. This lies in w)/|ou ka)\n nu=n (also now, in the present case), where the question is not of flute playing, but of virtue. oi)/ou kai\ nu=n, the reading of the Mss., would be not a proof but merely an exhortation.

kai\ a)nqrw/pois: since, acc. to Protagoras, men must possess virtue, evidently civil and social life, legal institutions and human society, are allied conceptions, and e)n no/mois and a)nqrw/pois can be connected as synonymous. He has already in mind, too, the contrast between a)/nqrwpoi and the a)/grioi about to be cited.
au)to/n: not himself, but merely referring back to o(/stis.
mhde/: nor, in general.

a)ll' ei)=en: belongs to the rel. clause beginning with oi(=s, which it
follows in free const. — Pherecrates, one of the masters of the old comedy, had in the year 421-420 B.C. (cf. Ath. v. 218 d e)dida/xqhsan de\ oi( *)/agrioi e)p' *)aristi/wnos a)/rxontos) brought out a comedy, the *)/agrioi, to the contents of which the surviving fragments (Meineke Frag. Com. Gr. I. 79 f., II. 254 ff., Kock Com. Att. Frag. I. 146) give almost no clue. Our passage would seem to imply that certain misanthropists (like Timon), who had fled from Athens into a wilderness, had encountered absolutely lawless and savage men, like the Cyclopes of the Odyssey, namely the *)/agrioi, who formed the Chorus. These savages by their rudeness had taught them to prefer an association with even the worst types of common humanity, with Eurybatus and Phrynondas. —
pe/rusi: see Introd. p. 6.
o( poihth/s: an Athenian speaker would hardly have added this qualification to an Athenian name. —
e)di/dacen: the technical term for the training of the actors and the chorus by the poet, then in general for the bringing out of the play. —

e)pi\ *lhnai/w|: means strictly only at the Lenaeon. This was a temple and sacred precinct of Dionysus south of the Acropolis, in and near which were observed the solemnities of the Lenaea, which for this reason were called *dionu/sia ta\ e)pi\ *dhnai/w| in distinction from *dionu/sia ta\ e)n a)/stei, the Great Dionysia (C. I. Att. II. 741 A, a 1. 10, b l. 4, d l. 9 from the years 333-330 B.C.). Between this and the citadel lay the Theatre of Athens, where all tragedies and comedies, on both festivals, were broughtout. Consequently the formula e)pi\ *lhnai/w| cannot designate those brought out at the Lenaean festival. Protagoras, however, uses the expression e)di/dacen e)pi\ *lhnai/w| in the wider sense: such as Pherecrates put upon the stage, as contrasted with the class of men which Socrates encountered in real life. —
e)n geno/menos: coming among. gi/gnesqai and ei)=nai are often used with advs. of place.

The *)/agrioi must have formed the Chorus, and e)n toi=s to<*>ou/tois a)nqrw/pois refers to them; the misa/nqrwpoi then were different persons, and in the words a)gaph/sais a)/n, w(/sper oi( kte(., Protagoras likens Socrates's condition, if he should ever meet beings like those *)/agrioi, to that of the misa/nqrwpoi in meeting the Chorus. We must therefore from the preceding context supply geno/menoi with e)n e)kei/nw| tw=| xorw=|, even though this is a little difficult.

Eurybatus was a thief notorious for his cunning, or an Ephesian who had betrayed Croesus to Cyrus; Phrynondas, an Athenian, infamous by reason of his trickery and baseness. Both had become proverbial representatives of all wickedness. Cf. Ephorus in Harpocr. kai\ e)nteu=qen tou\s ponhrou\s *eu)ruba/tous kalei=sqai, Suid. s.v. frunw/ndas: e)k tou/tou tou\s ponhrou\s frunw/ndas kalou=sin.

kai/: and so, paratactic for w(/ste. Cf. Aesch. Theb. 647 kata/cw d' a)/ndra to/nde, kai\ po/lin | e(/cei, Thuc. i. 99 xrh/mata e)ta/canto, kai\ toi=s *)aqhnai/ois hu)/ceto to\ nautiko\n kte(. — w(/sper kte(.: marks neither an antithesis to the preceding, nor a step in advance, but only an illustration. —
a)/n: see on 318 b.
ou)d' ei(=s: more emphatic than ou)dei/s, cf. 335 d, 343 d. These particles are freq. separated by preps.
oi(=os t' h)=n: sc. dida/skein from memaqh/kasi.
ou) r(a/|dion: anacoluthon, as though ou)de/ g' a)/n had not preceded. The anacoluthon is caused by the repetition in tou/tous e)/ti ti/s a)\n dida/ceien.

tw=n a)pei/rwn: those unskilled in a particular art. For these it is easy to find a teacher, while for the skilled it is difficult. By this example Protagoras gains a step in the development of his argument; unobserved, it forms the transition to his claim that there are nevertheless special teachers in virtue.
ou(/tw de/: after w(/sper, see on 326 d. That w(/sper referred back, and not to a following ou(/tws, is forgotten, as often happens. Sc. ou) p(a/|dion dida/skalon fanh=nai. —

ka)/n: properly an opt. ei)/h should follow, but ka)
 ei) became so much a formula that a)/n sometimes was not regarded in the const. Cf. Meno 72 c ka)
 ei) pollai\ kai\ pantodapai/ ei)sin (ai( a)retai/), e(/n ge/ ti ei)=dos tau)to
 a(/pasai e)/xousin, Symp. 185 a ka)
 ei)/ tis e)capathqei/h, kalh\ h( a)pa/th.
o)li/gon, diafe/rei: are to be taken together. —

probiba/sai: for the inf., cf. Gorg. 517 b metabiba/zein ta\s e)piqumi/as kai\ mh\ e)pitre/pein ou)de\n tou/twn die/feron e)kei=noi in regard to correcting the desires and not indulging them, these men in no wise excelled those others.
o)nh=sai: cf. Rep. x. 600 d ei)/ per oi(=o/s t' h)=n pro\s a)reth\n o)nina/nai a)nqrw/pous.

misqou=: cf. 349 a. Arist. Ethic. N. ix. I, p. 1164 a 25. o(/per fasi\ kai\ *prwtago/ran poiei=n: o(/te ga\r dida/ceien a(dh/pote, timh=sai to\n maqo/nta e)ke/leuen o(/sou dokei= a)/cia e)pi/stasqai, kai\ e)la/mbane tosou=ton. He sought thus to avoid the censure cast upon the sophists because they took money for their instruction.
ga/r: epexegetical, equiv. to namely.
bou/lhtai: for the apod., sc. kate/qhken (gnomic aor.). See on 311 d.
e)lqw\n ei)s i(ero/n: the Greeks, when an oath was to be peculiarly solemn, were wont to take it at some sacred place, as an altar (Andoc. I. 126 labo/menos tou= bwmou= w)/mosen).
The sons of Polycletus are wholly unknown. Obviously, however, they with their father are thought of as well known at Athens.

tw=nde: points to the sons of Pericles then present. Protagoras speaks in defence of his pupils, although compelled to admit the truth of what Socrates has said concerning them in 319 e. — Protagoras began his discourse with the commendation of his own teaching, having previously, before Socrates and Hippocrates, extolled the profession of the sophists; he closes it with a justification of his course in receiving compensation, and a complimentary allusion to his pupils. Grote (Plato II. 45 f.) considers this discourse one of the best parts of the Platonic writings, as an exposition of the growth and propagation of ‘common sense’ among a community.
e)pideica/menos: Socrates humorously refers to Protagoras's speech as made for display, cf. 347 b.
e)pi\ me\n polu\n xro/non: const. with e)/ti e)/blepon. Cf. 345 c, Legg. i. 646 c e)pi\ polla\s h(me/ras.
w(s e)rou=nta/ ti: Protagoras might have added further remarks quite as relevant as those with which he actually concluded.
tw=| o)/nti: in reality; for this dat. of manner, see H. 779 b.
w)= pai= *)apollodw/rou: cf. 335 d. An address of this kind always has something solemn and formal.
w=(de: hither; cf. Photius lex. s.v. kai\ *pla/twn pou ke/xrhtai a)nti\ tou= deu=ro kai\ e)nqa/de. Elsewhere it is found with this meaning only in the poets or late authors.
pollou= poiou=mai: usually peri\ pollou= (cf. Crito 48 e) or pro\ pollou= (cf. Isocr. v. 14). See G. 178; H. 746 a.
smikro/n ti: note the irony of Socrates. The little point proves forthwith to be a central point in the investigation. —
dh=lon o(/ti: see on 324 a, 1. 19.
ta\ polla/: a touch of sarcasm at the long speech of Protagoras.

13 ff. “A popular orator could also deliver a discourse like that of Protagoras, but, after that, in defending himself, and in entering into the exposition of single points when questioned, he would be as powerless as a book, and would on the slightest question deliver immediately another long discourse, as a brazen pot when struck keeps up a long reverberation.”
ei)pei=n: frequent in similar con nections for le/gein. Cf. Gorg. 456 c a)ll' ai(reqh=nai a)\n to\n ei)pei=n dunato/n (the man of ability in speaking), ei) bou/loito. —

w(/sper bibli/a kte(.: “They can only make speeches, they cannot defend a position” (e)rwta=n kai\ a)pokri/nesqai, i.e. diale/gesqai Crat. 390 c). Cf. Phaedr. 275 d deino
 ga/r pou tou=t' e)/xei grafh/,
kai\ w(s a)lhqw=s o(/moion zwgrafi/a| (the art of painting)' kai\ ga ta\ e)kei/nhs e)/kgona e(/sthke me
 w(s zw=nta, e)a
 d' a)ne/rh| ti, semnw=s pa/nu siga=|. tau)to
 de\ kai\ oi( lo/goi: do/cais me
 a)
 w(/s ti fronou=ntas au)tou\s le/gein, e)a
 de/ ti e)/rh| tw=n legome/nwn boulo/menos maqei=n, e(/n ti shmai/nei mo/non tau)to
 a)ei/. Cf. also below, 336 b f., 347 e ff.
a)potei/nei: freq. intrans. as here. Cf. Gorg. 458 b kai\ nu=n i)/sws po/rrw a)potenou=men. More often with to\n lo/gon, makrou\s lo/gous and the like. Cf. 335 c, 336 c, 361 a. —

kai\ ou(/tw: we should expect ou(/tw kai/, but thus also Rep. i. 354 b a)ll w(/sper oi( li/xnoi tou= ai)ei\ paraferome/nou a)pogeu/ontai a(rpa/zontes (but just as epicures hurriedly taste of every dish successively placed before them), kai\ e)gw/ moi dokw= ou(/tw o(rmh=sai (to have hastened on), ix. 585 a w(/sper pro/s me/lan faio\n a)poskopou=ntes, pro\s to\ a)/lupon ou(/tw lu/phn a)forw=ntes a)patw=ntai as though regarding gray as white in comparison with black, so regarding the absence of pain as pleasure in comparison with pain, they are deceived.

do/lixon: (from dolixo/s) the long course. “They reply in a speech of endless length.” The do/lixos was the severest of all the foot-races; in it the length of the stadium was traversed twelve times, at least, and perhaps twenty or even twenty-four times. The Spartan Ladas, victorious in this race, fell dead at the goal. Cf. 335 e tw=n dolixodro/mwn tw|. Phocion uses a similar figure (cf. Plutarch Phoc. 23) kalw=s pro\s to\ sta/dion (pareskeua=sqai dokou=sin), to\n de\ do/lixon tou= pole/mou fobou=mai, so also the comic poet Epicrates (Meineke Com. Gr. iii. 366) e)pei\ de\ do/lixon toi=s e)/tesin h)/dh tre/xei.
w(s au)to\ dhloi=: see on 324 a.
a(/: refers to e)rwthqei\s a)pokri/nasqai kte(.

smikrou) kte(.: cf. Euthyphro 13 a a)lla\ smikrou= tinos e)/ti e)ndeh/s ei)mi. The inf. pa/nt' e)/xein depends upon e)ndeh/s ei)mi, cf. Crat. 432 d h)\ ou)k ai)sqa/nei o(/sou e)nde/ousin ai( ei)ko/nes (how far the images fall short) tau)ta\ e)/xein e)kei/nois w(=n ei)ko/nes ei)si/n; Lys. 204 e pollou= dei=s to\ ei)=dos a)gnoei=n tou= paido/s. Since, however, here the sense is that of pa/nt' a)\n e)/xoimi, the corresponding cond. form ei)/ moi a)pokri/naio to/de follows.
fh/|s: implies assertion, not argument; asdoes thefollowing peiqoi/mhna)/n.

ei)/ per a)/llw| tw| cf. 352 c, Phaedo 67 b e)kei= i(kanw=s, ei)/per pou a)/lloqi (i.e. if anywhere), kth/sasqai tou=to, 63 c eu)= i)/ste, o(/ti, ei)/per ti a)/llo tw=n toiou/twn, dusxurisai/mhn (affirm confidently) a)
 kai\ tou=to. So almost always. Very rarely has ei)/per a verb of its own, as Meno 98 b a)ll' ei)/per ti a)/llo fai/hn a)
 ei)de/nai, o)li/ga d) a)
 fai/hn, e(
 d) ou)=n kai\ tou=to e)kei/nwn qei/hn a)
 w(=n oi)=da (this, at any rate, I would put down as one of the things that I know).
o(\ d' e)qau/masa kte(.: cf. Apol. 17 a ma/lista d' au)tw=n e(\n e)qau/masa.
th\n dikaiosu/nhn, ai\dw=: cf. 322 c di/khn kai\ ai)dw=.

pollaxou=: cf. 323 a e, 325 a. — If the different virtues form together only one and the same, viz. virtue, this fails to harmonize (au)=) with the representation that Zeus sent to men swfrosu/nh and ai)dw/s as two different virtues. —
h( dikaiosu/nh kte(.: placed emphatically before w(s, cf. Thuc. iii. 5 oi( d' e)k tw=n *)aqhnw=n pre/sbeis w(s ou)de\n h)=lqon pra/cantes, e)s po/lemon kaqi/stanto oi( *mutilhnai=oi.

The following argument upon the unity of the virtues is intended mainly to show that Protagoras has maintained their diversity, without having clearly thought out the matter. Socrates's request looks towards the definition, which would naturally have been given at the outset; see on 320 b.

e(no\s o)/ntos: repeated from above.
Socrates asks whether the particular virtues differ qualitatively or quantitatively; in their nature, or only in the degree and amount of the virtue contained in them. —
po/teron: sc. tau=ta mo/ria/ e)stin.
diafe/rei: with anacoluthon; we should have expected w(/sper ta\ tou= xrusou= mo/ria (sc. mo/ria/ e)sti tou= xrusou=), ou)de\n diafe/ronta kte(.
fai/netai: sc. pro\s th\n a)reth\n e)/xein.
kai\ metalamba/nousin kte(.: “in addition to the fact of their difference, do men also possess them singly?”

a)/llo: since men possess the object in its entireness, the acc. is used as a sort of cognate acc. Cf. 355 c, Apol. 36 b ou) metalabw\n to\ pe/mpton me/ros tw=n yh/fwn, Tim. 59 b kai\ gh=s mo/rion o)li/gon kai\ lepto\n metasxo/n.
sofi/a, a)ndrei/a: these complete the list of the five cardinal virtues discussed in this dialogue.

a)/llo: we should have expected to\ me
 a)/llo. Cf. Phil. 56 d ph=| pote\ diorisa/menos ou)=n a)/llhn, th
 de\ a)/llhn qei/h tis a)
 a)riqmhtikh/n how would you distinguish between the one and the other arithmetic? So often o( de/ without a preceding o( me/n (G. 143, N. 2). Cf. 331 a, 334 a, 343 e, 355 e, Theaet. 181 d du/o dh\ le/gw tou/tw ei)/dh kinh/sews, a)lloi/wsin, th
 de\ perifora/n I say now that there are these two kinds of motion, change, and motion in place, Symp. 207 d ou)de/pote ta\ au)ta\ e)/xwn e)n au(tw=| o(/mws o( au)to\s kalei=tai, a)lla\ ne/os a)ei\ gigno/menos, ta\ de\ a)pollu/s for he never retains the same substance, while yet called the same man, but in part he is ever becoming new, and in part he is suffering loss.
du/namin: force, efficiency, then nature, peculiar quality.

ou)k e)/fh: he said no. Certain verbs, beyond a mere negation, have their meaning at times precisely reversed by ou): i.e. ou)/ fhmi, nego, deny; ou)x u(pisxnou=mai, refuse; ou)k a)ciw=, regard as unworthy; ou)k e)w=, veto, forbid.
pra=gma/ ti h)\ kte(.: the Platonic Socrates often begins his examinations thus. Cf. 330 d, 332 a, 358 d.
*)=w *prwtago/ra te kai\ *sw/krates: out of respect for Protagoras, Socrates naturally reverses the order of persons in the common address, cf. 311 d, 316 a. This order is found also in 353 a.

au)to\ tou=to: in itself; justice in the abstract, as distinguished from the concrete objects which possess the quality. “Justice in itself must be just.” Cf. tou=to au)to\ to\ pra=gma below, and 360 e, 1. 3.
e)/stin a)/ra kte(.: is a further question of the supposed interlocutor.
fai/hn: equiv. to sumfai/hn, a frequent usage, cf. 332 a.
ou)kou=n, po/teron: these are also words of the supposed questioner. But there is an ellipsis of ei) de\ e)pane/roito, which would show this, and of which a)ganakth/saim' a)/n forms the apod.
XIX.
w(s: is seldom used thus with the inf., while oi(=os is often so used, cf. 330 c d, 331 a, o(/son 334 c. —
ou)k ei)=nai: the difference is conceived as a fact. mh/ would have indicated rather dependence in thought.
pra=gma: connected with di/kaion. Const. o(sio/ths ou) toiou=to/n e)stin, oi(=on ei)=nai di/kaion pra=gma.

to\ de\ a)no/sion: sc. h( dikaiosu/nh. The whole sent. might have closed with oi(=on o(/sion, but in order to bring out more strongly the absurdity of the result, if the parts of virtue are unlike, Socrates adds a)ll' oi(=on mh\ o(/sion. This then leads him to add further, respecting o(sio/ths, the description oi(=on mh\ di/kaion. But this negative mh\ di/kaion naturally calls out the yet stronger positive expression a)ll' a)/dikon a)/ra. When now Socrates has added this for o(sio/ths, it occurs to him to complete the matter by making just such a statement regarding that which has been predicated of dikaiosu/nh, and he adds to\ de\ a)no/sion, as though following a)lla\ to\ me\n a)/dikon, cf. 330 a. There is here also an imitation of easy
conversational style. — To treat mh\ o(/sion and a)no/sion, mh\ di/kaion and a)/dikon, as identical, is not, to be sure, strictly logical, since o(/sion and mh\ o(/sion, di/kaion and mh\ di/kaion are contradictories, o(/sion and a)no/sion, di/kaion and a)/dikon, contraries. Infants and idiots are neither the one nor the other. But as soon as, in the case of a person, one can speak of the quality just, pious, to be not just and unjust is the same thing. The defect in the argument, however, probably occasions the words h)\ o(/ ti o(moio/taton below.
kai/: also. It does not belong with de/.

dikaio/ths: rare, here prob. owing to conjunction with o(sio/ths, cf. Gorg. 508 a. This ending is a favorite one with Plato; see Lehrs's Arist. p. 257^{3}. — At first only the likeness of the two concepts is declared. Then, in order to emphasize this statement, the assertion follows that there is no such likeness between either of these concepts and any other.
a(plou=n: absolutely true, without exception. —
sugxwrh=sai: sc. me/ from the preceding moi/.
mh/ moi: see on 318 b.
to/: for the neut. art. with a clause, see G. 141, N. 7. —

ei) bou/lei: Socrates often rejects concessions made merely from courtesy, mere conditional assent, because he has to do with truth, with genuine persuasion, not with a momentary exhibition of his own skill and acuteness. He who will find the truth must take into the contest himself and his real belief; cf. 333 c.
tou=to kte(.: I use this expression ‘you and me.’ tou=to does not refer to what follows (by ‘you and me’ I mean this).
e)/stin o(/ph|: in a certain way. In these adv. expressions the verbal force of e)/stin has ceased to be felt.
tau=ta: viz. ta\ tou= prosw/pou mo/ria. But to say this, would be senseless.
ka)\n pa/nu kte(.: i.e. “this likeness or unlikeness cannot, when but a minimum, yet give its name to the objects.”

ou) me/ntoi ou)de/: a freq. doubling of negs. Cf. Xen. An. i. 8. 20 kai\ ou)de\n me/ntoi ou)de\ tou=ton paqei=n e)/fasan, ou)d' a)/llos de\ e)/paqen ou)dei\s ou)de/n. See G. 283, 9; H. 1030. — Protagoras having thus renounced his own position and rejected that of Socrates, has effectually blocked the argument.

e)/fh: see on 330 d. — The proof that sofi/a and swfrosu/nh must coincide, because they are both the contrary of the concept a)frosu/nh, rests simply on the indefiniteness of the concept a)frosu/nh. It must be admitted that Plato was entirely conscious of this, but intentionally lets Socrates confuse and vanquish the sophists with their own weapons. See on 329 c.
ou(/tw pra/ttontes: in acting thus; not a mere repetition of o(/tan pra/ttwsin. Cf. o(/ti a)dikei= 333 b.
h)\ tou)nanti/on: i.e. a)fro/nws pra/ttein.
o)cu/: high in tone.
a)nalogisw/meqa: think over again, recapitulate. Cf. Rep. x. 618 c a)nalogizo/menon pa/nta ta\ nu=n dh\ r(hqe/nta. The more common word for the thought with Plato is a)nomologei=sqai.
e)nanti/ws;
pa/nu ge: repeats, but with emphasis, what has already been said.

to/: const. with the following clause. Cf. to\ ei) bou/lei 331 c, 1. 29. Similarly to/ is used with the inf. as epexegesis of substs. Cf. Phaedo 92 a e)a/nper mei/nh| h(/de h( oi)/hsis, to\ a(rmoni/an me\n ei)=nai cu/nqeton pra=gma, 94 b ei) o)rqh\ h( u(po/qesis h)=n, to\ yuxh\n a(rmoni/an ei)=nai.

pro\s tw=| ei)=nai: besides being. Cf. Phaedr. 252 a pro\s ga\r tw=| se/besqai i)atro\n eu(/rhke mo/non tw=n megi/stwn po/nwn for besides his worship, he has found the only physician to heal his sharpest pangs, 270 a o(\ kai\ *periklh=s pro\s tw=| eu)fuh\s ei)=nai e)kth/sato.
a)no/moia: pred., sc. e)le/gonto ei)=nai.

mousikw=s: the comparison of conflicting statements with discordant tones, and the reverse, is not uncommon. Cf. Phaedo, 92 c ou(=tos ou)=n soi o( lo/gos e)kei/nw| pw=s cuna/|setai; kai\ mh\n pre/pei ge ei)/per tw| a)/llw| lo/gw| cunw|dw=| ei)=nai kai\ tw=| peri\ a(rmoni/as (and certainly, if any doctrine should be harmonious, that should be which relates to harmony), Lach. 188 d.

e(ni/: to this a)frosu/nh corresponds in the following words; to e(/n, the noms. sofi/a and swfrosu/nh, which are not e(/n, but plei/w. Plato therefore must have written plei/w, not the plei/osi of the Mss.

o)/nti: attracted from the fem. by the neut. e(ni/. Cf. 354 c th
 h(donh
 w(s a)gaqo
 o)/n. See H. 610.
h)= ga/r: is it not so? ga/r refers back to the preceding conclusion; and a)/llws pws indicates that a general expression (like ou(/tws e)/xei) is to be supplied. —
kai/: and that, although.
to\ pro/teron: cf. 331
a b. The remarks of Protagoras 331 c-e do not merit notice by Socrates.

o(/ti: in so far as. Cf. 333 d o(/ti a)dikou=sin, Parm. 155 e to\ e(\n — a)=r' ou)k a)na/gkh, o(/ti me\n e)/stin e(/n, ou)si/as mete/xein pote/, o(/ti d) ou)k e)/sti, mh\ mete/xein au)= pote\ ou)si/as; Symp. 207 d du/natai de\ tau/th| mo/non, th=| gene/sei, o(/ti a)ei\ katalei/pei e(/teron ne/on a)nti\ tou= palaiou= and this is possible only in this way, by generation, in so far as it always leaves behind a new in place of the old.
e)/gwge: with strong emphasis, e)pei\ . . . a)nqrw/pwn being antithetic. —
e)pei/: “although”; cf. 353 a.
tw=n pollw=n: not the majority, but referring to the polloi/ above.

“It is unimportant who maintains a principle under consideration, provided the principle itself be scrutinized; still, in the scrutiny, the views of those who hold the principle are brought to the test.”
e)kallwpi/zeto: pretended to be coy. Cf. Phaedr. 236 d pau=sai pro/s me kallwpizo/menos: sxedo\n ga\r e)/xw o(\ ei)pw\n a)nagka/sw se le/gein. In 317 c above, the sense is to plume himself.
dusxerh=: cf. 332 a.
e)/stw: be it so; an attempt to make the unavoidable concession without assent.

o(/ti a)dikou=sin: (see on b, 1. 53, above, o(/ti a)dikei=) is here emphatically repeated, as is afterwards a)dikou=ntes. Thus the attention is held to the question, with reference to the swfronei=n a)dikou=nta, whether a eu)= fronei=n and eu)= bouleu/esqai can be thought of in the particular relation to the a)dikei=n, and not in relation to something else with which the a)dikei=n might accidentally be associated. By means of the proof that this is inconceivable, Socrates aims to reach the demonstration that <*>wfrosu/nh and dikaiosu/nh are one.

toi=s a/nqrw/pois: naturally added after w)fe/lima, although the question under discussion can have reference only to men. But Protagoras seizes upon the words, and, carried away by his irritation, proceeds to refer w)fe/- lima to things which can have neither swfrosu/nh nor a)diki/a, even at last to the human body, in distinction from the man himself.

a)gwnia=n: prop. am eager for a fight; then, as feverish anxiety may be connected with this, generally am excited, in inward disquiet. Cf. Charm. 162 c kai\ o( *kriti/as dh=los me
 h)=n kai\ pa/lai a)gwniw=n kai\ filoti/mws pro/s te to
 *xarmi/dhn kai\ pro\s tou\s paro/ntas e)/xwn, Lys. 210 e katidw
 ou)=n au)to
 a)gwniw=nta kai\ teqorubhme/non u(po\ tw=n legome/nwn. —

parateta/xqai: prop. of soldiers, an army, in line ready for battle; here, like many such terms, transferred to the contest of words; stand in fighting attitude. Socrates observed more and more clearly (cf. 332 a), that Protagoras, vexed and excited, stood ready to break out (as he in fact afterwards does) with a refusal to give further answers.

a)nqrw/pois me\n kte(.: Protagoras here gives a long disquisition upon the relative nature of the useful which probably recalled actual discourses of his (see on 351 c), but he becomes confused in endeavoring to drag in much which should be kept separate. He has denied that the absolutely useless is good (ou)damw=s), but adds that he knows of much which is injurious to men, but beneficial to animals or plants. As he now begins with a)nqrw/pois me\n a)nwfelh=, it occurs to him that all things fall into three classes, the useful, the harmful and the neutral, so he adds to his first class ta\ de\ ge\ w)fe/lima, ta\ de\ ou)de/tera. By adding, with the last, a)nqrw/pois me/n, he returns to his opening thought, but continues only with i(/ppois de/, failing to add the w)fe/lima, because it is so vividly in his mind as the object of his discourse. —

a)nwfelh=: prop. useless, not infreq. harmful. Cf. Rep. viii. 560 d meta\ pollw=n kai\ a)nwfelw=n e)piqumiw=n, of which it had before been said 559 a ou)de\n a)gaqo\n e)nou=sai drw=sin, ai( de\ kai\ tou)nanti/on.
ou)deni/: since species are spoken of, ou)de/si might have been used (cf. Euthyd. 305 d), but whatever is denied of each individual must be denied also of the species. Cf. Dem. XIX. 66 and 62.

to\ e)/laion kte(.: note the artistic order, exciting surprise and expectation in the listeners. — Cf. Theophr. de causis plant. v. 15. 6 kai\ ga\r tau=ta (oleum, pix, adeps) fqei/rei kai\ ma/lista ta\ futa\ ta\ ne/a = Plin. N. H. xvii. 234.
e)ntau=qa: in this case, with man's body.

tw=| a)nqrw/pw|: loosely added, epexeg. of e)ntau=qa. Regularly, when two dats. are connected, of the whole and of a part, the dat. of the whole precedes. Cf. 339 e, 1. 44, Rep. iii. 407 b h)\ nosotrofi/a (diet in disease) tektonikh=| me\n kai\ tai=s a)/llais te/xnais e)mpo/dion nh=|
prose/cei tou= nou= (the application of the mind)? Lach. 190 b toi=s uie/sin au)tw=n a)reth\ paragenome/nh tai=s yuxai=s.
me/llei: for the change of number from a)sqenou=si, see on 319 d.

o(/son mo/non: equiv. to tosou/tw| mo/non w(/ste. Cf. Theaet. 145 a h)= ou)=n zwgrafiko\s *qeo/dwros; THEAET. ou)x, o(/son ge/ me ei)de/nai. — Thus Protagoras's reply to the question dokou=si/ tine/s soi swfronei=n a)dikou=ntes, ends somewhat wide of the mark, but gains the applause of the listeners. See on 328 d.
w(s: how. Cf. 315 b, 1. 35, Crito 43 b pa/lai qauma/zw ai)sqano/menos w(s h(de/ws kaqeu/deis.
e)pilh/smwn tis : ti\s indicates that the object approximately corresponds to the word; here somewhat. See on 313 c, l. 22. See H. 702 a.
e)pilanqa/nomai: cf. 336 d. This, which Socrates applies to himself, was true of the listeners. —
peri\ ou(= a)\n kte(.: whatever we are talking about, i.e. however weighty or trifling the topic may be. —

w(/sper ou)=n, ei) kte(.: cf. Apol. 17 d w(/sper ou)=n a)/n, ei) tw=| o)/nti ce/nos e)tu/gxanon w)/n, sunegignw/skete dh/pou a)/n moi (you would certainly indulge me) ei) e)n e)kei/nh| th=| fwnh=| te kai\ tw=| tro/pw| e)/legon e)n oi(=sper e)teqra/mmhn (in which I had been reared), kai\ dh\ kai\ nu=n kte(.
kai\ au)to\s . . . dida/cai: parenthetical.

makra\ le/gein kte(.: the sophists and rhetoricians boasted of their ability to speak on any subject as long or as briefly as one desired. Cf. 329 b, 335 b, Phaedr. 267 b *tisi/an de\ *gorgi/an te e)a/somen eu(/dein, oi(\ suntomi/an te lo/gwn kai\ a)/peira mh/kh peri\ pa/ntwn a)neu=ron (invented)? Gorg. 449 c kai\ ga\r au)= kai\ tou=to e(/n e)stin w(=n fhmi/, mhde/na a)\n e)n braxute/rois e)mou= ta\ au)ta\ ei)pei=n. Cf. Anaximenes Rhet. 22.
a)gw=na: this conversation then was not a search for truth, but a contest for victory. Cf. Gorg. 456 d.

w(s . . . dielego/mhn: added, without a copula, as an explanatory appos., to tou=to e)poi/oun. Cf. Rep. ii. 359 c ei) toio/nde poih/saimen th=| dianoi/a, do/ntes e)cousi/an e)pakolouqh/saimen, Meno 71 b kai\ au)to\s ou(/tws e)/xw, sumpe/nomai toi=s poli/tais (I share the poverty of the citizens), tou/tou tou= pra/gmatos, Gorg. 479 b kinduneu/ousi toiou=to/n ti poiei=n kai\ oi( th\n di/khn feu/gontes, to\ a)lgeino\n au)tou= kaqora=n those who flee from justice, seem to do the same sort of thing, (they seem) to see its painful side. A freq. usage.
ou)deno\s belti/wn: see on 324 d. —
e)ge/neto kte(.: see on 327 d.

o)/noma: cf. Apol. 38 c o)/noma e(/cete kai\ ai)ti/an u(po\ tw=n boulome/nwn th
 po/lin loidorei=n, 20 c ou) ga sou= ge ou)de
 tw=n a)/llwn peritto/teron pragmat euome/nou tosau/th fh/mh kai\ lo/gos ge/gonen, Xen. An. vii. 3. 19 para\ *seu/qh| to\ so
 o)/noma me/gisto/n e)sti.
e)kw\n ei)=nai: see on 317 a.
a)lla/ toi: in immediate reply to the declaration of Protagoras above, hence also ou)d' e)gw/ neither do I.
a)du/natos: with acc., cf. Meno 94 b i(/na de\ mh\ o)li/gous oi)/h| kai\ tou\s faulota/tous *)aqhnai/wn a)duna/tous gegone/nai tou=to to\ pra=gma. —
e)pei/: see on 333 c, 1. 54.
i(/na e)gi/gneto: for secondary tense of indic. in a final clause, expressing a purpose which cannot be fulfilled, see G. 216, 3; H. 884.
sunousi/a: conversation; cf. 338c.
a)potei/nonti: see on 329 a.

e)pei\ kte(.: for, if I had time, I should be glad to listen to this also (tau=ta equiv. to tou\s makrou\s lo/gous). Socrates in Plato is never at a loss to cover his meaning, — in this case, aversion to the long discourses of the sophists, — in terms of expression which are courteous yet perfectly transparent.
tri/bwnos: see on 342 c.
o(moi/ws e)/sontai : ei)=nai as well as gi/gnesqai may be modified by advs. See on 325 b, 1. 22.
w(s: causal; see on 310 e.
me/n, a)ta/r: cf. Rep. ii. 367 e a)ei\ me\n dh\ t\h\n fu/sin tou= te *glau/kwnos kai\ tou= *)adeima/ntou h)ga/mhn, a)ta\r ou)=n kai\ to/te pa/nu ge h(/sqhn, Xen. Hell. v. 4. 17. —
filosofi/an: here, as freq., desire for knowledge, intellectual aspiration; cf. Rep. ii. 376 b to/ ge filomaqe\s kai\ filo/sofon tau)to/n; Lys. 213 d e)kei/nou h(sqei\s th=| filosofi/a|.
w(/sper a)\n ei): see on 311 b. — Crison had conquered in the Olympic races, Ol. 83, 84 and 85 (448, 444, 440 B.C.), cf. Diod. xii. 5. 23, 29. In Legg. viii. 840 a his temperance is praised.
e(/pesqai: keep up with. —
dolixodro/mwn: see on 329 a. —
h(merodro/mwn: couriers, like Phidippides in Nep. Milt. c. 4 and Hdt. vi. 105. Hemerodromos (says Livy xxxi. 24) vocant Graeci, ingens die uno cursu emetientes spatium.

diaqei=n: cf. Theaet. 148c ei) diaqe/wn tou= a)kma/zontos kai\ taxi/stou h(tth/qhs if in a race you had been beaten by a man full grown and very swift. diaqei=n te kai/ is inserted dia\ me/sou (see on 327 a), and tw/| depends upon e(/pesqai. In many compounds dia/ expresses a race.
a)ll' ou) ga/r: see H. 1050, 4, d.

sugkaqei=nai: intr., as are many compounds of i(e/nai. Cf. 338 a, 1. 21, Theaet. 168 b i(/lew| th=| dianoi/a| sugkaqei\s w(s a)lhqw=s ske/yei in a spirit genial and sincerely accommodating, you will search, Rep. viii. 563 a oi( de\ ge/rontes cugkaqie/ntes toi=s ne/ois eu)trapeli/as te kai\ xarientismou= e)mpi/plantai.

xwri\s ei)=nai: is different in na ture or kind. Cf. Soph. O. C. 808 xwri\s to/ t' ei)pei=n polla\ kai\ ta\ kai/ria to say much and to speak fittingly are different things, Euthyd. 289 d dh=lon ou)=n o(/ti kai\ peri\ lo/gous xwri\s h( tou= poiei=n te/xnh kai\ h( tou= xrh=sqai evidently, as regards speeches, the art of making them differs from the art of using them. So also di/xa.
dhmhgorei=n: harangue, with more regard for the impression than for the treatment of the subject. —

o(ra=|s: either with or without w(s or o(/ti, stands freq. at the beginning of clauses, like our you see, i.e. you see for yourself. Cf. Xen. Hier. i. 16 a)ll' o(ra=|s: e)kei=no/
ge ou)k a)\n e)/ti pei/sais a)nqrw/pwn ou)de/na w(s kte(., Ar. Pax 331 a)ll' o(ra=t), ou)/pw pe/pausqe; Plato Crat. 432 c o(ra=|s ou)=n o(/ti a)/llhn xrh\ ei)ko/nos o)rqo/thta (principle of correctness) zhtei=n. Different is the interr. o(ra=|s do you see? Cf. Apol. 24 d o(ra=|s, w)= *me/lhte, o(/ti siga=|s kai\ ou)k e)/xeis ei)pei=n;
*)alkibia/dhs: cf. 309 b.
tou=: const. with ei)=nai.
te/: see on 325 b.
ei) . . . paraxwrei=: cf. 315 e ei) tugxa/nei w)/n.
a)ntipoiei=tai: sc. tou= krei/sswn ei)=nai dialexqh=nai.
mh/: and not ou), because const. with an imv. (equiv. to mhde\ a)poteine/tw); but ou)k e)qe/lwn, because e)kkrou/wn . . . lo/gon gives the reasons for the a)potei/nein, as they actually exist.

e)kkrou/wn: lit. strike out a weapon or a ball from one's hand, thrust one out of the way; then, put to one side, frustrate, always with the idea of violence. Here e)kkrou/wn tou\s lo/gous means “frustrating the purpose,” “defeating the result of the discussion.” Cf. Arist. Eth. N. iii. 15 ka)
 mega/lai kai\ sfrodrai\ w)=si (ai( e)piqumi/ai), kai\ to
 logismo
 e)kkrou/ousin, Dem. XL. 43 i(/na a)podiaithqe/nta mou lu/sas e)c a)rxh=s me sukofanth=| kai\ th
 di/khn tau/thn e)kkrou/h|.

ou)x o(/ti: i.e. ou) le/gw o(/ti. I do not speak of the fact that; or, in sense, although. Freq. in Plato. See on 319 d. — Nothing can ruffle Socrates's courtesy, but Plato puts into the mouth of the impetuous Alcibiades a plain and vigorous statement of what is already in the reader's mind. Prob. Alcibiades was an exception to the oi/ paro/ntes a)neqoru/bhsan 334 c.
pro/s: on the side of.

koinou\s kte(.: Prodicus gave much attention to the matter of synonyms, o)rqo/ths tw=n o)noma/twn, as he termed it, and his lecture upon the subject cost fifty drachmas. Cf. Crat. 384 b; Spengel sunagwgh\ texnw=n pp. 46-59. Since he attached too great value to this art, as it seems, and was always introducing such distinctions, he here, as 340 a, 358

a d, encounters the raillery of Socrates. For the sake of making a good hit, Plato perhaps goes beyond the reality in his description. koino/s and i)/sos were habitually joined with a)kroath/s. Cf. Dem. de Cor. 7 parasxw
 e(auto
 i)/son kai\ koino
 a)mfote/rois a)kroa- th/n, XXIX. 1 a)/n per i)/soi kai\ koinoi\ ge/nhsqe h(mw=n a)kroatai/, XV. 29 tw=n me
 ga i)di/wn dikai/wn oi( no/moi koinh
 th
 metousi/an e)/dosan kai\ i)/shn kai\ toi=s a)sqene/si kai\ toi=s i)sxuroi=s. Prodicus's remark takes up the koinh=| used by Critias.

e)gw\ me\n kai\ au)to\s kte(.: cf. Prisc. viii. 35 Cicero in Protagora: nunc a vobis, o Protagora et Socrates, postulo, ut de isto concedatis alter alteri et inter vos de hujuscemodi rebus controversemini, non concertetis.
di) eu)/noian: with the best of feel- ing.
e)n h(mi=n: before us as judges. See on 355 d; cf. Gorg. 464 d ei) de/oi e)n paisi\ diagwni/zesqai o)yopoio/n te kai\ i)atro/n.
polla/kis: const. with yeudome/nwn.

eu)frainoi/meqa: cf. Arist. Top. ii. 6. 6 *pro/dikos dih|rei=to ta\s h(dona\s ei)s xara
 kai\ te/ryin kai\ eu)frosu/nhn, but the distinctions themselves are not specified, and the statement is not sustained by the passage from Prodicus in Xen. Mem. ii. I. 24 ti/ a)
 kexarisme/non h)\ siti/on h)\ poto
 eu(/rois, h)\ ti/ a)
 i)dw
 h)\ ti/ a)kou/sas terfqei/hs, h)\ ti/nwn o)sfraino/menos h)\ a(pto/menos h(sqei/hs, ti/si de\ paidikoi=s o(milw=n ma/list' a)
 eu)franqei/hs.
au)th=|, au)tw=|: in sense nearly equiv. to mo/nh| and mo/nw|. See on 309 a.

suggenei=s: it was the cardinal point of the sophistic ethics, that positive laws are arbitrary restrictions, imposed upon men by powerful individuals or by the majority, with the purpose simply of putting them down, and of restraining the natural rights of the individual, i.e. those things which he desires and regards as his rights. That Hippias also taught this is shown by Xen. Mem. iv. 4. 14 ff. Plato therefore, in order here to characterize him, makes him express this principle.

o(/moion tw=| o(moi/w|: cf. Gorg. 510 b fi/los moi dokei= e(/kastos e(ka/stw| ei)=nai w(s oi(=o/n te ma/lista, o(/nper oi( palaioi/ te kai\ sofoi\ le/gousin, o( o(/moios tw=| o(moi/w|, Symp. 195 b o( ga\r palaio\s lo/gos eu)= e)/xei, w(s o(/moion o(moi/w| a)ei\ pela/zei, Lys. 214 b ou)kou=n kai\ toi=s tw=n sofwta/twn suggra/mmasin e)ntetu/xhkas tau=ta au)ta\ le/gousin, o(/ti to\ o(/moion tw=| o(moi/w| a)na/gkh a)ei\ fi/lon ei)=nai; ei)si\ de/ pou ou(/toi oi( peri\ fu/sew/s (nature) te kai\ tou= o(/lou (the universe) dialego/menoi kai\ gra/fontes, a description referring directly to Empedocles, but applying equally well to Hippias.

no/mos: the sophists often appealed, in support of their view of right, to a passage of Pindar (Frag. inc. 151 Boeckh, 169 Bgk.) no/mos o( pa/ntwn basileu\s qnatw=n te kai\ a)qana/twn a)/gei dikaiw=n to\ biaio/taton u(perta/ta| xeiri/ (does, and makes just, that which is most violent, with supreme hand), understanding by this the law of nature. Cf. Gorg. 484 b, 488 b. —
polla\ kte(.: often forces unnatural connections, i.e. of ordinary and superior natures in the state.

prutanei=on: was originally probably in most Greek cities the public building devoted to the Prytanis, the highest official, where was also the sanctuary of the *(esti/a, the sacred state-hearth, so that it formed the heart and centre of the city. Athens therefore is called here and by Theopompus (Athem. vi. 254 b) to\ prutanei=on th=s *(/ella/dos, in the same sense in which a Pythian oracle (Ael. V.H. iv. 6) called her th\n koinh\n e(sti/an th=s *(ella/dos, Pindar (Frag. 54) *(ella/dos e)/reisma, Thucydides (Anth. vii. 45) *(ella/dos *(ella/s, others to\ th=s *(ella/dos mousei=on. — The solemn, pompous, and at the same time flattering style of Hippias's words is doubtless true to the life.

Hippias compares himself and the rest of the company to arbitrators, umpires, freely chosen by the contending parties. It is the office of these umpires to persuade both parties (here, Socrates and Protagoras) to moderate their demands and to unite upon some intermediate course. sumbai/nein and sumbiba/zein are here the technical expressions (cf. Thuc. ii. 29 cunebi/base de\ kai\ to\n *perdi/kkan toi=s *)aqhnai/ois). u(po/ is used because sumbh=nai has a pass. sense. See H. 820. — The peculiar transposition of the words, for u(f' h(mw=n w(/sper u(po\ diaithtw=n, is very freq. in Plato in such comparisons. Cf. Rep. iii. 414 e dei= w(s peri\ mhtro\s kai\ trofou= th=s xw/ras e)n h(=| ei)si\ bouleu/esqai, vii. 520 e w(s e)p' a)nagkai=on au)tw=n e(/kastos ei)=si to\ a)/rxein (will take office), viii. 545 e w(s pro\s pai=das h(ma=s paizou/das (viz. ta\s *mou/sas), Theaet. 170 a w(/sper pro\s qeou\s e)/xein tou\s e)n e(ka)stois a)/rxontas look up to their commanders in such peril as to gods. — As sumbh=nai in this sense almost always stands absolutely, ei)s to\ me/son is most simply connected with sumbibazo/ntwn.
li/an: belongs to zhtei=n, and stands at the end of the clause because it is emphatic.

fai/nwntai: come into view, present themselves. Cf. Euthyd. 288 c oi)=mai ga/r ti au)toi=n pa/gkalon fanei=sqai, e)peida
 a)/rcwntai spouda/zein for I think some great beauty will appear in the two, when they begin to be in earnest, 294 a w(s qaumasto
 le/geis kai\ a)gaqo
 me/ga pefa/nqai. — As this refers only to Socrates's words, it cannot have u(mi=n with the Mss. h(mi=n is ethical dat. —

pa/nta ka/lwn e)ktei/nanta: (or sei/ein, e)fie/nai, kinei=n, e)klu/ein), like ou)ri/a| e)fie/nai and a)pokru/ptein gh=n, a nautical expression, “letting out all the ropes, that hold and stretch the sails, as long as possible,” i.e. setting every sail. Then figuratively, cf. Schol. on Plato ii., p. 466 Bk. paroimi/a e)pi\ tw=n pa/sh| proqumi/a| xrwme/nwn. Cf. Eur. Med. 278 e)xqroi\ ga\r e)cia=si pa/nta dh\ ka/lwn, Ar. Eq. 756 nu=n dh/ se pa/nta dei= ka/lwn e)cie/nai seautou=, Zenobius v. 62.
ou)ri/a| e)fe/nta: Ovid Met. XV. 176 (Pythagoras speaks), et quoniam magno feror aequore plenaque ventis | vela dedi. e)fe/nta is intr., see on 336 a. —

pe/lagos: a freq. comparison. Cf. Rep. v. 453 d ou)kou=n kai\ h(mi=n neuste/on (must swim) kai\ peirate/on sw/|zesqai e)k tou= lo/gou, Symp. 210 d e)pi\ to\ polu\ pe/lagos tetramme/nos tou= kalou=, Polit. 273 d i(/na mh\ xeimasqei\s (tempest-tossed) ei)s to\n th=s a)nomoio/thtos a)/peiron u)/nta to/pon du/h|, Cic. Tusc. 4, 9 statimne nos vela facere, an quasi e porta egredientes paullulum remigare.

a)pokru/yanta: cause to disappear, lose from sight. Cf. Thuc. v. 65. 6 e)peidh\ e)kei=noi a)pe/kruyan (sc. au)tou/s), Luc. V. H. ii. 38 e)pei\ de\ a)pekru/yamen au)tou/s, Verg. Aen. iii. 291 protinus aërias Phaeacum abscondimus arces.
temei=n: freq. of the way, course, open, take, pursue (like Lat. secare). Cf. Polit. 262 b dia\ me/swn de\ a)sfale/steron i)e/nai te/mnontas, Legg. vii. 803 e kaqa/per o(doi\ te/tmhntai. —

w(/s: equiv. to ou(/tws, elsewhere in prose, only after w(s, w(/sper (see on 326 d); yet this use is also found in Thuc. iii. 37 w(\s ou)=n xrh\ kai\ h(ma=s poiou=ntas parainei=n. — The imperative force of the fut. ind. corresponds to the assumption and confidence of Hippias. —

r(abdou=xon: it was very appropriate for Hippias the Elean to multiply terms for the directors and judges of contests, and thus to embellish his discourse. The r(abdou=xoi or r(abdofo/roi are seen on all vases in pictures of gymnastic contests. On e)pista/ths and brabeuth/s cf. Legg. xii. 949 a kai\ gumnikw=n te kai\ i(ppikw=n a)/qlwn
e)pista/tas kai\ brabe/as. Finally pru/tanis, an old word, president, was also doubtless the proper name of the one who arranged the contests. These presidents were selected either by those who instituted the respective games, or by the combatants themselves. In Socrates's words which follow, these methods of selection run into each other.
te/: see on 325 b, 1. 27.
h(rh/setai: the fut. pf. with temporal aug. is very rare.
a)lla\ dh/: introduces objections raised by others, like the Lat. at. Cf. Apol. 37 c a)lla\ dh\ fugh=s timh/somai; Crito 54 a a)lla\ dh\ tw=n pai/dwn e(/neka bou/lei zh=n;

a)du/naton u(mi=n: sc. ai(rei=sqai belti/ona h(mw=n, from which then naturally w(/ste . . . e(le/sqai would result. In other cases w(/ste at times immediately follows e)/sti, dunato/s, i(kano/s. Cf. Lys. xx. 24 u(mi=n d' ou)k h)=n, w(/st) ei)de/nai, Plato Phaedr. 269 d to\ du/nasqai w(/ste a)gwnisth\n te/leon gene/sqai, Polit. 295 a i(kano\s w(/ste dia\ bi/ou prosta/ttein.
to/ g' e)mo/n: for my part, so far as I am concerned. Frequent in Plato. Cf. Soph. 237 b to\ me\n e)mo\n o(/ph| bou/lei ti/qeso.

lo/gon u(posxe/tw: render account, i.e. defend his position. Cf. Gorg. 465 a tou/twn de\ pe/ri ei) a)mfisbhtei=s, e)qe/lw u(posxei=n lo/gon, Xen. Mem. iv. 4. 9 a)rkei= ga\r o(/ti tw=n a)/llwn katagela=|s (for it is enough for you that you ridicule the others) e)rwtw=n me\n kai\ e)le/gxwn pa/ntas, au)to\s d' ou)deni\ qe/lwn u(pe/xein lo/gon.
diafqei/rein: cf. 360 a, Symp. 174 b i(/na kai\ th\n paroimi/an diafqei/rwmen metaba/llontes that we may spoil the proverb by changing it.
e)do/kei pa=sin: they offered a facile acquiescence, cf. tau=ta h)/rese kte(. above.

h(gou=mai kte(.: the sophists were the first to make language the object of scientific examination and discussion. This was occasioned by, and in its turn promoted, the exegesis and criticism of the poets, who thus became the favorite theme of conversation in cultivated circles. This appears in Socrates's remarks in 347 c, and in the amusing scenes in Ar. Ran. 1099 ff. It was often, however, the sole aim of the sophists, through the pointing out of faults in form or contents, to exhibit their own superiority to these writers. Thus Protagoras censured the imv. in mh=nin a)/eide qea/, and the fem. form ou)lome/nhn (cf. Arist. Poet. 19, Soph. El. 14), and Hippias boasted his knowledge of the poets (cf. 347 a, Cic. de Or. iii. 127); see the dialogue Hipp. Mi. and Introd. p. 16 f. Isocrates says XII. 18 tine/s moi tw=n e)pithdei/wn e)/legon w(s e)n tw=| *lukei/w| sugkaqezo/menoi trei=s h)\ te/ttares tw=n a)gelai/wn (common sort of) sofistw=n kai\ pa/nta fasko/ntwn ei)de/nai diale/gointo peri/ te tw=n a)/llwn poihtw=n kai\ th=s *(hsio/dou kai\ th=s *(omh/rou poih/sews.
peri\ e)pw=n: this and also o)rqw=s were probably expressions characteristic of Protagoras, cf. 342 a. As to his o)rqoe/peia, so called in Phaedr, 267 c, see Introd. p. 4.

dielei=n: analyze, explain. Cf. 314 b diele/sqai, Hipp. Ma. 285 c a(\ su\ a)kribe/stata e)pi/stasai a)nqrw/pwn diairei=n, peri/ te gramma/twn duna/mews kai\ sullabw=n, Charm. 163 d kai\ ga\r *prodi/kou muri/a tina\ a)kh/koa peri\ o)noma/twn diairou=ntos. But in 340 a, 341 c it is distinguish.

nu=n dh/ : a)rti/ws h)\ mikro
 e)/mprosqen, Photius Lex. p. 305, 9. cf. Poll. i. 72, when used with an impf. (otherwise in 349 a). The contrast is marked, as here, by nu=n or nu=n de/, cf. 340 b nu=n dh\ ei)=pes . . . nu=n sko/pei, Legg. iii. 683 e h)\ nu=n dh\ me
 tou/tois perituxo/ntes toi=s lo/gois ou(/tw tau=t' e)ti/qemen, nu=n d) e)pilelh/smeqa or did we a little while ago, coming to these principles, lay them down thus, and now have we forgotten them? the comic poet Magnes (Meineke Com. Frag. ii. 10) ei)pe/ moi: nu=n dh\ me
 w)/mnus mh\ gegone/nai, nu=n de\ fh/|s; After the interruption, the contrast of the earlier with the later (nu=n e)/stai) could not be expressed by nu=n dialego/meqa (the reading of the Mss.).

pro\s *sko/pan: “in a poem in honor of Scopas.” The Scopadae, a princely family of Thessaly, allied with the Aleuadae, were dynasts in Crannon and Pharsalus. Of this family, Diactorides was among the suitors for the daughter of Clisthenes in Sicyon (Hdt. vi. 127), and a Scopas, according to Diogenes Laërtius, ii. 25, invited Socrates to his residence. Simonides, as Gorgias at a later day, was often the guest of the Scopadae, and composed several poems in their honor. These included an epinician ode (in which he celebrated the Dioscuri, Cic. de Or. ii. 86, Quint. xi. 2. 11 ff.), the poem before us (whether an epinician ode or a scolion see Introd. p. 19), and a threnos when a great part of the family perished, at a triumphal feast, by the fall of the roof of the banqueting hall (Bergk Poet. Lyr. iii. 384^{4}). To meet the a)popi/a, the criticism of Protagoras, several answers are now ready; namely, the first attempted explanation by Socrates, the one by Prodicus, the second by Socrates, and the barely intended one by Hippias. See Introd. pp. 11 f.

tetra/gwnon: firm and unchange- able, perfect. This meaning is derived from the use of the Pythagoreans, with whom the number four (tetraktu/s) and the square were symbols of the permanent, perfect, divine. Cf. dokei= de\ kai\ toi=s *puqagorei/ois (sc. to\ tetra/gwnon) ei)ko/na fe/rein th=s qei/as
ou)si/as (the image of the divine nature) Proclus on Euclidis Elem. p. 48 G, Boeckh Philolaus, 155. When tetra/gwnos occurs later in the sense of our passage, it is a play on the verse of Simonides. So Arist. Rhet. iii. II to\n a)gaqo\n a)/ndra fa/nai ei)=nai tetra/gwnon metafora/: a)/mfw ga\r te/leia. Somewhat differently Varro (Pliny N. H. 34. 19) calls the figures (signa) of Polycletus quadrata, in contrast to those of Lysippus. Cf. in quadrum redigere.

memelhko/s: cf. Soph. 227 a th=| tw=n lo/gwn meqo/dw| spoggistikh=s h)\ farmakoposi/as ou)de\n h(=tton ou)de/ ti ma=llon tugxa/nei me/lon the dialectical art concerns itself neither less nor more with the use of the sponge than with the taking of physic. — The usual impers. const. of me/lei is retained in the partic. with tugxa/nei.
dokei= de/ soi kte(.: this then is the e)rw/thma peri\ a)reth=s proposed above.
o(/ra: sc. ei) dokei= kalw=s te kai\ o)rqw=s pepoih=sqai.

ne/metai: equiv. to nomi/zetai. Cf. Soph. O. T. 1080 e)gw\ d' e)mauto
 pai=da th=s *tu/xhs ne/mwn, Tr. 483 ei)/ ti th/nd' a(marti/an ne/meis. Thus in prose form, ou)d' u(p) e)mou= nomi/zetai tou=to para\ *pittakou= kai/per sofou= o)/ntos a)ndro\s e)mmelw=s (321 c) ei)rh=sqai: xalepo
 e)sqlo
 e)/mmenai. — According to Didymus, in the Schol. on Plato ii. 369 Bk., Pittacus, the ruler of Mytilene, uttered the famous saying, on hearing that Periander, formerly mild and a friend of the people, had become cruel. With Solon's saying, xalepa\ ta\ kala/, which Plato frequently quotes, cf. Zenobius vi. 38. — Simonides was fond of quoting the expressions of others, as of Homer and Stesichorus, Frag. 25 Schn., 53 Bgk.; of Homer, Frag. 60 Schn., 85 Bgk.; of Hesiod, Frag. 32 Schn., 58 Bgk., or of combating them, as he said of a thought of Cleobulus of Lindus (Frag. 10 Schn., 57 Bgk.)
mwrou= fwto\s a(/de boula/. So Pindar, P. iv. 277 and elsewhere, appealed to Homer.

o(mologei=sqai, o(mologei=n: of persons o(mologei=n tini, of things o(mologei=sqai/ tini. Cf. Crat. 416 a kai\ touto ga\r toi=s e)/mprosqen o(mologei=tai, Rep. v. 457 c to\n lo/gon au)to\n au(tw=| o(mologei=sqai.
e)fobou/mhn . . . le/goi: I was afraid there was something in what he said.
o(/s ge: qui quidem, cf. 348 e, 1. 13. See H. 1037, 1.
u(pe/qeto: strictly, lay down a principle in order to reason from it, then in general maintain. Cf. 361 b u(poqe/menos. Similarly 343 e u(peipo/nta, and 359 a u(pokeime/nwn.

ei)s to\ pro/sqen proelqw/n: freq. of a road or an investigation; so proi+e/nai. Cf. Legg. iii. 682 a ei)s dh\ to\ pro/sqen proe/lqwmen e)/ti tou= nu=n e)pelqo/ntos h(mi=n mu/qou, Symp. 174 d keleu/ein (*swkra/th) proi+e/nai ei)s to\ pro/sqen (forwards), Gorg. 497 a kai\ pro/i+qi/ ge e)/ti ei)s tou)/mprosqen, below, 357 d ei)s to\ pro/sqen e)/ti w(mologh/kate, Soph. 258 c ei)s to\ pro/sqen e)/ti zhth/santes.
to\ pro/teron: adv.
pare/sxe: called out.

w(sperei\ . . . plhgei/s: a contest of opinions is often compared to a boxing match, in which stunning blows would be received in the face. Cf. Euthyd. 303 a e)gw\ me\n ou)=n w(/sper plhgei\s u(po\ tou= lo/gou e)kei/mhn a)/fwnos, Phil. 22 e e)/moige dokei= nu=n h(donh/ soi peptwke/nai kaqaperei\ plhgei=sa u(po\ tw=n nu=n dh\ lo/gwn.
i)liggi/asa: cf. Gorg. 486 b i)liggiw/|hs a)\n kai\ xasmw=|o (gape) ou)k e)/xwn o(/ ti ei)/pois, Lys. 216 c.
se/: i.e. the e(/tairos mentioned in the opening of the dialogue, cf. 309 a ff.
e)gge/nhtai: cf. Phaedo 86 e xro/nou e)ggenome/nou.—
le/goi: opt. after a historical present. See G. 201 Rem.

parakalei=n: usually dokw= moi (I am resolved) takes the inf. fut. (cf. Theaet. 183 d a)lla/ moi dokw= ou) pei/sesqai au)tw=|), but the pres. is also used (Pnaedr. 230 e e)gw\ me/n moi dokw= katakei=sqai I intend to lie down, Ar. Vesp. 177 a)ll' ei)siw/n moi to\n o)/non e)ca/gein dokw=). So here parakalei=n is to be taken as inf. pres. since the action referred to is close at hand. The appeal is repeated after the clause introduced by w(/sper.

Cf. Hom. *f 307 (*ska/mandros) *simo/enti de\ ke/klet' a)u/sas | ‘fi/le kasi/gnhte, sqe/nos a)ne/ros a)mfo/teroi/ per | sxw=men, e)pei\ ta/xa a)/stu me/ga *pria/moio a)/naktos | e)kpe/rsei.’ Hence the unusual expression to\n *simwni/dhn e)kpe/rsh| (cf. Soph. Tr. 1104 tuflh=s u(p' a)/ths e)kpepo/rqhmai ta/las, Lobeck on Aias 1198) and the preceding poliorkou/menon. This latter word is used figuratively in Rep. v. 453 a i(/na mh\ e)/rhma ta\ tou= e(te/rou lo/gou poliorkh=tai that the opposite view may not be besieged without defenders.
u(pe/r: Socrates's correction of the view of Protagoras will be at once a defence of Simonides.

mousikh=s: used at times by Plato of all intellectual effort and knowledge (cf. Rep. ii. 376 e mousikh=s d' ei)pw\n ti/qhs lo/gous but when you say this, do you include literature in music?), esp. poetry and philosophy (cf. Phaedo 61 a w(s filosofi/as me\n ou)/shs megi/sths mousikh=s). Here, somewhat sarcastically, it denotes the knowledge of synonyms, cf. 337 a ff.
diairei=s: Socrates had often heard Prodicus's expositions, see on 341 a, l. 15.

Const., o( *pittako\s to\ xalepo\n ou)k e)/lege tou=to, gene/sqai e)sqlo/n, a)lla\ to\ e)/mmenai, sc. e)sqlo/n. The inf. is used with equal freq. with and without the art. after this use of tou=to. Cf. also Gorg. 489 d pa/lai topa/zw toiou=to/n ti/ se le/gein to\ krei=tton.

Socrates ascribes this view only to Prodicus and others, not to himself, as he already has in mind his own later exposition. There is at the same time an allusion here to Prodicus's ‘Choice of Heracles’ in connection with which Xenophon also, Mem. ii. 1. 20, quotes the passage of Hesiod.

th=s ga kte(.: cf. Hes. *)/erga 287 ff. th
 me/n toi kako/thta kai\ i)lado
 (in abundance) e)/stin e(le/sqai | r(hidi/ws: lei/h me
 o(do/s, ma/la d' e)ggu/qi nai/ei. | th=s d' a)reth=s i(drw=ta qeoi\ propa/roiqen e)/qhkan | a)qa/natoi: makro\s de\ kai\ o)/rqios oi)=mos e)s au)th
 | kai\ trhxu\s to\ prw=ton: e)ph
 d' ei)s a)/kron i(/khtai, | r(hidi/h dh)/peita pe/lei, xaleph/ per e)ou=sa. The passage is cited also in Rep. ii. 364
c. Simonides himself had said (Frag. 32 Schn., 58 Bgk.) e)/sti tis lo/gos ta\n a)reta\n nai/ein dusamba/tois e)pi\ pe/trais.
e)kth=sqai: added by Plato (cf. 340 e) to explain r(hidi/hn. After vowels Plato uses kekth=sqai, after consonants both e)kth=sqai and kekth=sqai.

e)pano/rqwma: Socrates is making a defence of Simonides against attack, not a correction of error. His reply however ei)mi\ ... i)atro/s falls in with Protagoras's mei=zon a(ma/rthma kte(. Cf. a above.

kako/n: subst. (without ti\) as Gorg. 518 e kai\ su\ nu=n o(moio/taton tou/tw| e)rga/zei, or in the exclamation of those initiated in the Orphic-Bacchic mysteries (Dem. de Cor. 259), e)/fugon kako/n, eu(=ron a)/meinon, and in the common phrases, deino\n le/geis (Ar. Lysistr. 499), geloi=on pa/sxein (Rep. vii. 536 b) etc.
moi/: for the dat. of the agent, see G. 188, 3; H. 769.

i)w/menos . . . poiw=: the expression was proverbial, mh\ kako
 kakw=| i)a/sasqai. Cf. Hdt. iii. 53 mh\ tw=| kakw=| to\ kako
 i)w=, Thuc. v. 65 e)pebo/hsen o(/ti dianoei=tai kako
 kakw=| i)a=sqai, Soph. Aj. 362 mh\ kako
 kakw=| didou\s | a)/kos ple/on to\ ph=ma th=s a)/ths ti/qei do not, adding ill as a remedy to ill, make the woe of thy calamity the greater, the comic poet in Plut. Mor. 523 e to\ fa/rmako/n sou th
 no/son mei/zw poiei=. The const. is an ‘epexegetic asyndeton,’ as in 339 e di/kaios ei)=, 343 d a)mfisbhtou=nta, 343 e ei)po/nta . . . a)pokrino/menon, 348 a kataqeme/nous poiei=sqai.

pollh\ a)\n a)maqi/a ei)/h kte(.: it seemed not to occur to Protagoras, although believing a)ndri\ paidei/as me/- giston me/ros ei)=nai peri\ e)pw=n deino\n ei)=nai (cf. 339 a), to consider the argument of the poem as a whole, or to refute Socrates by a critical examination and comparison of its parts. Nor again did he cite other passages from his favorite poet, to establish the doctrine of the latter respecting virtue.
