His method here is the same which he uses elsewhere, cf. 324 a au)to/ se dida/cei and o(/stis mh\ w(/sper qhri/on a)logi/stws timwrei=tai, where, without any scientific treatment of the doctrine of punishment, he falls back upon ‘common sense.’ This mode of exegesis proved, as it has often done since, to be unsafe, when placed in the hands of an opponent.
qei/a: cf. 315 e, l. 26.
pa/lai: alludes ironically to Protagoras's claim that the sophist's art was of great antiquity, 316 d. Socrates says that Simonides, like Prodicus, had distinguished synonyms (gene/sqai, e)/mmenai).

e)/mpeiros: sc. ei)mi/, for with ou)x w(/sper (in the sense of while) the clause with w(/sper is always formed independently, preceded by simply ou)x, while the pred. of the clause with ou)x, (here e)/mpeiros ei)=nai) is supplied from that with w(/sper. Cf. Symp. 179 e ou)x (sc. e)ti/mhsan) w(/sper *)axille/a e)ti/mhsan kai\ ei)s maka/rwn nh/sous a)pe/pemyan, 189 c ou)x (sc. ou)de
 a)
 e)gi/gneto) w(/sper nu=n tou/twn ou)de
 gi/gnetai peri\ au)to/n it would not be as now, when none of these things is done for him.—Socrates calls himself a pupil of Prodicus also in Crat. 384 b, Meno 96 d, Charm. 163 d, always with special reference to the synonymic art, yet never without implied ridicule of the consequential pedantry with which Prodicus treated his doctrine. Here Soccrates makes sport of him and his hobby, by first alluring him to the explanation of xalepo/n by kako/n, and then suggesting that Prodicus did this in jest and for the sake of testing Protagoras.

w(/sper: should have been followed by ou(/tw kai\ to\ xalepo\n au)= oi( *kei=oi kte(., but this is postponed by the intervention at some length of the views of Prodicus upon deino/s. Here the clause o(/tan . . . le/gw, as though its main verb (nouqetei=) had not already preceded, is followed by another principal verb (e)rwta=|), and then, instead of the expected and postponed clause ou(/tw kai\ to\ xalepo\n kte(., the clause i)/sws ou)=n kte(. is added with anacoluthon. This intervention of a dependent clause between two main clauses is found also in Homer. Cf. also Plato Theaet. 172 d tou\s lo/gous e)pi\ sxolh=s poiou=ntai, w(/sper h(mei=s nuni\ tri/ton h)/dh lo/gon e)k lo/gou metalamba/nomen, ou(/tw ka)kei=noi they follow out their reasonings at their leisure, just as we now have taken up a third point, one following naturally from another; so they, etc.

sofo\s kai\ deino/s: cf. Theaet. 154 d ei) me\n deinoi\ kai\ sofoi\ e)gw/ te kai\ su\ h)=men, 173 b deinoi/ te kai\ sofoi\ gegono/tes, w(s oi)/ontai, Ar. Ran. 967 *qhrame/nhs; sofo/s g) a)nh\r kai\ deino\s ei)s ta\ pa/nta, and frequently thus. On account of its derivation, Prodicus will not allow the use of deino/s as a word of commendation (cf. colloquial parallels in Eng.); but his theory makes itself ridiculous in thus opposing the living language.

deinou= plou/tou kte(.: cf. Euthyd. 303 a puppa\c w)= *(hra/kleis kalou= lo/gou, Rep. vi. 509 c *)/apollon, daimoni/as u(per-
bolh=s. For the gen. of exclam., see G. 173, 3; H. 761.
fwnh/n: dialect; so below, l. 36 e)n fwnh=| barba/rw|, and 346 d, l. 61. Cf. Phaedo 62 a *)/ittw *zeu/s, e)/fh, th=| au(tou= fwnh=| ei)pw/n (Cebes was a Boeotian).
diairei=n: this was just Prodicus's art. Cf. 340 a.

barba/rw|: the Aeolic dialect might, in the time of Socrates and Plato, sound so strange to the Athenians, as to be termed, from an exclusive pride in the Attic literary style, ba/rbaros. Cf. Eust. on the Il., p. 279. 36 e)kwmw|dou=nto (were ridiculed) de/, fasi/n, oi( *)eretriei=s w(s pollw=| tw=| r_ e)n tai=s o(mili/ais xrw/menoi. dio\ kai\ au)toi/, kaqa\ kai\ *)hlei=oi, barbaro/fwnoi e)kalou=nto, w(s e)n r(htorikw=| eu(/rhtai lecikw=|. In the Cratylus, words and forms of the Aeolic and Doric dialects are often called cenika/, i.e. 401 b. This judgment might without improbability be ascribed to Prodicus, who naturally spoke Attic, and to Simonides, whose language varied little from the Attic.
e)gw\ eu)= oi)=d' o(/ti kte(.: here again Protagoras leaves it for Socrates to refute this interpretation by citing other words from the poem. See below.
sou=: for the prolepsis, see on 313 b, l. 19.

dokei=n: redundant, as though oi)=mai had not preceded, although it depends upon the latter. Cf. Soph. 225 d dokw= mh
 to/ ge a)mele\s tw=n oi)kei/wn (the neglect of one's own affairs) gigno/menon kalei=sqai kata\ gnw/mhn th
 e)mh
 ou)x e(/teron a)dolesxikou= (nothing else than garrulity); in Parm. 165 c the expression tau)to
 fai/nesqai peponqe/nai depends upon the preceding do/cei, Xen. Hell. vii. 4. 35 e)no/mizon tw=| qew=| oi)/esqai ma=llon a)
 ou(/tw xari/zesqai they thought they would thus the rather please the god.
ou) dh/pou: belongs to the whole following sent. with its internal contradiction emphasized by ei)=ta.—

ei)=ta: see on 319 d, l. 26. The thought of Socrates is, that Simonides cannot first say that it is evil to be good, and then characterize this as a prerogative solely of the gods. Here it is immaterial whether Simonides gives his own thought or only quotes Pittacus.

tou=to ge/ras: 344 c reads qeo\s a)\n mo/nos tou=to e)/xoi to\ ge/ras, but in the passage before us ge/ras is pred. Cf. Symp. 179 c eu)ariqh/tois dh/ tisin e)/dosan tou=to ge/ras oi( qeoi/, Apol. 18 a dikastou= me\n ga\r au(/th a)reth/, Ar. Eccl. 658 ka)gw\ tau/thn gnw/mhn e)qe/mhn.

*kei=on: the people of Ceos were renowned for the vigor and purity of their morals (Brönsted Reisen in Griechenland, i. 63 ff., Bursian, Geog. v. Griech. ii. 469 f.). In Legg. i. 638 b, the subjection of the Ceians by the Athenians is cited as an illustration of the fact that victory and virtue often lie with opposite camps.

ei) bou/lei labei=n kte(.: Socrates now delivers a discourse of considerable length; but the subject excludes the brevity of question and answer, and moreover he does this with the assent of Protagoras and upon the urgent request of the others (e)keleue/thn pa/nu).
o(\ su\ le/geis tou=to: cf. 338 e as you suggest. Similarly Gorg. 514 e to\ lego/menon dh\ tou=to.

Prodicus and Hippias unite in strongly urging Socrates, perhaps because they hope he will humble their rival.
The reflections of the seven wise men upon government and morals, and their efforts to regulate these, were expressed in sententious proverbs. This tendency to put their thoughts into pithy, striking sentences was a characteristic also of the vigorous Spartans. (Plut. *)apofqe/gmata lakwnika/ ii. 208 b ff.). Socrates makes use of this, by a keen stroke of wit, to surpass the paradoxical description of Protagoras (316 d),—to which he had already given a thrust (341 a),—by one still more paradoxical, in describing Crete and Lacedaemon, which were in fact strangers to all learning, as the most ancient seats of philosophy. This is also a hit at the imitators of the Spartans.

gh=s: Sauppe construes this with e)kei=, citing o(/pou gh=s Rep. iii. 403 e, gh=s ou)damou= ix. 592 a, ou(= gh=s Menex. 235 c, and declaring that to connect it with plei=stoi is against the usus loquendi. Still, this latter const. seems a very natural sequence and climax to plei/sth tw=n *(ellh/nwn, and is maintained by Stallbaum, Kroschel, and Deuschle, and given in Kr. Spr. 47, 28, 7, where this passage is cited.
sxhmati/zontai: cf. Soph. 268 a w(s a)gnoei= tau=ta, a(\ pro\s tou\s a)/llous w(s ei)dw\s e)sxhma/tistai (he has pretended to know), Tim. Lex. sxhmatizo/menos: prospoiou/menos h)\ suntatto/menos.

tou\s sofista/s: for the incorporation and assimilation of the antec., see G. 154; H. 995. (The article in such cases is more commonly dropped.) Cf. 359 d e)n oi(=s su/ e)/leges toi=s lo/gois, Phaedo 66 e to/te h(mi=n e)/stai ou(= e)piqumou=men fronh/sews, Rep. iii. 402 c ou)/te au)toi\ ou)/te ou(/s famen h(mi=n paideute/on ei)=nai tou\s fu/lakas neither we, nor the guardians whom we say we have to educate.
e)chpath/kasi: a humorous reference to Protagoras's description in 316

Many Athenians, who hated the democracy and bewailed the decay of morals, hoped to improve matters by an imitation of Spartan ways, and, as usually happens, copied them only externally. They made themselves conspicuous by stern looks, a mustache, a staff and short cloak, and engaged in gymnastics to such an excess, that, contrary to the law of Sparta, they zealously practised boxing. Cf. Ar. Av. 1281 e)lakwnoma/noun a(/pantes a(/nqrwpoi to/te, e)ko/mwn, e)pei/nwn, e)rru/pwn e)swkra/twn all men then had a Laconomania; they wore their hair long, went hungry and dirty, acted like Socrates, Dem. LIV. 34 oi(\ meq' h(me/ran me\n e)skuqrwpa/kasi kai\ lakwni/zein fasi\ kai\ tri/bwnas e)/xousi kai\ a(pla=s u(pode/dentai who during the day look gloomy and say they live in the Spartan style, wear short cloaks and single-soled shoes, Plut. Phoc. 10 h)=n de/ tis *)arxibia/dhs e)pikalou/menos *lakwnisth/s, pw/gwna/ te kaqeime/nos u(perfuh= mege/qei (wearing a beard of monstrous size) kai\ tri/bwna forw=n a)ei\ kai\ skuqrwpa/zwn. The same fashion prevailed also, as it seems (e)n tai=s po/lesi), in other cities.

w)=ta kata/gnuntai: the ears of the boxers bore the marks of the fists covered with thongs (caestus), cf. Gorg. 515 e tw=n ta\ w)=ta kateago/twn (sc. tw=n *lakwnistw=n). Hence the name w)t<*>ka/tacis a boxer with ears battered by the caestus, which Bekk. Anecd. 116, 32 and Poll. ii. 83 quote from Aristophanes.

a)nabola/s: the Spartans wore, without any chiton, a very short cloak of coarse stuff, often threadbare (tri/bwn); the Cynics also adopted this from Socrates, and it became later the usual philosophic dress. From its being thrown about the shoulders, in which manner of wearing it an artistic effect was sought (cf. e)pide/cia a)naba/llesqai Theaet. 175 e), the cloak was called a)nabolh/.
w(s kratou=ntas: for the acc. abs., see G. 278, 2, N; H. 974.
w(s dh/: scilicet.
cenhlasi/as: Pericles says in Thuc. i. 144 h)\n kai\ *lakedaimo/nioi cenhlasi/as mh\ poiw=si mh/te h(mw=n mh/te tw=n h(mete/rwn summa/xwn. Schömann Gr. Alt. i. 291^{3} f.

ou)de/na e)w=si: cf. Aristotle (in Harpocr. p. 166, 12 Ddf.) ou)k e)cei=nai/ fhsin a)podhmei=n toi=s *lakedaimoni/ois, o(/pws mh\ e)qi/zwntai a)/llwn no/mwn ei)=nai fi/loi. Laws of this kind are laid down also for the ideal state in Legg.
xii. 950 d f.—This is the only passage which states the same fact regarding Crete, but the agreement of Spartan and Cretan customs is well known.
e)n tau/tais tai=s po/lesi: i.e. in Lacedaemon and the Cretan cities.

gunai=kes: training and custom made the women in Sparta more nearly equal to the men than elsewhere, and their crisp, spirited sayings also were quoted; as of the mother who handed her son his shield, with the words te/knon h)\ ta\n h)\ e)pi\ ta=s, cf. Plut. ii. 240 b ff., *lakainw=n a)pofqe/gmata.
ei) ga\r e)qe/lei kte(.: cf. 324 a, l. 20.

ta\ me\n polla/: K. F. Hermann reads ta\ me\n prw=ta, but not at first simply, but in general, the conversation of the Spartan is plain and unpretending, and only occasionally does his keenness dart forth.
o(/pou . . . legome/nwn: “wherever in the conversation it may chance,” i.e. “at some unexpected point in the conversation.”

e)ne/bale: the aor. here expresses the action as occurring suddenly and all at once. Cf.Rep.X. 609 a ou)kou=n o(/tan tw/| ti tou/twn prosge/nhtai, ponhro/n te poiei= w(=| prosege/neto, kai\ teleutw=n o(/lon die/luse kai\ a)pw/lese whenever therefore one of these infects anything, it makes the thing infected evil, and finally wholly destroys it, Symp. 188 b (*)/erws) diafqei/rei te polla\ kai\ h)di/khsen. For the gnomic aor., see G. 205, 2; H. 840.—The comparing of words to darts is not infrequent, cf. Symp. 219 b e)gw\ tau=ta ei)pw/n, kai\ a)fei\s w(/sper be/lh, tetrw=sqai au)to\n w)/|mhn, Hor. Sat. i. 4. 79 unde petitum hoc in me jacis?
sunestramme/non: (opp. to lelume/non) twisted together, like a bowstring, where a slight distension gives great force, concise, pithy. Cf. contorta oratio, compressione rerum brevis (Cic. Brut. 29).

The memory of Myson early became obscure, and Plato alone numbers him with the seven, although Hipponax (Frag. 45 Bgk.) said kai\ *mu/swn, o(\n w(po/llwn a)nei=pen a)ndrw=n swfrone/staton pa/ntwn. It was not certainly known whether he was a native of Etis in Crete, or Chenae on Mt. Oeta, or Chen in Laconia. That Plato did not regard him as a Lacedaemonian, but as a Malian from Chenae, is clear from the following *lakedaimo/nios.
toiau/thn: defined by r(h/mata... ei)rhme/na.

a)ne/qesan kte(.: upon pillars of the pronaos of the Delphic temple were engraved sayings (Paus. X. 24. 1) ascribed by Grecian legend to the seven Sages, and the same spirit pervaded the teaching of Apollo and the wisdom of the Seven (Zeller Philosophie der Griechen i. 82 f.). According to Plutarch Mor. 385

f, five of them dedicated to Apollo an E (i.e. ei)=, thou art). Diodorus (ix. 9, Ddf.) relates of Chilon, kaqa/per a)parxa\s poiou/menos tw=| qew=| th=s i)di/as sune/sews e)pe/grayen e)pi/ tina ki/ona tri/a tau=ta: ‘gnw=qi seauto/n,’ kai\ ‘mhde\n a)/gan,’ kai\ tri/ton ‘e)ggu/a, pa/ra d' a)/ta.’
u(mnou=si: see on 317 a.

tou= dh\ . . . le/gw; Plato likes to enliven his discourse by such questions. Cf. Gorg. 457 e for this same phrase; Meno 97 e pro\s ti/ ou)=n dh\ le/gw tau=ta; Phaedr. 235 c po/qen dh\ tekmairo/menos le/gw; Symp. 178 d le/gw de\ dh\ ti/ tou=to; Apol. 40 b ti/ ou)=n ai)/tion ei)=nai u(polamba/nw. So frequently in Demosthenes.
o(/ti: not because, but “in order to show that.”

o( tro/pos th=s filosofi/as: these words form together a single conception, upon which tw=n palaiw=n, emphasized by its position, depends. Similarly 345 a h( th=s qerapei/as ma/qhsis. On the other hand, Rep. i. 329 b e)/nioi de\ kai\ ta\s tw=n oi)kei/wn prophlaki/seis (contumelious treatment) tou= gh/rws o)du/rontai, the words ta\s prophlaki/seis tou= gh/rws are to be connected, and tw=n oi)kei/wn depends upon them.
i)di/a|: in particular.
a(/te filo/timos w)/n: this, as well as w(/sper . . . a)qlh/thn below, contains a hit at Protagoras. Cf. 335 a.
kaqe/loi: cf. 344 c. So Theocritus xxii. 115 says of Polydeuces, who has vanquished Amycus in a boxing match, pw=s d' a)\r dh\ *dio\s ui(o\s a)dhfa/gon (gluttonous) a)/ndra kaqei=len;
tou=tw|: some take as depending upon e)pibouleu/wn, anticipating kolou=sai au)to/, but it is dat. of means, “through the making of the poem.”

e)pibouleu/wn: with the inf. means endeavor stealthily, plan to do a thing unobserved. Cf. Symp. 203 b h( *peni/a e)pibouleu/ousa paidi/on poih/sasqai, Rep. viii. 566 b biai/w| dh\ qana/tw| e)pibouleu/ousin a)poktinnu/nai la/qra| (to\n tu/rannon).

kolou=sai: often has something exalted as its obj., cf. Hdt. vii. 10. 5 file/ei ga\r o( qeo\s ta\ u(pere/xonta kolou/ein.—Protagoras, professing to adhere to the ethical question raised by Socrates, while merely changing its mode of treatment, has raised a wholly different one (cf. 339

a b). What Socrates thinks of the value of a discussion of the poets, he indicates below (cf. 347 e). Now, therefore, meeting Protagoras on his own ground, and assuming that in the examination of Simonides's poem a discussion of virtue is the real end, he purposes to find the true doctrine in the poem; and, as the first step, discovers in it a polemic aim. If this is contrary to the view of Protagoras, the latter has full opportunity to refute it (see on 347 a).

ou)de\ . . . lo/gon: wholly without reason, with no purpose whatever. See on 328 a, 351 e. Cf. 344 a. —Simonides inserted me/n, which always involves an antithesis, which is found here, acc. to Socrates, between gene/sqai and e)/mmenai.
le/gontos tou= *pittakou= kte(.: epexegetical of pro\s to\ tou= *pittakou= kte(.; hence the asyndeton. See on 340 e.
gene/sqai me/n: should strictly have been followed by ei)=nai de/ or diame/nein de/ (cf. 344 b, 345 c), but it is followed in 344 a only by ou) ga\r ei)=nai kte(. with anacoluthon.

th\n a)lh/qeian: i.e. the word a)lhqw=s or a)lh/qeia. In Greek, as in Latin, words which are referred to merely as words, often conform to the const. of the sentence. Cf. 341 a peri\ tou= deinou=, and the freq. to\ xalepo/n.

This style of exegesis should commend itself to Protagoras, for Socrates has borrowed it from him. See on 340 e. “To be sure, the position of the words would naturally lead one to construe a)laqe/ws with a)gaqo/n, but this distinction of two kinds of a)gaqo/s would indicate a false view, and therefore be unworthy of Simonides.” To make Simonides say, therefore, what it is manifest to Socrates that he should say, is readily accomplished by the convenient change which follows. The argument is ironical.

u(perbato/n: occurs here for the first time in the familiar grammatical sense. It is found also in Anaxim. Rhet. 30 (p. 60, 24 Sp.) (safw=s dhlw/somen) a)po\ tw=n o)noma/twn, e)a\n mh\ u(perbatw=s au)ta\ tiqw=men, a)ll' a)ei\ ta\ e)xo/mena e(ch=s ta/ttwmen, [Longin.] peri\ u(/yous, chap. 22 th=s de\ au)th=s i)de/as kai\ ta\ u(perbata\ qete/on: e)/sti de\ le/cewn h)\ noh/sewn e)k tou= kat' a)kolouqi/an kekinhme/nh ta/cis (an arrangement varying from the regular order). Here, however, u(perbato/n is an adj., and qei=nai is consider, assume, as qei=men following.

u(peipo/nta: premise as a startingpoint, see on 339 d. Cf. Ar. Vesp. 54 f. fe/re nun katei/pw toi=s qeatai=s to
 lo/gon, o)li/g' a)/tq) u(peipw
 prw=ton au)toi=sin tadi/ come now, let me declare the argument to the audience, first premising to them some few matters as follows, Dem. de Cor. 60 tou/twn u(fe/cw lo/gon, tosou=ton u(peipw/n, XXIII. 53 ge/grafen, ou)de
 u(peipw/n, o(/pws a)/n tis a)poktei/nh|, th
 timwri/an he has proposed private vengeance, without premising under what circumstances one may kill justifiably.
ei)po/nta: repeats le/gonta above, without to\n me/n. See on 330 a.
me/n: so placed after the preceding ei)=nai that the force of mh/n, in which it originated, still rings in it. Cf. 361 e tw=n me\n thlikou/twn.
pro\s lo/gon: with reason, coordinate with o)rqw=s. See on 351 e, l. 25.

tu/pon: form, general plan, freq. contrasted with exact description. Cf. Rep. iii. 414 a w(s e)n tu/pw|, mh\ di) a)kribei/as, ei)rh=sqai to speak generally, without aiming at exactness, Phil. 61 a to\ toi/nun a)gaqo\n h)/toi safw=s, h)\ kai/ tina tu/pon au)tou= lhpte/on then we must apprehend the good clearly, or at least get some general idea of it.
e)/legxos: pred., the subj. being h( bou/lhsis.

le/gei ga/r: refers to the words already quoted 339 c ou)de/ moi e)mmele/ws . . . e)/mmenai, for after these came immediately, acc. to 341 e, qeo\s a)\n mo/nos tou=t' e)/xoi ge/ras, and then, evidently, the words a)/ndra d' ou)k e)/sti kte(. Consequently o)li/ga dielqw/n can refer only to the lost lines which stood between the opening words a)/ndr' a)gaqo\n . . . tetugme/non and the words ou)de/ moi e)mmele/ws. Protagoras refers to the same lines, when he says in 339 d o)li/gon de\ tou= poih/matos ei)s to\ pro/sqen proelqw/n.—

w(s a)\n ei) le/goi lo/gon: in order to make clear that which the poet has said, it is converted into periodic prose. For the same purpose, after using the words o)li/ga dielqw/n, Socrates starts anew with the opening of the poem.
w)= *pittake/: shows that dir. disc. follows o(/ti.

mh\ ou) . . . e)/mmenai: for the double neg. after ou)k e)/sti, see G. 263, 1, N.; H. 1034. See on 352 d.—Socrates for the present passes unnoticed the use of e)/mmenai instead of gene/sqai, a distinction which Simonides had not at all in mind. The true thought of the poet, Socrates gives in e below.
kaqe/lh|: cf. 343 c.

One is tempted to ascribe e)n ploi/ou a)rxh=| to Simonides, but cf. in 344 e the introduction of ei)s gra/mmata as an illustrative example, without oi(=on or other indication that it is Socrates's illustration.

i)diw/thn: on the doctrine that the change to a condition presupposes the opposite condition, assumed in this argument of Socrates, cf. Phaedo 70 e a)nagkai=on o(/sois e)/sti ti e)nanti/on, mhdamo/qen a)/lloqen au)to\ gi/gnesqai h)\ e)k tou= au)tw=| e)nanti/ou it is necessary that whatever thing has an opposite be generated from no other source than from that opposite.
pote/: to be connected with kataba/loi, and then with kaqe/loi. Cf. 345 a f.

to\n de\ kei/menon ou)/: repeats for emphasis what had already been said before a)lla/. Cf. Parm. 155 d e)peidh\ de\ xro/nou mete/xei to\ e(/n (since the one partakes of time), a)=r' ou)k a)na/gkh kai\ tou= pote\ (the past) mete/xein kai\ tou= e)/peita (the future) kai\ tou= nu=n, ei)/ per xro/nou mete/xei; Gorg. 521 d ou) pro\s xa/rin le/gwn a)lla\ pro\s to\ be/ltiston, ou) pro\s to\ h(/diston.
17 tau)ta\ tau=ta: in this same way. Cf. Meno 90 d, tau)to\ tou=to Symp. 178 e and frequently.
gene/sqai: see on c above. Cf. also e and 345
a b below.

a)/llou poihtou=: Xen. Mem. i. 2. 20 quotes the verse without naming
the author. Perhaps it was an elegiac poet; in any case the poem had a gnomic character. Sophocles knew the verse, since, in Ant. 365, he makes the Chorus say, sofo/n ti to\ mhxano/en | te/xnas u(pe\r e)lpi/d' e)/xwn | pote\ me\n kako/n, a)/llot' e)p) e)sqlo\n e(/rpei one having inventive skill in a remarkable degree, beyond what one would expect, now falls into disaster, again attains to prosperity. See Bergk Poet. Lyr. iii. 735^{4}.

sofo/n, a)gaqo/n: in this whole exegesis Socrates keeps in view his main argument. Here, as developing eu)mh/xanon, sofo/n is inserted as the characteristic mark of true excellence, and a)gaqo/n in order to emphasize the contrast with the predicate.

to\ de/: strictly in relation to this however, then in fact however, whereas. Very frequent in Plato. Cf. Apol. 23 a oi)/ontai ga/r me au)to\n ei)=nai sofo/n: to\ de\ kinduneu/ei tw=| o)/nti o( qeo\s sofo\s ei)=nai.

pra/cas: “according as any man has done good or bad deeds, is he reckoned a good or a bad man.” An uninterrupted being is not required as the basis of the judgment. Socrates, however, going beyond the meaning of the poet, applies the word to the inward condition, eu)= pra/ttei one fares well, kakw=s pra/ttei one fares ill, and thus is able to push the inquiry as to the cause of this good or ill condition.
me/n: does not fit into the metrical scheme (see Introd. p. 18), but Attic usage allows its insertion here by Socrates in order to bring out the thought more clearly.
ei): sc. e)/prace.
h( ... ma/qhsis: see on 343 b, l. 47. Here Socrates finds his doctrine, that virtue is knowledge.

kako\s de\ kakw=s: (sc. pra/cas). Socrates follows the sense, repeating the words of the poet in order to explain them. So he says also to\ ge/ras 344 c, while Simonides (341 e) has ge/ras, and e)carkei= a)/n 346 d for e)carkei= o(\s a)/n 346 c.
kakw=s pra/cantes: not attrib. of i)atroi/, which would require pra/ttontes, and o(/stis ga/r instead of o(/stis de/ following, but circumstantial partic. of means with a)\n genoi/meqa.

a)/n: keeps in view the fact that the prot. o(/stis mh\ ge/noito has just been reached as an apod. The first statement is h(mei=s, kakw=s pra/cantes, ou)k a)\n i)atroi\ genoi/meqa. Then, starting again with this result, and selecting a single case, we have o(/stis (equiv. to ei)/ tis) mh\ i)atro\s a)\n ge/noito kte(. See GMT. 63, 2.
au(/th ga\r kte(.: the causes of the deterioration which are here mentioned are all of such a sort that loss of knowledge is occasioned by them. See on 344 e, l. 23.

diatelou=nta: is sometimes joined with an adj. without w)/n (Isocr. II. 4, Isae. VIII. 44, not so elsewhere in Plato). Here, however, after ei)=nai a)gaqo/n, the a)gaqo/n is simply repeated, in order to add the further limitation diatelou=nta (that is, permanently good). Hence o)/nta would be out of place.

e)pi\ plei=ston: contrasted with diatelou=nta means for the longest time. Cf. Thuc. i. 2. 2 th\n gou=n *)attikh\n e)k tou= e)pi\ plei=ston (from the remotest period) a)/nqrwpoi w)/|koun oi( au)toi\ a)ei/, vi. 54. 5 kai\ e)peth/deusan e)pi\ plei=ston dh\ tu/rannoi ou(=toi a)reth/n and these for the longest time as (i.e. longer than any other) tyrants practised virtue. So frequently in Thucydides e)pi\ polu/ is long. Cf. 328 d above.—That the words belong to the poet is evident from the loose connection with the preceding context and the abandon
ing of the dependent form.
kai/: connects e)pi\ plei=ston and a)/ristoi.

dhloi=: sc. pro\s to\n *pittako\n ei)rhme/na. dhlo/w is often const. like dh=lo/s ei)mi, taking the nom. of the partic. This case is similar, the partic. being supplied. Cf. Soph. Ant. 20 dhloi=s ga/r ti kalxai/nous' e)/pos for you are evidently distressed at something, ib. 242 dhloi=s d' w(/s ti shmanw=n ne/on you plainly have some ill news to tell, Eur. Med. 548 dei/cw sofo\s gegw/s, Isocr. XV. 5 e)dh/lwsan d' ou(/tw diakei/menoi. See G. 280; H. 981.
kenea/n: belongs by prolepsis to moi=ran ai)w=nos (like moi=ran bi/ou Soph. Ant. 896, the allotted portion of life).

e)s a)/prakton e)lpi/da bale/w: set upon the vain hope. Cf. Soph. Tr. 940 w(/s nin matai/ws ai)ti/a| ba/loi kakh=| that without ground he had laid a grievous charge upon her, Pind. P. ii. 35 eu)nai\ de\ para/tropoi e)s kako/tat' a)qro/an | e)/balon lawless unions plunge men into a sea of troubles.

pana/mwmon a)/nqrwpon: in appos. with to\ mh\ gene/sqai dunato/n. Similar is the thought of Phaedra's nurse, Eur. Hipp. 471 f. a)ll' ei) ta\ plei/w xrhsta\ tw=n kakw=n e)/xeis, | a)/nqrwpos ou)=sa ka/rta g' eu)= pra/ceias a)/n but if you have more things good than bad, mortal as you are, you surely must be well off. What follows is like Hom. Z 142 ei) de/ ti/s e)ssi brotw=n, oi(\ a)rou/rhs karpo\n e)/dousin, Hor. Od. ii. 14. 10 quicumque terrae munere vescimur.
e)pi\ dh/ min eu(rw/n: (i.e. e)feurw\n dh/ min) added humorously. Cf. 346 d.
fhsi/n: repeats the preceding fhsi\ ga/r.—
e)pece/rxetai... lang=greek>r(h/mati: persequitur et quasi hostiliter aggreditur. (Kroschel.)
e)pai/nhmi: see on 346 d.

The omission of a)/n with o(/stis and the subjv. is an old usage often followed by the poets. For the sing. referring to a pl. antec., cf. tou/tous o(\s a)/n below, also o(\s a)\n tou/twn e. See G. 151, N. 2, b; H. 609 a.

a)na/gkh| . . . ma/xontai: prover
bial. Cf. Legg. vii. 818 b a)ll' e)/oiken o( to
 qeo
 prw=ton paroimiasa/menos ei)s tau=ta a)poble/yas ei)pei=n (but it is likely that he who at first made the proverb about God had this in mind when he said), w(s ou)de\ qeo\s a)na/gkh| mh/pote fanh=| maxo/menos, Aesch. Prom. 515 ti/s ou)=n a)na/gkhs e)sti
 oi)akostro/fos (guide)? PROM. *moi=rai tri/morfoi mnh/mone/s t' *)erinu/es. CHO. tou/twn a)/ra *zeu/s e)stin a)sqene/steros; PROM. ou)/koun a)
 e)kfu/goi ge th
 peprwme/nhn (the appointed fate), cf. Gorg. 512 e.
This argument also is obviously ironical. a)na/gkh| above is clearly intended as the antithesis of e(kw/n, and the poet really expresses thus the thought which Socrates combats. See on 343 e, 344 e.

sxedo/n ti: pretty nearly; here a courteous softening of the assertion. “I am pretty sure.” Cf. Charm. 164 d sxedo\n ga/r ti e)/gwge au)to\ tou=to/ fhmi ei)=nai swfrosu/nhn, to\ gignw/skein e(auto/n. See on 348 c, l. 55.

e(ko/nta e)camarta/nein: this also (cf. 345 b) is a peculiarly Socratic thought, founded upon the principle that all morality rests upon knowledge. Cf. 352 d, 358 e, Gorg. 509 e h(ni/ka w(mologh/samen mhde/na boulo/menon a)dikei=n, a)ll' a)/kontas tou\s a)dikou=ntas pa/ntas a)dikei=n.
kai\ dh\ kai/: after a general statement lays marked stress on the special case which follows it. Cf. 348 e, Apol. 18 a. See H. 1042 c.
oi(=on: as, for example. For the inf. sumbh=nai following the rel. in indir. disc., see GMT. 92, 2, N. 3; H. 947.
mhte/ra: from Homer down (i 367 mh/thr h)de\ path\r h)d' a)/lloi pa/ntes e)tai=roi), in such enumerations mh/thr commonly stands first.

a)llo/koton: strange, perverse, unnatural. Cf. Rep. vi. 487 d tou\s me
 plei/stous kai\ pa/nu a)lloko/tous gignome/nous, i(/na mh\ pamponh/rous ei)/pwmen the most of them become very strange beings, not to call them utter rogues, Phryn. Bekk. Anecd. 15. 3 kuri/ws me
 ou)=n oi( to
 nou=n beblamme/noi kai\ e)/mplhktoi a)llo/kotoi kalou=ntai.
o(ra=n: depends upon h(gei=to.
a)melou=sin: (accuse them) of neglecting. Pred. partic. after e)gkalw=sin, of the class verba sentiendi et declarandi.
ma=llon: sc. h)\ kat' a)ci/an.
e)pikru/ptesqai, e)painei=n: although these verbs balance e)pideiknu/nai, kathgorei=n above, the former, e)pikru/ptesqai, has for its obj. th\n ponhri/an, the latter, tou\s gone/as h)\ th\n patri/da.

paramuqei=sqai: soothe. It depends, not upon a)nagka)zesqai, but upon h(gei=to, hence prosanagka/zontas is added. Cf. e)paine/sai below. In meaning, it is like alloqui (cf. Hor. Ep. 13. 18 deformis aegrimoniae dulcibus alloquiis). It also has the meanings encourage, console. Cf. Menex. 247 c pate/ras kai\ mhte/ras a)ei\ xrh\ paramuqei=sqai w(s r(a=|sta fe/rein th\n cumfora/n.

h(gh/sato: some have taken this in the sense of think fit or needful (formerly with the mistaken idea that dei=n was omitted), as Phil. 59 a ei)/te kai\ peri\ fu/sews h(gei=tai/ tis zhtei=n. This, however, would require the pres. inf.; the aor. inf. after h(gei=sqai and kindred verbs can denote only past time. Simonides therefore reflected on what he had already done. Yet the words of Pind. I. ii. 6 a( *moi=sa ga\r ou) filokerdh/s pw to/t' h)=n ou)d) e)rga/tis were generally understood as directed against Simonides for using his art to win money; this was his a)na/gkh. Cf. Schneidewin Simon. p. xxiv. f.
a)nagkazo/menos: i.e. by a large reward, as was the case also with the sophists.
tau=ta: see on 310 e.

a)pa/lamnos: base, wanton. Cf. Theogn. 281 deilw=| ga/r t' a)pa/lamna brotw=| pa/ra po/ll) a)nele/sqai | pa\r podo/s, h(gei=sqai/ q' w(s kala\ pa/nta tiqei= it is in the power of wretched mortal to commit many lawless deeds, and to imagine that he directs all successfully, Pind. O. ii. 57 o(/ti qano/ntwn me\n e)nqa/d' au)ti/k) a)pa/lamnoi fre/nes | poina\s e)/tisan of the dead, lawless souls suffer at once here on earth their penalties.
u(gih\s a)nh/r: a sound man. This is a pred. after o(\s a)\n h)=| and sums up the preceding preds. Cf. Simonides, Frag. 50 Schn., 37 Bgk. kalo\n pro/swpon.
a)pei/rwn: equiv. to a)/peiros, a)perei/sios.
“Everything, even that which is ordinary, is good, provided only there is nothing base, shameful, connected with it.”
te/: epic use of the particle subjoined to relatives. See G. 151. N. 4; H. 1041.
pana/mwmon kte(.: the repetition of the following passage, already once treated, suggests that in the order of the poem it may belong here, and have been anticipated above.

tou/tou g' e(/neka: if it comes to this. Cf. Phaedo 85 b a)lla\ tou/tou g' e(/neka le/gein te xrh\ kai\ e)rwta=n o(/ti a)\n bou/lhsqe, Rep. i. 337 d a)ll' e(/neka a)rguri/ou le/ge, Polit. 304 a pei/ras me\n toi/nun e(/neka (if, then, the attempt is what is wanted) fanero\s e)/stai.—“If I must first find an absolutely blameless man, I shall be able to praise no one.”

e)pai/nhmi: verba vulgo contracta apud Lesbios semper fere verborum in m_i_ flexi
onem assumunt. Ahrens Dial. Aeol. p. 145. Still, Simonides was certainly not thinking of Pittacus in this; the Doric lyric poets as well used many of these forms.
th=| fwnh=|: alluding to 341 c.

dialabei=n: make a division, in the sense of punctuate; of the voice, pause. Isocrates, XII. 17 (diairou=ntes ou)k o)rqw=s) and Aristotle Soph. El. 4, p. 166, 25 Bk., say diairei=n. In Arist. Rhet. iii. 5 diasti/cai is so used.

Const. nu=n de/ se ye/gw, sfo/dra ga\r kte(., but from Homer down (as with a)lla\ ga/r), between nu=n de/ and the statement introduced by it, there often intervenes the reason for the latter, the final statement usually following the intervening clause with anacoluthon. See on 319 b, l. 6. Cf. Hom. M 326 nu=n d)—e)/mphs (notwithstanding) ga\r kh=res e)festa=sin qana/toio —i)/omen, Plato Symp. 180 c nu=n de\— ou) ga/r e)stin ei(=s: mh\ o)/ntos de\ e(no\s (but now, for he is not one; and since he is not one) o)rqo/tero/n e)sti pro/teron prorrhqh=nai o(poi=on (that it be determined beforehand which) dei= e)painei=n.

1 f. Socrates having concluded, it would have been in place for Protagoras to take exception to his interpretation of the poem. Although a portion is lost, it seems clear that the poet is deprecating a too severe judgment of the prince whom he had eulogized, and consequently of himself in giving the eulogy. On the interpretation, see Introd. p. 20.
kai\su/: anticipates e)moi/ following.
e)pidei/cw kte(.: Hippias then is con cerned not to discover the true sense of the poem, which cannot be manifold, but to display his own wit in an ingenious exposition.
nai/, ei)sau=qi/s ge: cf. Gorg. 447c th\n de\ a)/llhn e)pi/deicin ei)sau=qis poihsa/sqw

e)a/swmen: sc. skopei=sqai from the following skopou/menos. Cf. Alc. I. 113 d e)a/santes ou)=n peri\ au)tw=n skopou=sin o(po/tera sunoi/sei pra/casin passing over therefore the question concerning them, they ask which course will prove profitable if taken.—We expect skopw/meqa, but the expression is turned on account of the change to dir. discourse.

sumposi/ois: this custom is followed in Xen. Symp. 2. 1 e)/rxetai/ tis au)toi=s e)pi\ kw=mon (revel) *surako/sios a)/nqrwpos, e)/xwn te au)lhtri/da a)gaqh
 kai\ o)rxhstri/da (dancing-girl) tw=n ta\ qau/mata duname/nwn poiei=n kai\ pai=da pa/nu ge w(rai=on kai\ pa/nu kalw=s kiqari/zonta kai\ o)rxou/menon. These show their skill during the whole banquet. Plato, however, has the same view as the one here, when he says Symp. 176 e ei)shgou=mai th
 me
 a)/rti ei)selqou=san au)lhtri/da xai/rein e)a=n, au)lou=san e(auth=|, h)\ a)
 bou/lhtai tai=s gunaici\ tai=s e)/ndon, h(ma=s de\ dia\ lo/gwn a)llh/lois sunei=nai to\ th/meron.

a)gorai/wn: cf. a)gorai=os nou=s: o( pa/nu eu)telh\s kai\ surfetw/dhs (vulgar) ou)de\ pefrontisme/nos: oi( ga\r a)gorai=oi a)/nqrwpoi a)maqei=s kai\ a)pai/deutoi Bekk. Anecd. 339. 10; Ar. Eq. 218 fwnh\ miara/, ge/gonas kakw=s, a)gorai=os ei)=.
u(po\ a)paideusi/as: is intended to touch Protagoras in a tender spot.

timi/as: like our dear opp. to cheap. Cf. Euthyd. 304 b to\ ga\r spa/nion ti/mion, to\ de\ u(/dwr eu)wno/taton, Lys. XXII. 22 a)\n ou)=n tou/twn katayhfi/shsqe, ta/ te di/kaia poih/sete kai\ a)ciw/teron (cheaper) to\n si=ton w)nh/sesqe: ei) de\ mh/, timiw/teron.
au(toi=s, e(autw=n: the pl. of the refl. is often used for the reciprocal pron., esp. when there is a contrast with others. See G. 146, N. 3; H. 686 b.
kai\ ai( toiai/de: returns from the comparison, which was introduced by kai\ ga\r ou(=toi c.
me/n: no de/ follows. Of the two contrasted kinds of feast suggested by the comparison, only the one here considered is emphasized by me/n. Cf. 344 a, 349 d, 361 e.

la/bwntai: the sunousi/ai are personified, as Symp. 218 a oi( e)n filosofi/a| lo/goi ne/ou yuxh=s mh\ a)fuou=s o(/tan la/bwntai when the teachings of philosophy take hold of a young and noble soul. Then, with anacoluthon, those present at the sunousi/ai become the subj., a)lla\ e)w=si xai/rein kte(.
fasi/n: Socrates ironically reminds them of Hippias's expression 337 d, l. 8.
31 ff. See on 343 c, l. 55.

e)pago/menoi: cite as authorities. Cf. Hipp. Ma. 289 b h)\ ou) kai\ *(hra/kleitos tau)to\n tou=to le/gei, o(\n su\ e)pa/gei; Rep. ii. 364 c tou/tois de\ pa=si toi=s lo/gois ma/rturas poihta\s e)pa/gontai.—
au)tou/s: see on 325 a, l. 14.
kataqeme/nous: putting aside. Cf. Tim. 59 c tou\s peri\ tw=n o)/ntwn a)ei\ katatiqe)menos lo/gous.

pare/xein: intrans. submit one's self, used thus esp. of the sick man who delivers himself into the hands of
the physician. Cf. Gorg. 475 d a)lla\ gennai/ws <*> lo/gw|, w(/sper i)atrw=|, pare/xwn a)pokri/nou, Theaet. 191 a tw=| lo/gw| pare/comen w(s nautiw=ntes patei=n te kai\ xrh=sqai o(/ ti a)/n bou/lhtai like sea-sick passengers, we will submit ourselves to the argument, to trample on us and use us as it will. The refl. is added Apol. 33 b a)ll' o(moi/ws kai\ plousi/w| kai\ pe/nhti pare/xw e)mauto\n e)rwta=n, Phaedr. 228 e e)mauto/n soi e)mmeleta=n (to practise on me) pare/xein ou) pa/nu de/doktai. Cf. 312 c, l. 3, above.
bou/lh|: sc. pare/xein, cf. 342 a e)a\n de\ bou/lh| (e)me\ a)kou/ein), sou= a)kou/somai, Phaedr. 229 b kaqi/zesqai h)/, a)\n boulw/meqa, katakliqh=nai.
suneidw=men: ti/ tini share knowledge with another, then know a thing of another. Cf. Symp. 193 e ei) mh\ sunh/|- dein *swkra/tei te kai\ *)aga/qwni deinoi=s ou)=si peri\ ta\ e)rwtika/.

sxedo/n ti: limits the extent of tw=n a)/llwn, which otherwise would be equiv. to tw=n a)/llwn a(pa/ntwn. Cf. Lach. 199 c sxedo/n ti h( peri\ pa/ntwn a)gaqw=n kai\ pa/ntws e)xo/ntwn (e)pisth/mh). See on 345 d, l. 18.
mo/gis: cf. 360 d, l. 67.

prou)tra/peto: brought himself. Cf. Hom. Z 336 e)/qelon d' a)/xei+ protrape/sqai (give myself up to grief), m 381 o(po/t' a)\y e)pi\ gai=an a)p) ou)rano/qen protrapoi/mhn (turned back), Thuc. ii. 52. 2 e)s o)ligwri/an e)tra/ponto kai\ i(erw=n kai\ o(si/wn they fell into the contempt of things sacred and profane, Plat. Apol. 21 b e)/peita e)pi\ zh/thsin au)tou= toiau/thn tina\ e)trapo/mhn.
Socrates likes to preface critical discussions with an assurance
of this kind, that he is concerned only with the subject in hand. Cf. Gorg. 457 e.
le/gein ti: say something correctly, be right. Here with pa/nu, “there is a good deal in what Homer says.” Cf. 320 b, 339 c.

Cf. Hom. K 224 ff., where Diomedes says, when offering to go out as a spy, su/n te du/) e)rxome/nw, kai/ te pro\ o( tou= e)no/hsen | o(/ppws ke/rdos e)/h|: mou=nos d' ei)/ pe/r te noh/sh|, | a)lla/ te/ oi( bra/sswn te no/os lepth\ de/ te mh=tis, also Symp. 174 d, where Socrates refers to v. 224. We should have expected su/n te du/o e)rxome/nw pro\ o( tou= e)no/hsan, but, as though e)/rxontai had preceded, kai/ follows with a change of construction, so that e)rxome/nw is left as nom. abs. pro\ o( tou= stands in transposed order for o( pro\ tou= equiv. to e(/teros pro\ e(te/rou.

e)sme/n: sc. ou(/tws e)/xontes (sc. su/nduo e)rxome/nw). Similar to this are clauses like 350 b ai)sxro
 me/nta)
 ei)/h, and those in which we insert an explanatory otherwise, as 355 d ou) ga a)
 e)chma/rtanen.—The art. oi( in the expression a(/pantes a)/nqrwpoi is against Plato's usage, but the insertion of e)sme/n makes oi( a(/nqrwpoi almost independent of a(/pantes.

e)pidei/cetai, bebaiw/setai: can, not shall. Hence the subjv., the reading of most of the Mss., cannot be used. Cf. Eur. Heracl. 46 zhtou=s' o(/pou gh=s pu/rgon oi)kiou/meqa, Dem. de Cor. 16 ou)x e(te/rw| o(/tw| kako/n ti dw/somen zhtei=n, Menander (Meineke Com. Gr. iv. 240) ou)k e)k po/twn zhtou=men, w(=| pisteu/somen ta\ tou= bi/ou.

h(gou/menos: explains the preparatory e(/neka tou/tou. Cf. Theaet. 151 b tau=ta e(/neka tou=de e)mh/kuna, u(popteu/wn se w)di/nein ti kuou=nta e)/ndon (suspecting that you are in labor, great with some conception), Parm. 126 a pa/reimi/ ge e)p' au)to\ tou=to, dehso/menos u(mw=n.
kai\ dh\ kai/: see on 345 e.
o(/s ge: see on 339 d.
su\ de\ kai\ au)to/s: free resumption of ou) mo/non au)to\s kte(. above. Socrates ironically uses oi)/ei . . . ei)=nai, after the manner of Protagoras, as quite equivalent to ei)=.—
poiei=n: cf. 318 a, 319 a, 328 b.

pepi/steukas: the perf. here has its true force, expressing the action as complete while still efficient in its result; “you have such confidence in yourself.” Cf. 2 Ep. ad Tim. i. 12 oi)=da ga\r w(=| pepi/steuka, where however the verb has a stronger meaning.
a)/llwn: cf. 316 d. kai/ belongs to the whole sentence.

seauto/n: (before u(pokhruca/menos) belongs to a)pe/fhnas.—u(pokhruca/menos: lit. have proclaimed by the crier. Cf. Aeschin. III. 41 a)/lloi de/ tines u(pokhruca/menoi tou\s au(tw=n oi)ke/tas a)fi/esan a)peleuqe/rous let them go free. Here used figuratively, expressing a boastful praise of himself, in which Protagoras indulged.
ei)s pa/ntas tou\s *(/ellhnas: see on 312 a.

misqo/n: cf. 328 b. The Homeric a)/rnusqai had been preserved in the expression misqo\n a)/rnusqai, this commonly taking the derived form misqarnei=n. But many other Homeric words are found in Plato, cf. Sengebusch Homerica Dissert. i. 122.—The innovation of the sophists, in asking pay for their instruction, must seem, to the high spirit of a free Athenian, an unworthy act of trade.—After the discomfort of Protagoras in 333

a b, and the unexpected outcome of the discussion of Simonides's poem, it would seem that the sophist would hardly have listened with unmixed pleasure to Socrates's recapitulation of his ample professions, closing with the fact that he was the first to charge a fee; especially when this rehearsal constituted an argument for his doing what he was especially disinclined to do: pw=s ou)=n kte(.
a)namnhsqh=nai: ironically indicates the fear that he has forgotten some point. Cf. 350 c, l. 35 ou) kalw=s mnhmoneu/eis.
h)=n to\ e)rw/thma: cf. 329 c, l. 35.
u(po/keitai: the same idea is expressed from the other side in e)pi\ . . . pra/gmati above, and pra/gmati . . . e)pikei=sqai below; cf. in Eng. ‘am known under such a name.’
e(/kaston: partitive appos. with pra=gma.

u(po/logon: charged to one's account (cf. u(pologi/zesqai), reckoned against one. Cf. Lach. 189 b mhde
 th
 h(mete/ran h(liki/an u(po/logon poiou/menos, Lys. XXVIII. 13 ou)de\ a)di/kws tou/tois fhmi\ a)
 ei)=nai u(po/logon th
 e)kei/nwn fugh/n, Dem. XXXVI. 48 a)ciou=ntes mhde
 u(po/logon ei)=nai, ei)/ pote tou= sou= patro\s e)ge/neto.
me/n: (after mo/ria) im plies an antithesis, ou) de\ o)no/mata pe/nte e)pi\ e(ni\ pra/gmati, as indicated in l. 28 above. See on 347 e, l. 29.
h( de\ a)ndrei/a: this forms the subject of discussion in the Laches.

diafero/ntws: not in 359 b (where other points are repeated freely). This is not so much a strengthening of the superlative, as an emphasizing of a)ndreiota/tous above the preceding superlatives. Peculiarly, surpassing all the rest, are they very courageous. Thus also in Tim. 23 c po/lis a)ri/sth pro/s te to
 po/lemon kai\ kata\ pa/nta eu)nomwta/th diafero/ntws, Thuc. viii. 68. 3
pare/sxe de\ kai\ o( *fru/nixos e(auto
 pa/ntwn diafero/ntws proqumo/taton e)s th
 o)ligarxi/an. Thus in some cases ma=llon with the comp.

i)/tas, i)e/nai: Protagoras follows the etymology; i)/ths: a)nti\ tou= i)tamo/s, sklhro/s, tolmhro/s, kai\ di) au)tw=n xwrw=n tw=n pragma/twn Schol. Ar. Nub. 445. In Symp. 203 d, Eros is described as a)ndrei=os w)\n kai\ i)/ths kai\ su/ntonos bold, reckless, and alert.

ei) mh\ mai/nomai/ ge: cf. Euthyd. 283 e h)= dokei= soi oi(=o/n t' ei)=nai yeu/desqai; *nh\ *di/a, e)/fh, ei) mh\ mai/nomai/ ge, Rep. X. 608 d su\ de\ tou=t' e)/xeis le/gein; *ei) mh\ a)dikw= g), e)/fhn.
to\ me/n ti: not adverbial acc., but nom., as au)tou= shows. So o(/lon.

kolumbw=si: this employment of divers, probably for the recovery of articles which had fallen in, or for the cleaning out of wells, is mentioned also in Lach. 193 c kai\ o(/soi a)\n e)qe/lwsin ei)s fre/ar katabai/nontes kai\ kolumbw=ntes karterei=n e)n tou/tw| tw=| e)/rgw|, and by Hesych. kolumbhta/s: tou\s e)k tw=n frea/- twn a)nape/mpontas tou\s ka/dous. The e)pista/tai tw=n u(da/twn in Athens had special oversight of the wells and cisterns; an important function, in the meagreness of the water supply.

a)/fippoi: the rare word is explained as a)pei/rws e)/xontas i(ppikh=s by the Schol. on Rep. i. 335 c a)=r' ou)=n th=| i(ppikh=| oi( i(ppikoi\ a)fi/ppous (du/nantai poiei=n) then by the equestrian art can the horsemen make others bad horsemen?

Iphicrates, an able Athenian general in the first half of the fourth century B.C., greatly increased the effectiveness of the peltastai/, although such troops are mentioned before his time. Thucydides, in ii. 29, iv. 28, speaks of Thracian, and Xenophon, in the Anabasis, distinguishes Thracian and Grecian peltasts. Cf. An. i. 8. 5 to\ *(ellhniko\n peltastiko/n, vi. 5. 26 oi( *(/ellhnes peltastai/. In vi. 2. 16, the Thracian peltasts of Clearchus are distinguished from those which followed Xenophon.

au)toi\ . . . maqei=n: Cf. e, l. 48 below. After au)toi\ e(autw=n with comps., a second comparison sometimes follows by way of explanation. Cf. Legg. i. 649 a (o( oi)=nos) pio/nta to\n a)/nqrwpon au)to\n au(tou= poiei= prw=ton i(/lewn (goodnatured) eu)qu\s ma=llon h)\ pro/teron, Hdt. viii. 86 e)ge/nonto makrw=| a)mei/nones au)toi\ e(wutw=n h)\ pro\s *eu)boi/h|, Thuc. vii. 66.

tou\s a)ndrei/ous: about the courageous. le/gein is rarely used thus with an acc., without a following o(/ti or w(s and a finite verb. Here, instead of o(/ti (w(s) qarrale/oi ei)si/, the acc. with the inf. is used. Cf. Symp. 199 e peirw= dh\ kai\ to
 *)/erwta ei)pei=n: o( *)/erws e)/rws e)sti
 ou)deno\s h)\ tino/s; 178 b *parmeni/dhs de\ th
 *ge/nesin le/gei, prw/tiston me
 kte(., Phaedo 94 d oi(=o/n pou kai\ *(/omhros e)n *)odussei/a| pepoi/hken, ou(= le/gei to
 *)odusse/a: sth=qos de\ plh/cas kte(.
e)kei= au)=: cf. a above.

sofi/a: sofi/a, ma/qhsis, e)pisth/mh are here (ef. 349 b ff.) interchanged as synonymous expressions (a)maqesta/tous, ma/qwsin, e)pisth/mones), and to this refers the censure in Arist. Eth. N. iii. 11 dokei= de\ kai\ h( e)mpeiri/a h( peri\ e(/kasta a)ndrei/a tis ei)=nai: o(/qen kai\ o( *swkra/ths w)|h/qh e)pisth/mhn ei)=nai th\n a)ndrei/an. The true nature of e)pisth/mh Plato leaves here unexamined; but Protagoras, in failing to take up this point in his contest with Socrates, is shown not to observe the lack of accuracy, but to be satisfied with the indefinite idea of insight. See Introd. p. 23.

Protagoras has maintained in 349 d that courage and knowledge are frequently dissociated. In opposition to this, Socrates has shown that, while people often confound daring with
courage, only that daring which is accompanied by knowledge can correctly be called courage; from which it follows that courage and knowledge are inseparably connected. When now Plato makes Protagoras say that his statement that the courageous are also daring, has been unfairly turned about by Socrates, this is wholly aside from the point at which Socrates was aiming. By this objection, as well as by his irrelevant illustration, Protagoras shows that he has misunderstood the purpose of Socrates. For this reason Socrates does not follow him, but from another point takes up a new line of proof.
to/te: “when you discussed this.”

tou\s de\ . . . w(molo/ghsa: Protagoras might simply have said tou\s de\ a)ndrei/ous w(s ou) qarrale/oi ei)si/, ou)damou= e)pe/deicas. He wishes, however, at the same time, to assert that Socrates has not overthrown his position. So, instead of ou)damou= e)pe/deic<*>s, he says ou)damou= e)pe/deicas o(/ti to\ e)mo\n o(molo/ghma ou)k o)rqw=s w(molo/ghsa, w(s oi( a)ndrei=oi ou) qarrale/oi ei)si/n, while we, in our mode of thought, should have expected w(s qarrale/oi ei)si/ (without ou)). This use of w(s ou) qarrale/oi rests upon the idiom found also i.e. in Gorg. 482 b h)\ ou)=n e)kei/nhn e)ce/legcon w(s ou) to\ a)dikei=n e)sti kai\ a)dikou=nta di/khn mh\ dido/nai a(pa/ntwn e)/sxaton kakw=n, h)\ kte(. either refute her (sc. Philosophy, and prove) that to do wrong and escape the penalty is not the worst of all evils, or etc. Here, after e)ce/legcon, instead of the principle to be refuted, there is added the principle which is to be established by the refutation of its opposite.
a)pofai/neis: Protagoras himself had drawn and admitted this inference, cf. 350 a.
e)n tou/tw|: in consequence of this, in so far, cf. 324 e.

50 f. Protagoras introduces a singu lar flaw into his logic. He has admitted (350 a) that oi( e)pisth/mones tw=n mh\ e)pistame/nwn qarralew/teroi/ ei)si, and
that

(b) oi( qarrale/oi ou(=toi (sc. oi( a)/neu e)pisth/mhs) ou)k a)ndrei=oi/ ei)sin, and Socrates has drawn the inference (c) h( sofi/a a)\n a)ndrei/a ei)/h (i.e. e)sti/). Now, however, Protagoras declares that oi( e)pista/menoi dunatw/teroi/ ei)si tw=n mh\ e)pistame/nwn, then, omitting the needful premise oi( a)/neu e)pisth/mhs dunatoi\ ou)k i)sxuroi/ ei)si, which of course no one would think of asserting, he would have Socrates draw the conclusion h( sofi/a e)sti\n i)sxu/s.
tou/tois: does not depend upon toi=s au)toi=s, but toi=s au)toi=s tou/tois simply repeats and strengthens tou/tw| tw=| tro/pw| above.
ei)=nai: depends, like ou) ga\r tau)to\n ei)=nai above, upon o(mologw=.

60 ff. Protagoras attempts to controvert the interchange, which he imputes to Socrates, of qa/rsos and a)ndrei/a, by instituting an analogy between them and the two terms du/namis and i)sxu/s, which like them, if the derivation of the consequents (gi/gnesqai ll. 55, 60) is immediate, stand in the relation of genus and species, viz.: qa/rsos: a)ndrei/a= du/namis: i)sxu/s. The two antecedents he derives from te/xnh and e)pisth/mh respectively, and from qumo/s and mani/a in common; the two consequents, from fu/sis, and respectively from eu)trofi/a th=s yuxh=s and eu)trofi/a tou= sw/matos. The difficulty is to ascertain the exact nature of these relations asserted to be equal, to identify the generic marks in both genus and species, and, in any view, to harmonize this with his previous statements. As all a)ndrei/oi are qarrale/oi, and all i)sxuroi/ are dunatoi/, the source of a)ndrei/a must be found in that of qa/rsos, and of i)sxu/s in that of du/namis. But it is difficult, for instance, to indentify fu/sis, one source of a)ndrei/a, with either te/xnh or qumo/s, two of the sources of qa/rsos,—leaving mani/a out of the question. The te\ kai/, moreover, connect qumo/s so closely with mani/a as almost to force us to take the former in a bad sense, anger, passion. Again, it is sufficiently difficult to identify fu/sis, one source of i)sxu/s, with e)pisth/mh or qumo/s, sources of du/namis, but the attempt to identify with either of these the other source of i)sxu/s, viz. <*>u)trofi/a tou= sw/matos, amounts to an absurdity.
XXXV.
1 f. Socrates is unable to follow the above style of reasoning, and opens another approach.
This reply of Protagoras looks as though he intended to make a distinction between higher and lower happiness, or between the agreeable and the good; but he does not carry out any such distinction.

mh\ kai\ su\ kte(.: the common notion of agreeable and disagreeable considers only the moment, the passing feeling of desire and aversion. Thus the agreeable can be viewed as harmful (i.e. in its results) and bad, the disagreeable, as beneficial and good. The sophists regarded it as the best gift of fortune, to be able to enjoy the pleasure of the moment without fear of consequences. Protagoras holds himself aloof from this, and follows the common view; for he does not comprehend the Socratic idea, that the truly agreeable is only that which remains such, i.e. the good, and that only ignorance confounds the transient with the permanent. Plato, however, who in this holds the Socratic view, does not bring out its full contrast with that of Protagoras, since he is concerned only to show the obscurity of the sophist upon the very subject matter of his own teaching.

kaq' o(\ kte(.: const. ta\ h(de/a kata\ tou=to a)gaqa/ e)sti, kaq' o(\ h(de/a e)sti/, mh\ ei)/ ti a)p) au)tw=n a)pobh/setai a)/llo. kata\ tou=to and ei)/ ti . . . a)/llo are contrasted. “According to the concept itself, I mean without reference to outward consequences.” The emphasis is thus thrown strongly upon the thought that only the concept itself is to be considered, not the consequences of the concrete reality (cf. 353 d). If, with the inferior Mss., we read ei) mh/ ti, a single case only is excepted, in which the h(de/a are not also a)gaqa/. Cf. Phaedo 77 e, where ma=llon de\ mh\ w(s h(mw=n dedio/twn is added in order to heighten the contrast of i)/sws e)/ni tis e)n h(mi=n pai=s o(/stis fobei=tai with the preceding w(s (h(mw=n) dedio/twn, Crito 47 d peiqo/menoi mh\ th=| tw=n e)pai+o/ntwn do/ch|, where mh/ with the words following enhances the contrast between that which we do and that which we ought to do (pei/qesqai th=| tw=n e)pai+o/ntwn do/ch|). Cf. also 359 a, ll. 3, 6.
12-One is tempted to believe that this guarded threefold division had actually been made by Protagoras. See on 334 a.
a)sfale/steron : a)lhqe/steron would have had more ethical weight.
Const. e)/sti de\ (tw=n h(de/wn kai\ a)niarw=n) a(/ e)stin (a)gaqa\ kai\ kaka/).
w(/sper su\ le/geis kte(.: Protagoras requests that now also they follow the method for which Socrates has a preference, cf. 348 c, 349 e. ske/mma is that which is reached by the skopei=sqai.

pro\s lo/gon: reasonable, in accordance with fact. Cf. 343 d, 344 a, Phil. 33 c kai\ ei)sau=qis e)piskeyw/meqa, e)a\n pro\s lo/gon ti h)=|. With pro\s lo/gon, cf. kata\ lo/gon, meta\ lo/gon.—The investigation properly conducted is to reach the result that the agreeable and the good appear as one and the same thing, as is indicated by the position of me/n, de/.
ei) de\ mh/: sc. pro\s lo/gon dokh=| ei)=nai kte(.

di/kaios: sc. ei)=, a rare ellipsis. Cf. Theaet. 143 d soi\ dh\ ou)k o)li/gistoi plhsia/zousi (by no means a few resort to you), kai\ dikai/ws: a)/cios ga/r, Gorg.
487 d kai\ mh\n o(/ti ge oi(=os parrhsia/zesqai (to speak frankly), au)to/s te fh\|s kai\ o( lo/gos o(mologei= soi. See on 319 b, l. 6.
kata/rxeis: pres., because the sense is you are (still) the leader.
The apod. of ei) ei)/poi, naturally expected after w(/sper (i.e. a)\n ge/noito), is lost sight of, and instead of it, kai\ e)gw\ toiou=to/n ti poqw= follows with anacoluthon.
ta\s . . . a)/kras: the hands. Homer often uses xei/r to denote the arm.

pw=s . . . e)pisth/mhn: Socrates is still aiming at the relation of courage to the other virtues, in order to arrive at this relation through the identity of the agreeable and the good. He now seeks to bring out the predominance of the understanding in man.
Const. kai\ (referring to 351 c mh\ kai\ su/, w(/sper oi( polloi/, kte(.) tou=to (sc. e)pisth/mh, 357 c) dokei= soi ou(/tws (sc. ei)=nai or e)/xein), w(/sper kte(.
toiou/tou: pred.
polla/kis: const. with a)/rxein.

This passage is referred to by Arist. Eth. N. vii. <*> deino
 ga e)pisth/mhs e)nou/shs, w(s w)/|eto *swkra/ths, a)/llo ti kratei=n kai\ perie/lkein au)to
 (to
 e)pista/menon) w(/sper a)ndra/podon.
a)\n krathqh=nai: represents krathqei/h a)/n, as though preceded by an opt. in the prot., making a milder statement of the case.
a(/n: i.e. a(\ a)/n, cf. Gorg. 486 e a(/n moi su\ o(mologh/sh|s.
ei)/ pe/r tw| a)/llw|: cf. 329 b, l. 28.

mh\ ou)xi/: because ai)sxro/n e)sti, a)/noia/ e)sti, ai)sxu/nomai are regarded as neg. expressions. See GMT. 95, 2, N. 1, Rem.—As a teacher of wisdom and virtue, Protagoras must maintain their value; thus Socrates, by associating Protagoras with himself in combating the vulgar view, involves him also in the final conclusion, that all virtue is wisdom.
ge/gwn: connected, as is freq. the partic. in conversation, with a verb used by the previous speaker. Here sc. fh/|s, from fhmi/ implied in the words of Protagoras.
Protagoras thinks it unprofita ble to follow up the idle opinions of ignorant men; see 353 a, l. 75, below.
u(po\ tw=n h(donw=n h(tta=sqai: is pred. of o(/ (cf. 353
a c, 354 e, 357 c), but the true character of that which they call ‘being controlled by the passions’ is repeated and appended freely to the rel. clause, kai\ ou) pra/ttein kte(.
tau=ta: see on 325 a, l. 14.
e)pei\ gignw/skein: on the inf. by assimilation after e)pei/ in indir. disc., see GMT. 92, 2, N. 3; H. 947. Cf. Phaedo 109 e.
tou=to to\ pa/qhma: sc. gignw/skontas ta\ be/ltista ou)k e)qe/lein pra/ttein, e)co\n au)toi=s, cf. 352 d.
h(donh=s: for the gen. after verbs implying comparison, see G. 175, 2; H. 749.

a)lla/: now (like at after si); not infreq. after ei). Cf. Phaedo 91 b ei) de\ mhde/n e)sti teleuth/santi, a)ll' ou)=n h(=tton toi=s parou=sin a)hdh\s e)/somai o)duro/menos but, if all is ended when one is dead, I shall at least be less disagreeable to my friends through lamentations.
o(/ ti a)\n tu/xwsi: (sc. le/gontes) the first thing that strikes them. Cf. Crito 45 d o(/ ti a)\n tu/xwsi, tou=to pra/cousi.
h(=|: const. tau/th| e(/pou, h(=|.
ei) de\ mh\ bou/lei (e)mme/nein), e)w= xai/rein, ei)/ soi fi/lon (e)me\ xai/rein e)a=n).
a)/llo ti: or a)/llo ti h)/, equiv. to nonne, cf. Apol. 24 c. See G. 282, 3; H. 1015 b.

oi(=on kte(.: the particulars of the
general toi=sde follow fate/ in the nom. and inf.
o(/mws de/: see on 326 d, l. 45.

o(/ ti paqo/nta kte(.: the Mss. have o(/ ti maqo/nta. A difficult passage. Entirely suitable to the context is the thought that in judging whether the agreeable as such is good, the quality of that which is agreeable is of no importance. Now the phrase ti/ paqw/n (GMT. 109, N. 7, b) has the meaning, what has happened to him, what ails him that, wherefore? Cf. Ar. Pax 699 (*krati=nos) a)pe/qanen, o(/q' oi( *la/kwnes e)ne/balon. HERM. ti/ paqw/n; TRYG. o(/ ti; The phrase ti/ maqw/n is regarded as having a similar meaning (what put it into his head, with what idea, wherefore?), but G. Hermann (Ar. Nub. p. xlvi. ff.) and others rightly replace it everywhere with ti/ paqw/n. We read then in our passage o(/ ti paqo/nta, and compare with it Apol. 36 b ti/ a)/cio/s ei)mi paqei=n h)\ a)poti=sai, o(/ ti paqw
 e)n tw=| bi/w| ou)x h(suxi/an h)=gon what do I deserve to suffer, or what fine to pay, that I fell into such a condition that I could not keep quiet during my life? and Euthyd. 299 a polu\ me/ntoi dikaio/teron a)
 to
 u(me/teron pate/ra tu/ptoimi, o(/ ti paqw
 sofou\s ui(ei=s ou(/tw e)/fusen (whatever ailed him to beget such wise sons). We find then as the thought, through whatsoever means and in whatsoever way they cause one to enjoy oneself. With paqo/nta an indef. tina/ (acc. obj.) is understood, by a customary use of the partic.
tou\s pollou/s: Protagoras wa rily retains the original designation, instead of saying tou\s a)nqrw/pous.
w(/s famen ... *prwtago/ras: Protagoras allows this to pass as his opinion, and thus accepts it. If he had a different principle in mind in 351
c d, here was the place to urge it.
a)/n: is repeated in the following fai/en a)/n.—
w)= a)/nqrwpoi oi( le/gontes: cf. 337 c h(mei=s oi( a)kou/ontes, w)= a)/ndres oi( paro/ntes.
au)= a)gaqa\ a)niara/: cf. 353 c ponhra\ . . . ei)=nai.
kau/sewn kte(.: i.e. all forms of the healing art, surgery, medicine, diet.
limoktoniw=n: hunger cure. Galen, 15, p. 829 K., explains it as a)siti/a pantelh/s, or at least h( e)pi\ toi=s po/masi mo/nois di/aita a diet of drinks only.

a)/llwn: obj. gen. Cf. Gorg. 514 a e)a\n mh\ kalh\ ka)gaqh\ h( dia/noia h)=| tw=n mel- lo/ntwn h)\ xrh/mata polla\ lamba/nein h)\ a)rxh/n tinwn h)\ a)/llhn du/namin h(ntinou=n unless there be an honorable and good mind in those who are to receive much money, or the rule of others, or any other sort of power.
fai=en a)/n: after the double question, refers to the second member, which introduces with the corrective h)/ the true belief of the speaker.

tau=ta kte(.: must refer to ta\ gumna/sia kte(., ll. 29 f. It is the conclusion of the whole series beginning with ou)kou=n pa/lin l. 27, and corresponds to the closing sentence of the first series ou)kou=n fai/netai kte(. l. 23. For this reason de/ (which the Mss. have for dh/) cannot be correct.
dokei=: sc. au)tou\s a)\n fa/nai.
o)/n: for ou)=san, under the influence of a)gaqo/n. Cf. 359 d, l. 31 ou)=sa, and so freq.
a)ne/roisqe: we should have expected ei)/ me a)ne/roinq' oi( a)/nqrwpoi (cf. 353

a c), but it is quite in the style of the Platonic Socrates, that he so far yields to the inclination to introduce discussions in the form of animaginary dialogue, as here, in this supposed conversation with the multitude, to imagine also a second dialogue with them.
e)/peita: see on 310 c, l. 18.
e)n tou/tw| kte(.: on this point the whole argument turns.
See on 353 e, l. 23.

le/gete: after o(/tan le/ghte above, we should have expected here kai\ u(/tan au)=qis au)= le/ghte, but after the long objective clause with o(/ti, the discourse, as is frequently the case, changes to the independent form. For this reason, in order to characterize this second part of what the multitude say as also ridiculous, the words are added, w(s de\ tau=ta geloi=a/ e)sti. Cf. 357 c, l. 89.

a)/ra: the previous discussion leads to the result that the use of four words is unnecessary, two being sufficient; since good and agreeable, bad and disagreeable, coincide. a)/ra has its position late in the sentence also in Gorg. 519 b polla\ kai\ a)gaqa\ th\n po/lin pepoihko/tes a)/ra a)po/lluntai.
au)ta/: i.e. the concepts.
ou(/tw: belongs to qe/menoi. What follows is the assertion of the multitude (cf. 352 d, l. 60).
h(ttw/menos: sc. o(/mws au)ta\ poiei=.

u(po\ me\n h(donh=s: sc. h(ttw/menon, ta\ kaka\, gignw/skonta o(/ti kaka/ e)sti, poiei=n. Instead of having me/n followed by its correlative, u(po\ de\ a)/llou lekte/on, we have, with anacoluthon, e)kei/nw| dh\ kte(.
u(bristh/s: inclined to mockery.
e)n u(mi=n: before you as judges. See on 337 b, l. 34.
ou) ga\r a)\n kte(.: see on 348 d, l. 6. “If the good were equal to the evil, or greater, evidently there would be no error in choosing it.”

a)na/cia: as that is a)/cion w)nh=s which is worth being taken for its price, so here to\ a)gaqo/n is a)na/cion tou= kakou= when it is not worthy to be chosen in preference to the bad, while kako/n ti is a)/cion a)gaqou= when it de serves to be chosen in place of the good.
plei/w: see on 330 a, l. 16.
e)pi\ toi=s au)toi=s: cf. 349 b, l. 29 e)pi\ e(ni\ pra/gmati.

a)ci/a: Cicero's translation (Prisc. v. 64), quae igitur potest esse indignitas voluptatis ad molestiam, nisi in magnitudine aut longitudine alterius utrius posita? shows that the
false reading of the Mss. a)naci/a, which arose from the preceding a)naci/wn, is very old. a)naci/a is not found as a subst., while *d*h and AN are often interchanged.

After the substs. u(perbolh/ and e)/lleiyis, we should expect tau=ta d' e)sti\ to\ mei/zw te kai\ smikro/tera gi/gnesqai, but the sentence is const. as though replying to the question kai\ pw=s a)/llws a)/cia ta\ h(de/a pro\s ta\ luphra/, a)ll' h)\ u(perba/llonta a)/llhla kai\ e)llei/ponta;
h(du/: we should have expected h(du\ kai\ luphro/n, but, as the words stand, we must regard kai\ luphrou=, which follows, as an afterthought.
a)gaqo\s i(sta/nai: good at weigh- ing.

e)a
 de\ h(de/a kte(.: to this are subord. e)a
 me
 ta\ a)niara\ kte(., and e)a
 de\ ta\ h(de/a kte(., and to this e)a
 me/n, again, are subord. e)a/n te—e)a/n te.
e)a/n te, e)a/n te: whether, or. See H. 1045, 2.
tau=ta: sc. ta\ h(de/a.
prakte/a: sc. ta\ h(de/a.
o(/te: causal, quum, quando, since.

mege/qh: objects of any size, magnitudes. Cf. Phil. 41 e e)n me\n o)/yei to\ po/rrwqen kai\ e)ggu/qen o(ra=n ta\ mege/qh th\n a)lh/qeian a)fani/zei in vision, the near and distant seeing of mag-
nitudes obscures the true proportions, Phaedo 111 d kai\ a)ena/wn (ever-flowing) potamw=n a)mh/xana mege/qh.
e)n tou/tw|: see on 310 d, l. 27.
mh/kh pra/ttein: the peculiar expression is chosen to conform the illustration to the truth to be explained, namely, that it is knowledge which must determine us ta\ h(de/a h)\ ta\ luphra\ pra/ttein.
h( . . . du/namis: the (subjective) impression of the visible world. The passage is directed against Protagoras's theory of knowledge. See Introd. p. 3.

e)pla/na kai\ e)poi/ei : a)/n is not added, because the a)/n with e)fa/nh above is still in force. Cf. Phaedr. 229 c ou)k a)
 a)/topos ei)/hn: ei)=ta fai/hn, Phaedo 87 e a)n- agkai=on me/nta)
 ei)/h . . . to/t' h)/dh e)pideiknu/oi, Lys. 208 b e)w=|en a)/n. po/qen e)w=|en; Ar. Eq. 1057 ou)k a)
 maxe/saito: xe/saito ga/r.
pra/cesi, ai(re/sesi: limit both preceding verbs.
a)/kuron: without force, vain. Cf. Crito 50 b e)n h(=| ai( geno/menai di/kai mhde\n i)sxu/ousin, a)ll' u(p) i)diwtw=n a)/kuroi gi/gnontai.
me/nousan: opp. to e)pla/na above.

th
 metrhtikh/n: sc. o(mologei=n a)
 tou\s a)nqrw/pous sw/|zein a)
 h(ma=s pro\s tau=ta.
au)to pro\s e(auto/: i.e. to\ peritto\n pro\s to\ peritto/n or to\ a)/rtion pro\s to\ a)/rtion.
e)sti/n: the gen. with ei)=nai expresses here the object with which the art has to do.
a)/n: const. with o(mologei=n.

tou=: introduces all the following gens., and also the advs. porrwte/rw and e)ggute/rw. Cf. 356 a, l. 33, where the advs. ma=llon kai\ h(=tton are co-ordinated with mei/zw te kai\ smikro/tera kte(. With fai/netai is to be supplied h( swthri/a tou= bi/ou ou)=sa.
pro\s a)llh/las: i.e. h(donh=s pro\s lu/phn kai\ lu/phs pro\s h(donh/n.
h(ni/ka: cf. 352 c ff.

u(mei=s de\ dh\ kte(.: does not depend upon h(ni/ka, but stands independently; hence the repetition with anacoluthon of e)peidh\ de\ u(mi=n ou)x w(mologou=men, meta\ tou=to h)/resqe h(ma=s. See on 355 b, l. 73.
*prwtago/ra kte(.: cf. 353 a.
a)lla/: in apod., cf. Hom. *q 154.
e)pisth/mhs: sc. e)ndei/a|.—
ei)s to\ pro/sqen: going further, see on 339 d, l. 33.
102... lang=greek>tou=to: is the subj. (“this of which you ask, namely to\ h(donh=s h(/ttw ei)=nai”); a)maqi/a h( megi/sth is the predicate.

105... lang=greek>ou)/te au)toi/: sc. e)/rxesqe. There should regularly follow, ou)/te oi( u(me/teroi pai=des e)/rxontai para\ kte(., but with the second ou)/te the const. changes. Cf. Dem. XXIX. 54 o( d' ou)/t) au)to\s (o)mo/sai) ou)/t' e)kei/nois ou)/t) e)moi\ dou=nai to
 o(/rkon h)ci/wsen, XLIX. 52 ou) ga dh/pou a)/neu ge staqmou= h)/mellen ou)/q' o( u(potiqe/menos (paralh/yesqai) ou)/q' o( u(potiqei\s to
 xalko
 paradw/sein for it surely was not likely that the mortgagor would receive the money, or the mortgagee pay it, without weighing it.
106... lang=greek>tou/twn: i.e. “of all that leads to h(donh=s mh\ h(/ttw ei)=nai.” This (tou= h(donh=s mh\ h(tta=sqai) is understood with the following w(s ou) didaktou= o)/ntos.
108. Cf. 318 e, ll. 42 ff.—Socrates, with exquisite irony, supports the custom of the sophists, and his apostrophe naturally pleases them marvellously (cf. 358 a u(perfuw=s).

Socrates has established the two theses at which he has been aiming, viz., that the agreeable is the good, and that the understanding rules in man. He now moves on to connect these two principles with
the relation of a)ndrei/a to the other virtues. See on 352 b, l. 39, 359 c, l. 19.

h(mi=n: “for let us all make the examination together.” Prodicus and Hippias had been invited at the outset 317 d, but Socrates repeats particularly 343 c e)piskeyw/meqa dh\ au)to\ koinh=| a(/pantes and 358 d sunedo/kei a(/pasin h(mi=n. By taking the others along with Protagoras, Socrates makes it the more difficult for the latter to break away again before the consummation of the argument, cf. 360 d.
diai/resin: see on 337 a, l. 26.

ei)/te . . . o)noma/zwn: Plato frequently alludes thus to the custom of using various bynames in invocations of the gods, as poluwnumi/a showed the manifold honor of the deity. Cf. Crat. 400 e w(/sper e)n tai=s eu)xai=s no/mos e)sti\n h(mi=n eu)/xesqai, oi(/tine/s te kai\ o(po/qen xai/rousin o)nomazo/menoi by whatever names and whence soever they please to be invoked, Symp. 212 c tou=ton ou)=n to\n lo/gon w(s e)gkw/mion no/mison ei)rh=sqai, ei) de/, o(/ ti kai\ o(/ph| xai/reis o)noma/zwn (whatever and however you choose to name it), tou=to o)no/maze, Aesch. Ag. 160 *zeu/s, o(/stis pot) e)sti/n.—
o(po/qen... lang=greek>o)noma/zwn: cf. Hom. K 68 patro/qen e)k geneh=s o)noma/zwn a)/ndra e(/kaston.
tou=to kte(.: “use that expression, that word, which pleases you best, in your reply to my question.” Cf. Symp. 212 c.

e)pi\ tou/tou: cannot express an aim, the actions directed at this (plei=n e)pi\ *sa/mou Thuc. i. 116 and similar expressions are entirely different); but the meaning is that, “the actions belonging in this sphere (viz. of the agreeable and painless life), so soon as the agreeable and the good are one and the same, are noble.” e)pi\ tou/tou can then be compared with e)pi\ tou= sou= bi/ou Phaedr. 242 a and similar passages.—The whole passage ai( e)pi\ tou/tou . . . w)fe/limon is somewhat strange. But Socrates wishes to show that no one who knows what is truly agreeable, and is aware that the truly and permanently agreeable is good, will do, or will wish to do, anything that does not bring this pleasure. Hence Socrates concludes that, if the agreeable is good, all actions connected with this are noble, and consequently good and useful. For no one will wish to do anything else than what is good and useful.

kai\ dunata/: every one is perfectly conscious that there are deeds better than his own, but which he does not do because they are beyond his power. Thus a)/lla belti/w needs the limitation kai\ dunata/, and this alone gives meaning to the words e)co\n ta\ belti/w.—
e)/peita: see on 319d, l. 26.
h(/ttw ei)=nai au(tou=: less precise than the former expression h(donh=s h(tta=sqai etc., but this marks the unreasonableness of the supposed experience. Cf. 352 b ff.
tou=to: repeats with emphasis to\ h(/ttw ei)=nai au(tou=.
a)/llo ti: see on 353 c, l. 5.

a)nti\ tw=n a)gaqw=n: ‘brachylogy’ for a)nti\ tou= i)e/nai e)pi\ ta\ a)gaqa/. Cf. Symp. 195 c ne/os me
 ou)=n e)sti/: pro\s de\ tw=| ne/w| a(palo/s (and besides being young, tender), Theaet. 185 e kalo\s ga ei)=: pro\s de\ tw=| kalw=| eu)= e)poi/hsa/s me, Phil. 41 c ou)kou=n to\ me
 e)piqumou=n h)=n h( yuxh\ tw=n tou= sw/matos e)nanti/wn e(/cewn, i.e. tw=n e)nanti/wn tw=n tou= sw/matos e(/cewn it was the soul then, that desired the states opposite to those of the body, Hdt. ii. 134 (*mukeri=nos) purami/da . . . a)peli/peto pollo
 e)la/ssw tou= patro/s i.e. th=s tou= patro/s.

de/os, fo/bos d' ou)/: Prodicus's distinction was probably the one made by Ammonius, p. 39 de/os kai\ fo/bos diafe/rei. de/os me\n ga/r e)sti poluxro/nios kakou= u(po/noia, fo/bos de\ h( parauti/ka pto/hsis. But the distinction is often neglected.
to/de: sc. diafe/rei.
u(pokeime/nwn: used as a perf. pass. of u(poti/qesqai. See on 339 d, l. 32.
to/te: cf. 330
a b.
u(/steron: cf. 349 d.
kai\ e)/ti ma=llon: sc. qauma/zw.
h)ro/mhn: cf. 349 e.
d' ou)=n: introduces a confirmation and development of the preceding statement.
i)/qi dh/: a new argument, starting from the previous concessions. Cf. 357 e.
ou)k... lang=greek>o(\s kte(.: here appears the irrelevance of Protagoras's contention in 350 c f. See on 351 b, l. 61.

qarrale/a: “matters in which one can be qarrale/os.” Cf. Rep. v. 450 e ta)lhqh= ei)do/ta le/gein a)sfale\s kai\ qarrale/on, Lach. 194 e (th
 a)ndrei/an fhsi
 ei)=nai) th
 tw=n deinw=n kai\ qarrale/wn e)pisth/mhn, 198 b.
e)n oi(=s . . . toi=s lo/gois: i.e. as Socrates had been leading the discussion. Cf. 351 e, l. 29. On the const., see on 342 b ou(\s . . . tou\s sofista/s.
a)/rti: cf. 358 c, ll. 22 ff.

e)peidh\ . . . ou)=sa: several critics would strike out these words; but they contain a brief repetition of the argument to which Protagoras has just referred. People commonly say that one sometimes does the evil knowingly, suffering oneself to be overcome by h(donh/ (cf. 352 d ff., 353 c). But now Socrates has shown that no one does this, but he who seems to do it, simply lacks the proper knowledge of good and evil; that consequently the h(/ttw ei)=nai h(donh=s or, as in 358 c, h(/ttw ei)=nai au(tou= is only a)maqi/a. It is entirely correct therefore to say here briefly “we can assert that no man chooses that which he holds to be evil, because h(/ttw ei)=nai e(autou= has been shown to be a)maqi/a.”
tau/th|: in this respect.
au)ti/ka: see on 318 b, l. 17.
e)n toi=s e)/mporsqen: cf. 358 b.
As oi( deiloi/ corresponds to ai)sxroi\ fo/boi, so oi( maino/menoi to ai)sxra\ qa/rrh.

See the definition, Xen. Mem. iv. 6. 11 oi( me\n a)/ra e)pista/menoi toi=s deinoi=s te kai\ e)pikindu/nois kalw=s xrh=sqai a)ndrei=oi/ ei)sin, oi( de\ diamarta/nontes tou/tou deiloi/. Cf. Lach. 194 e, and above, 359 c.

e)pe/neusen: the growing perception of Protagoras that a)ndrei/a and sofi/a coincide, and consequently that his position (cf. 349 d) has been completely overthrown, is admirably brought out in his increasing unwillingness to assent.
pa/nu mo/gis: cf. 348 c, l. 55.
au)to\s pe/ranon: in Gorg. 506 c Callicles says to Socrates, le/ge w)= )gaqe\ au)to\s kai\ pe/raine.

filoneikei=n: insist pertinaciously, contentiously. Cf. Rep. i. 338 a prosepoiei=to de\ filoneikei=n pro\s to\ e)me\ ei)=nai to\n a)pokrino/menon. Here in freer form is the art. with the inf. Cf. Thuc. ii. 53 to\ me\n prostalaipwrei=n ou)dei\s pro/qu- mos h)=n, Soph. Phil. 1252 a)ll' ou)de/ toi sh=| xeiri\ pei/qomai to\ dra=n but neither am I persuaded by your hand to act, Plato Soph. 247 b ai)sxu/nontai to\ tolma=n o(mologei=n they are ashamed to venture to confess. Thucydides has also the simple acc. in v. III. 4 ta\ xei/rw filoneikh=sai.
XL.

au)to\ h( a)reth/: virtue in itself. See on 330 c, l. 33. Cf. Crat. 411 d au)to\ h( no/hsis tou= ne/ou e)sti\n e(/sis mental perception in itself is an impulse towards the new, Theaet. 146 e a)lla\ gnw=nai e)pisth/mhn au)to\ o(/ ti/ pot' e)sti/n, and so frequently.
a)petei/namen: see on 329 a, l. 20, and for the discourses themselves, 319 a f. and 323 c ff.
w(/sper a)/nqrwpos: Plato not infrequently employs such personifications. The most celebrated is that of the laws, cf. Crito 50 a ff.
pa/nta xrh/mata: with a touch of contempt, everything imaginable. e)pisth/mh is predicate.
dikaiosu/nh: cf. 333 d ff.—
swfrosu/nh: cf. 332 a ff.
a)ndrei/a: cf. 349 d ff.

o(/lon: nothing more nor less than, absolutely. Cf. 349 e, l. 15, Meno 79 b e)mou= dehqe/ntos o(/lon ei)pei=n th\n a)reth/n when I asked you to tell me completely the nature of virtue, and c ei)rhkw\s o(/ ti a)reth/ e)sti to\ o(/lon, 81 d to\ ga\r zhtei=n a)/ra kai\ to\ manqa/nein a)na/mnhsis o(/lon e)sti/n.
u(poqe/menos: see on 339 d, l. 32.
e)/oike speu/donti: equiv. to e)/oike speu/dein. A very common const. in Plato, cf. Apol. 27 a e)/oike ga\r w(/sper ai)/nigma cuntiqe/nti.

pa/nta ma=llon h)\ e)pisth/mhn: any- thing else rather than knowledge. The real change was not in the position of the disputants, but in the concept of virtue under examination. Socrates had maintained that the sophistic virtue could not be taught; he has proved that the true virtue can be taught. See Introd. p. 23.

e)celqei=n: a rare use, go on from one thing to another. Cf. Thuc. i. 70. 3 kratou=nte/s te tw=n e)xqrw=n e)pi\ plei=ston e)ce/rxontai when they conquer their enemies, they push their victories to the farthest extent, Soph. O. C. 981 sou= g' ei)s to/d) e)celqo/ntos a)no/sion sto/ma when you give vent to so unhallowed words.
polla/kis: frequent in Plato after mh/ and ei), meaning perchance.
“That we may not later, grown wise by misfortune, have to come back to sound views (e)pimhqei=sqai), but may think out the whole matter clearly beforehand (promhqei=sqai).”
fh=|s: cf. 321 b ff.
w(=|: i.e. Prometheus in the myth. What is related of him Socrates will use as a model.
kat' a)rxa/s: cf. 320 b, 335 c, 348 d.
die/codon: see on 326 a, l. 19. f.

thlikou/twn, ge/noio: Protagoras avails himself of Socrates's modesty (cf. c above) to recover his own position of superiority, as the elder of Socrates, and one who is already famous. Cf. 314 b, 316 c, 317 c, 320 c, 335 a.
ei)sau=qis: cf. 347 b, l. 7.
e)/fhn: cf. 335 c, l. 38.

tw=| kalw=|: lovers and admirers in Athens saluted those dear to them through their beauty or amiability with the word kalo/s. Sitalces, in his admiration for the Athenians, e)n toi=si toi/xois e)/graf' *)aqhnai=oi kaloi/ (cf. Ar. Ach. 144). Theramenes throws off as in the ‘cottabus’ the last drops of the fatal hemlock, exclaiming, *kriti/a| tou=t' e)/stw tw=| kalw=| (see Xen. Hell. ii. 3. 56). Hence the frequent kalo/s upon vases. Socrates in Plato often uses it with mild irony; here it is also a play upon *kalli/a|.
This closing line reverts to 310 a. Hippocrates is not again mentioned, as he early retreated into the background, and has remained there during the entire conversation with Protagoras.
